{"file": "M.Sc. Applied Psychology.docx", "source": "docx", "chunk": 0, "text": "\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTemplate for P.G., Programmes \n\n\nChoice Based Credit System (CBCS), Learning Outcomes Based Curriculum Framework (LOCF) Guideline Based Credits and Hours Distribution System\nfor all Post \u2013 Graduate Courses including Lab Hours\n\nFirst Year \u2013 Semester \u2013 I \nSemester-II\nSecond Year \u2013 Semester \u2013 III\nSemester-IV\n\nTotal 91 Credits for PG Courses \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSEMESTER  I (CORE)\nCourse Name: THEORIES OF PERSONALITY\nCourse Code:\nYear and Semester:      rdyr ,th Semester\nCredits : 5\n\nOBJECTIVES: \nMajor objectives of this course are:\nTo make the student understand about personality and its determinants\nTo know the fundamentals of personality theory and its emergence to gain insight about human behavior.\nTo understand the significance of each school of thought in psychology\nTo compare and contrast the conceptual framework of various theories of personality\nTo know the recent trends in personality theories how its applied in the field of psychology\n\nLEARNING OUTCOMES: -\nOn successful completion the students will be able to :\nCO1(K2): Understand the determinants of psychology and how it emerged as significant concept of psychology\nCO2(K2): Classify and compare various personality theories\u2019 basic principles and approaches in understanding human nature.\nCO3(K4): Explain a critical understanding of personality through various Western approaches including type and trait, psychoanalytic, socio-cognitive, and humanistic and contemporary theories.\nCO4(K5): Apply different personality theory\u2019s perspectives by engaging students in a discussion about the everyday applications of various personality theories.\nCO5(K5): Adapt to apply principles of personality in counseling practices.\nLesson - Units\nUnit \u2013 I: Introduction to personality Theory - Nature of Personality- Personality theory and history. Definitions- Personality, Paradox of human nature. Personality in perspective: genetic, environmental, learning, parental, developmental factors.\nUnit \u2013 II:Psychodynamic Approach: Sigmund Freud- Psychoanalysis, Alfred Adler- Individual Psychology, Carl Jung- Analytical Psychology, Klein- Object Relations Theory\nUnit \u2013 III:Neo Psychoanalytic Approach: Karen Horney- Psychoanalytic Social Theory, Erich Fromm- Humanistic Psychoanalysis, Sullivan- Interpersonal Theory, Erikson- Post-Freudian Theory\nUnit \u2013 IV:Humanistic Approach/ Type/Cognitive /Dispositional:  Abraham Maslow- Holistic Dynamic theory. Carl Rogers- Person-Centered theory, May \u2013 Existential"}

{"file": "M.Sc. Applied Psychology.docx", "source": "docx", "chunk": 2, "text": ":      rdyr ,th Semester\nCredits : 5\n\n\nOBJECTIVES:\nMajor objectives of this course are:\nTo understand the processes of   scientific research.\nTo gain knowledge in ethics in research\nTo explore the use of appropriate research design. \nTo familiarize with various types of sampling techniques\nTo gain knowledge in research report writing\n\nLEARNING OUTCOMES: \nOn successful completion the students will be able to :\nCO1(K2): Describe the elements of research, sampling and hypothesis formulation.\nCO2(K3): Develop research report in APA Style.\nCO3(K3): Apply knowledge for the selection of appropriate research design.\nCO4(K4): Analyze ethical issues in conducting a research\nCO5(K5): Explain the steps  in  conducting Psychological research.\n\nLesson - Units\nUnit- I: Foundations of Research -Meaning \u2013 Critical thinking process \u2013 Objectives of science \u2013 Need for research \u2013 Research approaches \u2013 Steps in research. Method Vs Methodology. General Principles \u2013 Ethical issues: Children, Adults, Animals. Research problem \u2013 Sources \u2013 Criteria of good problem.Reviewing the literature \u2013 Research article.\n\nUnit- II: Hypothesis,variables and sampling- Hypothesis: Meaning \u2013 Types \u2013 Basic concepts related to hypothesis testing. Variables \u2013 Definition \u2013 Ways of asking questions \u2013 measuring observed variables \u2013 Scales of measurement \u2013 Types of measures \u2013 Reliability \u2013 Validity. Sampling \u2013 Meaning \u2013 Probability and Non-probability sampling \u2013 Sample &amp; effect size. Data collection methods: Observational research \u2013Survey research.\n\nUnit- III: Research Design: Experimental design: Independent groups designs \u2013 Completely randomized groups designs, randomized factorial groups design. Dependent groups designs: Within-participants design, matched groups design \u2013 Mixed Designs \u2013 Single-participant design \u2013 Baseline designs. Non- experimental designs: Quasi-experiments \u2013 Time-series design, nonequivalent groups designs, longitudinal research, Cross-sectional research, Case-studies, Correlational research.\n\nUnit- IV: Statistics: Organizing data: Frequency distribution \u2013 Graphs \u2013 Descriptive statistics: Measures of central tendency \u2013 Measures of variation \u2013 Types of distributions. Inferential statistics: z test \u2013 t test \u2013Analysis of Variance \u2013 Correlation\u2013 Concepts related to correlation \u2013 Correlation coefficient \u2013Regression. Non-parametric statistics: Mann-Whitney test \u2013 Wilcoxon Chi-square \u2013 Spearman Rank correlation \u2013 Kruskal-Wallis test. Analysis of data using SPSS\n\nUnit"}
====================

Computers in research \u2013 Internet and research.\n\nLearning Resources\nRecommended Text books \nEvans, A.N., &Rooney, B. J. (2011). Methods in psychological research. New Delhi, India: Sage Publications India Pvt. Ltd.\nJackson, S.L. (2015). Research methods and statistics. New Delhi, India: Cengage Learning India Pvt. Ltd.\nKothari, C. R.(2004). Research methodology,(2 nd ed). Chennai: New Age International Publishers.\nShaughnessy, J.J., Zechmeister, E.B. &amp;Zechmeister, J.S. (2006). Research Methods in Psychology. (7th ed.). Singapore: McGraw-Hill.\n\n\n\nREFERENCE BOOKS\n1. Coaley, K. (2009). An introduction to psychological assessment and psychometrics. New Delhi, India:\nSage Publications India Pvt. Ltd.\n2. Coolican, H. (2009). Research methods in statistics in psychology. New Delhi, India: Rawat\nPublications.\n3. Gravetter, F.J., &amp; Forzana, L.A.B. (2009). Research methods for behavioral sciences. Boston, MA:\nWadsworth Cengage learning.\n4. Mohanty, B., &amp; Misra, S. (2019). Statistics for behavioural and social sciences. New Delhi, India: Sage\nPublications.\n5. Myers, J. (2008). Fundamentals of behavioural statistics.\nNew York, NY: McGraw Hill.\n7. Singh, A.K. (2006). Tests, measurements and research methods in behavioural sciences. Patna, India:\nBharati Bhavan Publishers.\n\nRecap\nReviewing of Psychological research done using various research designs, sampling\ntechniques\n\nWeb source:\nhttps://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/psychology/psychological-research\nhttps://opentextbc.ca/researchmethods/chapter/qualitative-research/\nhttps://"}

{"file": "M.Sc. Applied Psychology.docx", "source": "docx", "chunk": 4, "text": "www.studysmarter.us/explanations/psychology/research-methods-in-psychology/\nhttps://www.verywellmind.com/introduction-to-research-methods-2795793\nhttps://apaformat.org/apa-format-overview/\n\n\nOut of Syllabus: Self Study\n\nDifference Between qualitative and quantitative research\nRecent research in the area of the specialization\nStudents can submit a research proposal in their area of interest\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCourse Name: COUNSELING SKILLS AND TECHNIQUES\nCourse Code:\nYear and Semester:      rdyr ,th Semester\nCredits : 4\n\nOBJECTIVES:\nThe major objectives of this course are:\nTo acquire knowledge about skill based models of counseling.\nTo examine the ethical issues in counseling\nTo understand the skills and process of online counseling.\nPractice the skills of attending, listening and responding with empathy using classroom activities and exercises.\nTo understand one\u2019 strengths and limitations in basic counseling skills.\nLEARNING OUTCOMES: \nOn successful completion the students will be able to :\nCO1(K2): Discuss the process of counseling offline and online and ethical issues.\nCO2(K3): Explain the basic counseling skills of listening, responding , challenging and formulating action plans.\nCO3(K4): Identify and differentiate skills at different stages of Counseling.\nCO4(K5): Evaluate the various counseling approaches that are skill based.\nCO5(K6): Apply the skills of counseling through classroom activities and practicum\n\n\nLesson - Units\nUnit- I: Counseling Skills and Ethical Issues: The Helping relationship and process. Specific Counseling skills: Understanding the internal frame of reference, showing attention and interest, paraphrasing and reflecting feelings, structuring, probing, monitoring, challenging, self-disclosing. Managing resistances and making referrals. Facilitating problem solving. Improving client\u2019s perceptions, negotiating homework, conducting middle sessions and terminating helping. Ethical and Legal Issues in Counseling\n\nUnit- II: The Skill Based Models of Counseling: Egan\u2019s problem management approach to helping. Stage I Problem clarification, Stage II Setting goals based on dynamic understanding, Stage III Facilitating action. Ivey and Ivey\u2019s Step by Step Micro skills model- Towards Intentional interviewing and Counseling. The Micro skills hierarchy. Drawing out client stories. Relationship-Story and Strengths- Goals- Restory- Action. Increasing skills and flexibility. Theory and Microskills.\n\nUnit- III: Listening & Empathy Building: Qualities of the Effective Listener:"}
====================
{"file": "M.Sc. Clarifying empathy\u2013 Empathy building Statements\u2013People who empathize \u2013Simple reflection of content \u2013 Simple reflection of feeling \u2013 Selective reflection \u2013 Putting it all together \u2013 Using Empathy in everyday life \u2013 Empathy in difficult situations\u2013Ethical issues \n\nUnit- IV: Activities in Counseling: Information Activities: Types of information \u2013 Pros and cons of advice-giving \u2013 Breakingbad news \u2013 Confrontation I \u2013 Confrontation II \u2013 Checking for understanding. {"file": "M.Sc. Applied Psychology.docx", "source": "docx", "chunk": 7, "text": "ometrics. Psychometrics in the 21st century. Defining the test\u2013 Classification of tests \u2013 Characteristics of standardized tests. Scaling-Selecting a scaling method. Representative scaling methods. Criterion referenced tests and norm referenced tests.\n\nUnit- II: Construction of Intelligence Tests: Item writing for Intelligence tests: Analogies, odd-man-out, sequences. Tests of ability and attainment: Content of items, multiple choice items. Advantages of multiple choice items.True-false items, matching items, choosing the item type. Other item types, arrangement of items for a test trial, guessing. Constructing Personality Inventories- Problems in constructing personality Inventories. Writing items for personality Inventories: item forms, guidelines for item writing. Eliminating response sets. Item content.\nUnit- III: Construction of Other Types of Tests: Objective tests: Advantages, principles, stimulus-instruction situation, and response scoring parameters. Distinction between objective tests of ability, temperament and dynamics. Practical hints for objective test construction in personality and motivation. Differential Activation of different subjects. The influence of ability and achievement on objective test scores. Group vs Individual tests. Objective test dimensions.Projective Tests-construction of projective tests. Item writing for mood and state scales. Attitude measurement: types of attitude scales.\n\nUnit- IV: Item Analysis: Important variables for item analysis. Two indices in item analysis- correlations of items and the total score, choice of item \u2013analytic statistics.Item scoring and item analysis-Itemdifficulty, Item discrimination, Item response theory. Selection of items after item analysis. Re-writing items.Failure to form a test.\n\nUnit- V: Test Standardization: An overview of the different types of reliability and validity. Factors affecting reliability and validity- Generalizability of test scores. Norms- Meaning and purpose of norms. Raw score transformation.Percentile And Percentile Ranks, Standardized scores. Normalizing standard scores .T scores, stanines, sten scores and C-Scale. Selecting a norm group--age and grade norms. Local and sub group norms..Practical difficulties in test construction.\nRecap: \nConducting quiz, class test, assigning students to do review sessions, \u201cQuestion hour\u201d\n\nRecommended Textbooks\nKline,P.(2015).A handbook of test construction: Introduction to psychometric design. NewYork, NY:Methuen.\nSchultz,K. S., Whitney,D.J. &Zickar,M.J.(2021) Measurement theory in action-"}

Introduction to a functional behavioral analysis. Basic behavioral principles of the A-B-C  contingency .Formal behavioral assessment. A brief look at the areas of application.\n\nUnit- II: Procedures to Establish New Behaviours: Stimulus control: discrimination and generalization. Prompting and fading techniques. Types of prompts. How to use prompting and transfer of stimulus control (for example in autism). Chaining . Examples of behavioral chains, analyzing stimulus-response chains, task analysis, backward chaining, forward chaining, total task presentation. Chaining Components of behavioral skills training procedures. Modeling, instructions, rehearsal, feedback.\n\nUnit- III: Procedures to Increase Desirable Behavior and Decrease Undesirable Behavior: Differential reinforcement of alternative behavior, differential reinforcement of other behavior-Differential reinforcement of low rates of responding. Antecedent control procedures. Using antecedent control strategies. Using punishment. Timeout, Response Cost.\nUnit- IV:  Other Behavior Change Procedures\nToken economy, practical considerations, implementing a token economy, applications of token economy, advantages and disadvantages of a token economy. Behavioral contract, components of a behavioral contract. Cognitive behavior changes procedures, Thought stopping. Introduction to third wave therapies\u2013Dialectical Behaviour therapy, Metacognitive therapy.\n\nUnit- V: Overview of Assessment, Formulation and Intervention in Clinical Conditions:\nClinical Conditions\u2013 Depression, panic, OCD, GAD, eating disorders, PTSD. {"file": "M.Sc. MP / ID / 306 \u2013 INTER DISCIPLINARY, CREDITS 3) offered in the third semester. \nThe Modules chosen by the students from the list given below will be oriented to the students in one or two (few) sessions. \nEach Student has to develop 6 modules under the guidance of a supervisor (out of which 3 will be from self-help skills topics found below and 3 from interpersonal skills topics) using psychological concepts and counseling techniques (BMT, CBT, REBT, etc could be used)  for specific target populations. \nStudents are expected to submit a project report about the training procedures.\nSELF-HELP SKILLS (Practical Oriented Teaching)\nSelf-Awareness\nStress Management & Relaxation Training\nSelf-Concept, Self Esteem Skills\nAssertiveness skills\nAnger management\nDiary keeping and self-analysis\nGoal setting behaviors\nTime management skills\nPhysical disciplines - Exercise, etc.\nReading skills\nCoping with Complexity And ambiguity\nCoping Emotions\nCoping with failures\nCreative thinking\nSelf-efficacy skills\n\n\n\nINTERPERSONAL SKILLS (Practical Oriented Teaching)\nCommunication Skills (Styles)\nFacilitation and Moderation Skills.\nConflict management\nProblem solving and Decision Making\nMotivation and Leadership Skills\nPeer Counselling\nRelationship Skills (also with reference to opposite sex and Martial relationship)\nEvent Management Skills\nTeam Building\nEmpathy and interpersonal relationship skills\nNegotiation and confrontation skills\nLearning Resources:\nRecommended text books:\nAgochiya, D. Aims of community research. Methods of community psychology research. Understanding individuals within environments and the community\nUnit- II: Preventing problem behavior and promoting social competence:  Understanding the key concepts of prevention and promotion. Ways to implement programs.\nUnit- III: Promoting community and social change: Citizen participation and empowerment. Program evaluation and program development.\nUnit- IV: Community based psychological first aid: Introduction. On being a helper in providing CBPFA. Traumatic stress.-emotional, physical, behavioral and cognitive reactions to stress. Stress of disasters. Coping with stress. CBPFA with marginalized and rural communities.\nUnit -V: Group service learning project on a community related issue: Skill training exercises for the students.\nRecap: Conducting quiz, class test, assigning students to do review sessions,\u201cQuestion hour\u201d\n\nLearning Resources \nRecommended Text Books\n1. Units\nUnit- I: Introduction :\nConceptual Framework / Theoretical Framework\nNeed of the study\n\nUnit- II: Review of Related Literature (Last ten years)\nIntroduction (Brief)\nStudies on variables, sample and related variables and samples\nCritical analysis of reviews collected\n\nUnit- III: Method of Investigation\nIntroduction\nStatement of the Problem\nObjectives\nHypotheses\nResearch Design (Methodology)\nSample (Sample, Sample Size, Sampling technique & Delimitation)\nVariables\nTools (Description of the Tools \u2013 Author(s), Year, Target Group, No of items, Scoring, Norms, Reliability & Validity)\nStatistical techniques\nUnit- IV: Results and Discussion\nIntroduction\nTables followed with discussion\n\nUnit- V: Summary and Conclusion\nSummary (one and half pages)\nFindings\nSuggestions & Recommendations\nImplications\nConclusion\n\n\n\nReference  (APA FORMAT)\n\n\nAppendices  (Tools used, item analysis if any, special diagrams, photographs if any)\n\n\n\n\nGROUP I\n\nCourse Name: GERIATRIC: CHALLENGES AND DEVELOPMENT\nCourse Code:\nYear and Semester:      rdyr ,th Semester\nCredits : 3\nOBJECTIVES"}

Units\nUnit- I: Physiological conditions of old age: Understanding the physiological conditions of old age in context to life style, socio economic conditions, gender -Old age from an old age perspective- Old age from society\u2019s perspective \u2013 Life expectancy in India and abroad \u2013 sensory problems \u2013 vision and eye diseases \u2013 cataracts \u2013 glaucoma \u2013 hearing loses \u2013 problems in movement and balance \u2013 Parkinson disease and dental problems \u2013 alcohol abuse \u2013 sexual activity.\nUnit- II: Health issues in old age: Heart diseases \u2013 BP \u2013 other cardiovascular problems \u2013 arthritis, diabetics, osteoporosis, cancer, kidney or bladder diseases, incontinence, indigestion, urinary tract infections, changes in the nervous system, immune system .\nUnit- III: Mental illness in old age: Symptoms of mental illness in old age \u2013 stress \u2013 different forms of stressors in old age \u2013 depression \u2013 Alzheimer and dementia \u2013 confusion due to multiple medication \u2013 loneliness \u2013 panic disorder-fear of death \u2013 anxiety \u2013 reduced mental and cognitive functioning \u2013 suicidal tendency \u2013 insomnia \u2013 substance abuse \u2013 falls .\nUnit- IV: Care and welfare needs of old age: Physical needs \u2013 health care needs \u2013 social needs \u2013 psychological needs \u2013 financial needs \u2013 retirement \u2013 singleness \u2013 adjustment problems of the aged \u2013 violence, neglect, abuse, crime, empty nest syndrome \u2013 governmental and nongovernmental welfare measures for the aged.\nUnit- V: Elderly care and management: Knowledge and skills required for old age care planning- assessments \u2013 financial support- legal and medical issues \u2013 referrals, advocacy and counseling \u2013"}

{"file": "M.Sc. Applied Psychology.docx", "source": "docx", "chunk": 24, "text": " addiction counseling, assessment and Interview        techniques for making diagnosis\nCO3(K3): Able to Psycho educate family members to deal with addiction\nCO4(K4): Devise individualized treatment plan for addiction patients with respected to their bio-psychosocial environment\nCO5(K3): Apply various therapeutic techniques in addiction counseling.\nLesson - Units\nUnit\u2013 1: Introduction to Addiction Counseling & Therapy: Counseling relationship, establishing a genuine helping relationship, Disease model vs Moral model of Addiction, Contemporary Psychoanalytic models of addiction, Kohut\u2019s self-psychology approach to addiction, defense mechanisms and addiction theory, advantage and disadvantages of psychoanalytic theory and contemporary analytic theories.\nUnit\u2013 2: Types of Drugs and Their Effect: Drug categories, sedatives \u2013hypnotics, stimulants, opians, narcotics, hallucinogens, and psychotropic medications. Effects of drugs on the brain, factors affecting the response to drugs, Federal Drug Administration Schedule of Drugs. Contemporary Forms of addiction: Internet, shopping, work, sex, gambling, food, gadget. Social media addiction. Addiction cycle: Emotional Trigger, Craving, Ritual, Using,Guilt.\nUnit\u2013 3: Drug and Alcohol Assessments, Diagnosis and Interview Techniques: The counselor as a Facilitative Gatekeeper, Components of a Comprehensive Assessment Alcohol and Drug Assessment Instruments, Psychological Information, Medical Information. Psychological applications to addiction counseling, Assessments, techniques and Interviews, Clinical applications for counselors.\nUnit\u2013 4: Families and Addiction: Bepko and Krestan Stage Theory, Family Life Cycle,Family Roles in Addicted Families, Al-Anon, Nar-Anon, Al-a-Teen, Families Anonymous, and ACOA Support Meetings, Intervention Strategies for Both Family and Addicted Member.\nUnit\u2013 5: Developmental theories of Recovery, Relapse and Prevention Techniques: Developmental theory, advantages and limitations, relapse prevention, Gorski\u2019s Relapse model, Marlatt\u2019s Relapse model, application to addiction counseling, strengths and limitations. Biomedical model, Aversion therapy. Cognitive Therapy, Motivational Approaches to Addiction Treatment, Mindfulness based Therapies and Group Theory, Structure and Process.\nLearning Resources:\nRecommended Text books:\nCavaiola,A.A .,&Smith,M.(2020).A comprehensive guide to addiction theory and counseling techniques.Routledge.\nBrook,F.,&McHenry,B.(2015).A Contemporary Approach to Substance Use Disorders and"}

{"file": "M.Sc. Applied Psychology.docx", "source": "docx", "chunk": 28, "text": "): Describe the clinical picture of childhood disorders.\nCO2(K2): Explain the causal factors and prevalence of childhood disorders.\nCO3(K3): Compare the diagnostic criteria of different childhood disorders.\nCO4(K4): Identify the different types of psychological assessment of various childhood disorders.\nCO5(K5): Apply various behavioural management and remedial education strategies for the different developmental disorders through hypothetical case discussions.\nLesson - Units\nUnit- I: Intellectual Disability - Definition, classification, prevalence,  etiology,  early identification, interpersonal deficits, behavior problems and management. Common intellectual disability syndromes - hypothyroidism, Fragile X syndrome, Down\u2019s, William\u2019s, PKU.\nUnit- II:Language and learning disabilities-  Definition, prevalence, etiology \u2013 social and\nmotivational factors. Assessment- tests of intelligence and cognitive abilities - underlying psychological and cognitive deficits. Treatment approaches-  individualized educational program, remedial teaching.\nUnit-  III: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder- Diagnostic criteria \u2013 co morbid factors - academic, social &amp; conduct problems. Etiology - biological, family and social influences.Assessment -interviews, behavior rating scales. Treatment \u2013 medication, behavior\nmodification, self-regulation and cognitive behavioral intervention.\nUnit- IV: Anxiety and other Disorders - Generalized anxiety, separation anxiety, social phobias, school phobia, specific phobias, Obsessive Compulsive Disorder. Schizophrenia in\nchildren and adolescents. Childhood depression. Conduct disorder. habit disorders-treatment\nUnit- V:Autism spectrum disorders- Prevalence, psychological and behavioral functioning, etiology,  assessment, comprehensive educational treatment and behavioral intervention. Presentation of case formulation and recommend suitable intervention strategies in hypothetical cases.\nRecap: Conducting quiz, class test, assigning students to do review sessions, \u201cQuestion hour\u201d\nLearning Resources:\nRecommended Text books:\nWicks \u2013 Nelson, R., &amp; Israel, A. {"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 1, "chunk": 0, "text": "SAGE Open Medicine\nCreative Commons Non Commercial CC BY-NC: This article is distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons  \nAttribution-NonCommercial 4.0 License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/) which permits non-commercial use, \nreproduction and distribution of the work without further permission provided the original work is attributed as specified on the SAGE and Open \nAccess pages (https://us.sagepub.com/en-us/nam/open-access-at-sage).\nhttps://doi.org/10.1177/20503121211034366\nSAGE Open Medicine\nVolume 9: 1 \u201310\n\u00a9 The Author(s) 2021\nArticle reuse guidelines: \nsagepub.com/journals-permissions\nDOI: 10.1177/20503121211034366\njournals.sagepub.com/home/smo\nIntroduction\nCancer is a global health problem responsible for one in six \ndeaths worldwide. In 2020, there were an estimated 19.3 \nmillion new cancer cases and about 10 million cancer deaths \nglobally. Cancer is a very complicated sequence of disease \nconditions progressing gradually with a generalized loss of \ngrowth control.1\u20133 There were only a few options of cancer \ntreatment for patients for many decades which include sur -\ngery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy as single treat-\nments or in combination.4,5 But recently, many pathways \ninvolved in cancer therapy progression and how they can be \ntargeted has improved dramatically, with combinatorial \nstrategies, involving multiple targeted therapies or \u201ctradi-\ntional\u201d chemotherapeutics, such as the taxanes and platinum \ncompounds, being found to have a synergistic e\ufb00ect.6 New \napproaches, such as drugs, biological molecules, and \nimmune-mediated therapies, are being used for treatment \neven if the excepted therapy level has not reached that \nresists the mortality rate and decreases the prolonged sur -\nvival time for metastatic cancer.\nThe creation of a new revolution in neoplastic cancer or \ntargeting drugs depends on the pathways and characteristics \nof different tumor entities.7 Chemotherapy is considered the \nmost effective and widely used modality in treating cancers \nNew approaches and procedures for  \ncancer treatment: Current perspectives\nDejene Tolossa Debela1 , Seke GY Muzazu1,2,"}
====================
{"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 1, "chunk": 1, "text": "  \nKidist Digamo Heraro1,3, Maureen Tayamika Ndalama1, \n Betelhiem Woldemedhin Mesele1,4, Dagimawi Chilot Haile1,5, \nSophia Khalayi Kitui1 and Tsegahun Manyazewal1  \nAbstract\nCancer is a global health problem responsible for one in six deaths worldwide. Treating cancer has been a highly complex \nprocess. Conventional treatment approaches, such as surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy, have been in use, while \nsignificant advances are being made in recent times, including stem cell therapy, targeted therapy, ablation therapy, \nnanoparticles, natural antioxidants, radionics, chemodynamic therapy, sonodynamic therapy, and ferroptosis-based therapy. \nCurrent methods in oncology focus on the development of safe and efficient cancer nanomedicines. Stem cell therapy has \nbrought promising efficacy in regenerating and repairing diseased or damaged tissues by targeting both primary and metastatic \ncancer foci, and nanoparticles brought new diagnostic and therapeutic options. Targeted therapy possessed breakthrough \npotential inhibiting the growth and spread of specific cancer cells, causing less damage to healthy cells. Ablation therapy \nhas emerged as a minimally invasive procedure that burns or freezes cancers without the need for open surgery. Natural \nantioxidants demonstrated potential tracking down free radicals and neutralizing their harmful effects thereby treating or \npreventing cancer. Several new technologies are currently under research in clinical trials, and some of them have already \nbeen approved. This review presented an update on recent advances and breakthroughs in cancer therapies.\nKeywords\nCancer, treatment, stem cell, targeted drugs, ablation, natural antioxidants, gene therapy\nDate received: 4 March 2021; accepted: 5 July 2021\n1  Center for Innovative Drug Development and Therapeutic Trials for \nAfrica (CDT-Africa), College of Health Sciences, Addis Ababa University, \nAddis Ababa, Ethiopia\n2  Enteric Diseases and Vaccines Research Unit, Centre for Infectious \nDisease Research in Zambia (CIDRZ), Lusaka, Zambia\n3  Wachemo University, Hossana, Ethiopia\n4  Kotebe Metropolitan University, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia\n5  University of Gondar, Gondar, Ethiopia\nCorresponding author:\nDejene"}

Box 9086, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. \nEmail: dejene.tolossa@aau.edu.et\n1034366 SMO0010.1177/20503121211034366SAGE Open MedicineDebela et al.\nresearch-article2021\nReview\n"}

{"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 2, "chunk": 0, "text": "2 SAGE Open Medicine\nas used alone or in combination with radiotherapy. \nGenotoxicity is how chemotherapy drugs target the tumor \ncells mainly producing reactive oxygen species that largely \ndestroy tumor cells.8 Hormonal treatments are also widely \nused for cancer malignancies and considered as cytostatic \nbecause it restricts tumor development by limiting the hor-\nmonal growth factors acting through the direction of hypo-\nthalamic\u2013pituitary\u2013gonadal axis (HPGA), hormone receptor \nblockage, and limiting of adrenal steroid synthesis.9\nIn this narrative review, a general overview of the most \nadvanced and novel cancer therapies was provided. In addi-\ntion, also new strategies currently under investigation at the \nresearch stage that should overwhelm the drawbacks of \nstandard therapies; different strategies to cancer diagnosis \nand therapy; and their current status in the clinical context, \nunderlining their impact as innovative anti-cancer approaches.\nCancer treatment modalities\nWe can see cancer treatment modalities by dividing them into \nconventional (traditional) and advanced or novel or modern \ncategories. In this era worldwide, over half of all ongoing \nmedical treatment trials are focusing on cancer treatments.7 \nEntities, such as the type of cancer, its site, and severity, guide \nto select treatment options and its progress. The most widely \nused traditional treatment methods are surgery, chemotherapy, \nand radiotherapy, while modern modalities include hormone \ntherapy, anti-angiogenic, stem cell therapies, immunotherapy, \nand dendritic cell-based immunotherapy.10\nConventional cancer therapies\nThe most recommended conventional cancer treatment strat-\negies include surgical resection of the tumors followed by \nradiotherapy with x-rays and/or chemotherapy.11 Of these \nmodalities, surgery is most effective at an early stage of dis-\nease progression. Radiation therapy can damage healthy \ncells, organs, and tissues. Although chemotherapy has \nreduced morbidity and mortality, virtually all chemothera-\npeutic agents damage healthy cells, especially rapidly divid-\ning and growing cells.12 Drug resistance, a major problem \nwith chemotherapy, is a phenomenon wherein cancer cells \nthat initially were suppressed by an anti-cancer drug develop \nresistance to the drug. This is caused primarily by reduced \ndrug uptake and increased drug efflux.13 Limitations of con-\nventional chemotherapeutic modality, such as dosage selec-\ntion difficulty, lack of specificity, rapid drug metabolism"}
====================
{"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 2, "chunk": 1, "text": ", \nand mainly harmful side effects.14\nAdvanced and innovative cancer \ntherapies\nAmong the obstacles of cancer, drug resistance and its deliv-\nery systems are the most problem in cancer cure and decreas-\ning signs and symptoms; but currently, there are many \napproved treatment approaches and drugs. The efficiency of \nconventional cancer is reduced due to tumor pathology and \narchitectural abnormality of tumor tissue blood vessels.15 \nThe following are the advanced and innovative cancer ther -\napy types with their benefits and challenges.\nStem cells therapy\nStem cells are undifferentiated cells present in the bone mar-\nrow (BM) with an ability to differentiate into any type of \nbody cell. Stem cell therapeutic strategy is also one of the \ntreatment options for cancer which are considered to be safe \nand effective. Application of stem cell is yet in the experi-\nmental clinical trial; for example, their use in the regenera-\ntion of other damaged tissue is being explored. Mesenchymal \nstem cells (MSCs) are currently being used in trials that are \ndelivered from the BM, fat tissues, and connective tissues.16\nPluripotent stem cells\nEmbryonic stem cells (ESCs) isolated from the uniform \ninner mass cells of the embryo possess the flexibility to \nadminister rise to any or all kinds of cells except those within \nthe placenta. In 2006, the invention of Yamanaka factors to \ninduce pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) from physical cells in \na culture marked a breakthrough in cell biology.17 Avoiding \nethical issues from embryo destruction, iPSCs and ESCs \nhave the same characteristics. Hematopoietic embryonic \nstem cells (hESCs) and iPSCs are currently used for the \ninduction of effector T cells and natural killer (NK) cells,18 \nand anti-tumor vaccine preparation.19\nAdult stem cells\nAdult stem cells (ASCs) groups often used in tumor therapy \ninclude hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs), MSCs, and neural \nstem cells (NSCs). HSCs, located in BM, can form all mature \nblood cells in the body. Currently, only approved by the Food \nand Drug Administration (FDA) is the infusion of HSCs \nderived from cord blood to treat multiple myeloma and leu"}

{"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 2, "chunk": 2, "text": "-\nkemia.20 MSCs are found in many tissues and organs, play-\ning important roles in tissue repair and regeneration into \ncells, such as osteocytes, adipocytes, and chondrocytes. \nMSCs have special biological characteristics and are used as \ncomplimentary with other approaches in treating tumors.21 \nNSCs can self-renew and generate new neurons and glial \ncells and are used for treating both primary and metastatic \nbreast and other tumors.22\nCancer stem cells\nCancer stem cells (CSCs) are generated in normal stem cells \nor precursor/progenitor cells by the epigenetic mutations \nprocess. Their role in tumor treatment includes cancer \ngrowth, metastasis, and recurrence, so that it could give \npromise in the treatment of solid tumors.23 Stem cells have \nseveral action mechanisms in treating the tumor. The homing "}

{"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 3, "chunk": 0, "text": "Debela et al. 3\nprocess is one mechanism which is a rapid migration of \nHSCs into defined stem cell niches in BM after that the \ntransplants undergo the engraftment process before giving \nrise to specialized blood cells. This mechanism is dependent \non the active interaction between stem cell CXCR4 receptors \nand requires their interaction with endothelial cells through \nLFA-1, VLA-4/5, CD44, and the secretion of matrix degra-\ndable enzyme MMP-2/9.22 The second mechanism is the \ntumor-tropic effect in which the migration of MSCs toward \ntumor microenvironment (TM) after attraction by CXCL16, \nSDF-1, CCL-25, and IL-6 secreted by tumor cells and dif-\nferentiation of MSCs within the tumor cells which contrib-\nutes to tumor stromal development.24 Stem cells also act by \nparacrine factor secretion, including extracellular vesicles \n(EVs) and soluble materials,25 and their differentiation \ncapacity, such as transplanted HSCs, can give rise to all \nblood cell types.26\nGenerally, cancer treatment using stem cell therapy by \nvarious strategies, including transplantation of HSC,27 MSC \ninfusion,28 therapeutic carriers, 29 generation of immune \neffector cells,30 and vaccine production.31 The stem cell can-\ncer therapy approach confronted the following side effects: \n(1) tumorigenesis, (2) adverse events in allogeneic HSC \ntransplantation, (3) drug toxicity and drug resistance, (4) \nincreased immune responses and autoimmunity, and (5) viral \ninfection.22 Despite several successes, there are challenges, \nsuch as therapeutic dose control, low cell targeting, and \nretention in tumor sites, that should be investigated and over-\ncome in the future. In addition, existing results from stem \ncell technologies are highly encouraging for tumor treatment \nbut it still needs further efforts to improve the safety and effi-\ncacy before they could enter clinical trials. Table 1 summa-\nrized the licensed list of stem cell therapies.\nTargeted drug therapy\nTargeted cancer therapies are drugs or other substances \nwhich are sometimes interchangeably used as \u201cmolecularly \ntargeted drugs,\u201d \u201cmolecularly targeted therapies,\u201d and \u201cpre-\n"}

{"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 3, "chunk": 1, "text": "cision medicines.\u201d Those drugs\u2019 mechanism of action is by \ninterfering with growth molecules which leads to blocking \nthe growth and spreading of cancer.34 Tumor initiation and \nprogression are determined by the TM of an atypical tumor \nwhich comprises endothelial cells, pericytes, smooth muscle \ncells, fibroblasts, various inflammatory cells, dendritic cells, \nand CSCs. There are various signaling mechanisms and \npathways that TM-forming cells dynamically interact with \nthe cancerous cells which are suitable for sustaining a rea-\nsonably high cellular proliferation. So, it is the area of \nresearch interest using TM conditions to mediate effective \ntargeting measures for cancer therapy.35\nSelectively treating cancer cells with conventional chem-\notherapy is difficult since it is similar to normal cells. So \nthose problems are intervened by cellular mechanisms, such \nas cell cycle arrest, apoptosis induction, proliferation pre-\nvention, and interfering with metabolic reprogramming by \ntargeted drug therapy agents.36 Modifying TM and targeting \nTM for drug delivery for effective treatment are two strate-\ngies that can be used for the treatment of cancer.37 Targeted \ntherapy drugs do work in different ways from standard \nchemotherapy drugs treatment like attacking cancer cells \nwhile doing less damage to normal cells which is a program-\nming that sets them apart from normal, healthy cells.38\nUsing targeted therapy markedly increased the survival \nrate for some diseases, for example, from 17% to 24% in \npatients with advanced pancreatic cancer, the addition of \nerlotinib to standard chemotherapy. Imatinib has had a dra-\nmatic effect on chronic myeloid leukemia, and rituximab, \nsunitinib, and trastuzumab have revolutionized the treatment \nof renal cell carcinoma and breast cancer, respectively.39\nWe can classify the targeted cell agents based on the \nmechanism of their work or their target site. Some enzymes \nserve as signals for cancer cells to grow. Some targeted ther-\napies inhibit enzymes that are signals for cancer cells to \ngrow. These drugs are called enzyme inhibitors. Blocking \nthese cell signals can inhibit cancer from getting bigger and \nspreading.40\nSome targeted therapies are called apoptosis-inducing \ndrugs because they are aimed right at the parts of the cell that \ncontrol whether cells live or die. The examples are serine/\nthreonine kinase, protein"}

{"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 3, "chunk": 2, "text": " kinase B (PKB/Akt), which pro-\nmotes cell survival, and inhibitors of this protein are in the \npreclinical phase.41\nThese agents stop the tumors from making new blood \nvessels which helps cut off the tumors\u2019 blood supply so that \ntumors cannot grow. In addition, they arrest tumor growth \nthat involves by curtailing blood supply to the tumor by \ninhibiting angiogenic factors, such as vascular endothelial \ngrowth factor (VEGF) or its receptors. {"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 4, "chunk": 0, "text": "4 SAGE Open Medicine\nextended by months after the use of Avastin (bevacizumab) \nin combination with 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.42\nTypes of target agents\nMonoclonal antibodies\nAntibody drugs are man-made versions of immune system \nproteins administered intravenously to attack certain tar -\ngets on cancer cells. They contain a more proportion of \nhuman components than murine components.43 Their attack \nmechanisms of action are recruiting host immune functions \nto attack the target cell, binding to ligands or receptors \nthereby interrupting essential cancer cell processes, and \ncarrying a lethal payload, such as radioisotope or toxin, to \nthe target cell.44 Gemtuzumab is an example of a CD-33-\nspecific monoclonal antibody currently used for AML \ntreatment by conjugating with calicheamicin.45 In addition, \nibritumomab tiuxetan is an anti-CD20, a 90Y metal iso-\ntope-based is developed in clinical therapy.46 Delivery of \nactive therapeutics, prodrug activation enzymes, and chem-\notherapy toxins are also another use of target agents of \nmonoclonal antibodies.47\nSmall molecule inhibitors\nThese are smaller protein in size (\u2a7d500 Da) than monoclonal \nantibodies, so that they can simply translocate through \nplasma membranes and can be taken orally. Their main func-\ntion is interrupting cellular processes by interfering with the \nintracellular signaling of tyrosine kinases which leads to the \ninhibition of tyrosine kinase signaling and initiates a molecu-\nlar cascade that can lead to the inhibition of cell growth, pro-\nliferation, migration, and angiogenesis in malignant tissues.48 \nExamples of small molecule inhibitors are gefitinib and erlo-\ntinib which inhibit epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) \nkinase and EGFR in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) \npatients, respectively. There are also lapatinib and sorafenib \nwhich act on the inhibition of EGFR/Erb-B2 Receptor \nTyrosine Kinase 2 (ERBB2) for ERBB2-positive breast can-\ncer and VEGFR kinase, in renal cancer.49\nAblation cancer therapy\nAblation is a treatment technique"}
====================
{"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 4, "chunk": 1, "text": " that destroys tumors with-\nout removing them mostly indicated for small-size tumors of \nless than 3 cm and the surgical option is contraindicated. \nAblation is also used with embolization for larger tumors. \nHowever, this technique might not be indicated for treating \ntumors near major blood vessels, the diaphragm, or major \nbile ducts due to destroying some of the normal tissue around \nthe tumor.50\nThermal ablation\nThis technique uses extreme hyperthermia or hypothermia to \ndestruct tumor tissue concentrating on a focal zone in and \naround the tumor. Similar to surgery, thermal ablation \nremoves the tumor and a 5\u201310 mm thick margin of seem-\ningly normal tissue but the tissue is killed in situ and then \nabsorbed by the body later. The procedure is similar to sur-\ngery using an open, laparoscopic, or endoscopic approach \nbut is commonly applied using a percutaneous or non-inva-\nsive approach. The type of tumor, site, physician\u2019s choice, \nand health status determine the approach.51\nRadiofrequency ablation (RFA), microwave ablation, \nhigh-intensity focused ultrasound, and cryoablation are cur -\nrently being used in the clinical setting. Cryoablation uses a \nhypothermic modality to induce tissue damage by a freeze-\nthaw process against others. All these treatments operate on \nthe principle of hyperthermia except cryoablation. Of all the \nablation techniques, cryoablation demonstrated the highest \npotential to elicit a post-ablative immunogenic response.52\nRecent studies showed additional to tissue disruption \nRFA and cryoablation can modulate the immune system that \nthey were applied as therapy on TM and in the systematic \ncirculation. Evidence has shown that ablation procedures \naffect carcinogenesis due to its local inflammatory response \nleading to an immunogenic gene signature.53\nThe advantage of this procedure over surgery is that it \nprovides a minimal (e.g. percutaneously or laparoscopically) \nor non-invasive approach to cancer therapy and gets atten-\ntion as an alternative to standard surgical therapies.54\nCryoablation\nCryoablation is one of the ablation techniques which ablates \nthe extensive tissue by freezing to lethal temperatures fol-\nlowed by liquid formation,"}
====================
{"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 4, "chunk": 2, "text": " causing extensive tissue. Benign \nand malignant primary tumors are mostly treated by this \ntherapy.55 James Arnott reported that the freezing tempera-\ntures can impair cancer cell viability after he attempted the \nusage of cold temperatures by salt and ice solutions for the \ngeneration of local numbness before surgical operations in \nthe nineteenth century. He suggested cryoablation as an \nattractive therapeutic option and increased a patient\u2019s \nsurvival.56\nCryoablation techniques are based on the principle of the \nJoule\u2013Thomson effect which was studied in the 1930s by \nmany researchers and concluded using liquid CO2 under \nhigh pressure, liquid air, and liquid oxygen to achieve the \ncooling effect and the subsequent formation of ice crystals so \nemployed to treat lesions, warts, and keratosis. However, \nafter 1950, Allington replaced liquid N2 for the treatment of \nvarious skin lesion disorders.47\nRFA therapy\nRFA is a minimally invasive procedure and an image-guided \ntechnique using hyperthermic (high-frequency electrical \ncurrents) conditions to destroy cancer cells. Imaging tech-\nniques, such as ultrasound, computed tomography (CT), or \nmagnetic resonance imaging (MRI), guide needle electrodes "}
====================
{"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 5, "chunk": 0, "text": "Debela et al. 5\ninto a tumor cell. Generally, RFA is the most effective \napproach for treating small-size tumors of less than 3 cm in \ndiameter. RFA can be used in combination with other con-\nventional cancer treatment options.57 After starting the use of \ndeployable devices or multiple-electrode systems, RFA can \ntreat medium tumors (up to 5 cm diameter).58\nGene therapy\nGene therapy is the insertion of a normal copy of a defective \ngene in the genome to cure a specific disorder. The first \napplication dates back to 1990 when a retroviral vector was \nexploited to deliver the adenosine deaminase (ADA) gene to \nT cells in patients with severe combined immunodeficiency \n(SCID). Approximately, about 2900 gene therapy clinical tri-\nals are currently ongoing, two-third of which are related to \ncancer. Strategies, such as expression of proapoptotic and \nchemosensitizing genes, expression of wild-type tumor sup-\npressor genes, expression of genes able to solicit specific \nanti-tumor immune responses, and targeted silencing of \noncogenes, are under evaluation for cancer gene therapy.47\nThymidine kinase (TK) gene delivery is effective for the \nadministration of prodrug ganciclovir to activate its expres-\nsion and induce specific cytotoxicity.59 The p53 tumor sup-\npressor gene which is vectors carrying has been assessed for \nthe clinical purpose very recently. ONYX-015 has been \ntested in NSCLC patients and gave a high response rate \nwhen given alone or combined with chemotherapy.60 \nGendicine, a recombinant adenovirus carrying wild-type \np53-induced complete disease regression in head and neck \nsquamous cell cancer had similar success when combined \nwith radiotherapy.61\nSome challenges that have been faced with gene therapy \nare the selection of the right conditions and the choice of the \nbest delivery mechanism. Identified drawbacks of this ther-\napy are genome integration, limited efficacy in specific sub-\nsets of patients, and high chances of being neutralized by the \nimmune system. Basic research and medical translation used \nRNA interference (RNAi) as an efficient technology that \nable to produce targeted gene silencing.62 RNA-induced \nsilencing complex (RISC) mediates the targeted gene silenc-\ning"}
====================
{"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 5, "chunk": 1, "text": " process by cleaving the messenger RNA (mRNA) and \ninterference with protein synthesis.63 A siRNAs can be \ndesigned to block desired targets, involving cell proliferation \nand metastatic invasion; hence, precise molecular mecha-\nnisms are a triggering factor for tumor formation. This \nmethod relies on siRNA-mediated gene silencing of anti-\napoptotic proteins, transcription factors (i.e. c-myc gene),64,65 \nor cancer mutated genes (i.e. K-RAS).66\nAdvantages of siRNA-based drugs are safety, high effi-\ncacy, specificity, few side effects, and low costs of produc-\ntion.67 However, occasionally, they can induce off-target \neffects or elicit innate immune responses, followed by spe-\ncific inflammation.68 Delivery methods currently under study \nare chemical modification (insertion of a phosphorothioate at \n3\u2019 end, introduction of a 2\u2019 O-methyl group, and modification \nby 2,4-dinitrophenol) and lipid encapsulation, or conjugation \nwith organic molecules (polymers, peptides, lipids, antibod-\nies, small molecules) efficiently target to spontaneously cross \ncell membranes of naked siRNAs.69 Interaction of cationic \nliposomes with negatively charged nucleic acids facilitates \neasy transfection by simple electrostatic interactions.70 They \ncan be constituted by 1,2-dioleoyl-3-trimethylammonium \npropane (DOTAP) and N-[1-(2,3-dioleoyloxy) propyl]-N, \nNtrimethylammonium methyl sulfate (DOTMA).71 Currently, \na Phase I clinical trial is recruiting patients for evaluating the \nsafety of Eph receptor A2 (EphA2) targeting 1,2-dioleoyl-sn-\nglycero-3-phosphocholine (DOPC) encapsulated siRNA \n(siRNA-EphA2- DOPC) in patients with advanced and recur-\nrent cancer.72 siRNAs can be concentrated in cationic poly-\nmers, such as chitosan, cyclodextrin, and polyethyleneimine \n(PEI).73 CALAA-01 is one of the cyclodextrin polymers con-\njugated with human transferrin is being entered a Phase I \n"}
====================
{"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 5, "chunk": 2, "text": "clinical trial. PEI has been used as an anti-cancer by forming \nsmall cationic nanoparticles and loading with human epider-\nmal growth factor receptor 2 (HER-2 receptor)-specific \nsiRNA.74 Phase II clinical trial has been started to evaluate \nLocal Drug EluteR (siG12D LODER) directed to mutated \nKirsten rat sarcoma (K-RAS) oncogene for the treatment of \nadvanced pancreatic cancer. Conjugating to peptides, anti-\nbodies, and aptamers improves stability during circulation \nand enhances cellular uptake of siRNAs.75 The introduction \nof nanocarriers has largely improved siRNAs stability, phar-\nmacokinetics and biodistribution properties, and targeting \nspecificity. Polyallylamine phosphate nanocarriers have been \ndeveloped to release siRNAs in the cytoplasm after disassem-\nbly at low endosomal pH.76\nDose correction and variabilities between individuals and \ndifferent stages of disease are challenging issues on clinical \ntranslation of the siRNA-based approach. In the future, the \nneeded research is on setting up the best-personalized ther-\napy and toward controlled release to reach only specific tar -\ngets on treating the tumor. Table 2 summarizes the gene \ntherapy drugs based on their mechanism of action and \ninduction.\nNatural antioxidants\nDay to day, the anatomy undergoes many exogenous insults, \nsuch as ultraviolet (UV) rays, pollution, and tobacco smoke, \nthat end in the assembly of reactive species, particularly oxi-\ndants and free radicals, liable for the onset of many diseases, \ntogether with cancer. These molecules can even be made as a \nconsequence of clinical administration of medication; how-\never, they are additionally naturally created within our cells \nand tissues by mitochondria and peroxisomes, and from \nmacrophages metabolism, throughout traditional physiologi-\ncal aerobic processes.47"}
====================
{"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 6, "chunk": 0, "text": "6 SAGE Open Medicine\nOxidative stress and radical oxygen species can signifi-\ncantly change the regulation of transcription factors by dam-\naging the DNA and other bio-macromolecule.77\nVitamins, polyphenols, and plant-derived bioactive com-\npounds are natural antioxidants used as preventive and thera-\npeutic drugs against these molecules that damage the body \ndue to their anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.78 \nStudies added to cancer therapy after appreciating their anti-\nproliferative and proapoptotic properties. Compounds, such \nas vitamins, alkaloids, flavonoids, carotenoids, curcumin, \nberberine, quercetin, and others, are examples of natural \nantioxidants screened in vitro and in vivo.79\nLimited bioavailability and/ or toxicity is one of the chal-\nlenges of natural drugs while their translation into clinical \npractice.47 Curcumin has cytotoxic effects in different kinds \nof tumors, such as the brain, lung, leukemia, pancreatic, and \nhepatocellular carcinoma,80 while sparing normal cells at \neffective therapeutic doses. The curcumin\u2019s biological prop-\nerties, treatment duration and efficient therapeutic doses are \nunder study.80 This day, about 27 clinical trials are done, \nwhile 40 are under study on curcumin.\nBerberine is an alkaloid compound that has been studied \nto be effective against different cancers as a chemopreven-\ntive agent, modulating many signaling pathways. Different \nnanotechnological strategies have been developed to facili-\ntate its delivery across cell membranes due to their poorly \nsoluble in water.81 Six clinical trials are under study and two \nhave been completed.\nQuercetin is another natural plant origin agent that is \neffective alone and also in combination with chemotherapeu-\ntic agents in treating many cancers, such as lung, prostate, \nliver, colon, and breast cancers.82 Quercetin\u2019s mechanism of \naction is by binding to cellular receptors and the interference \nof several signaling pathways.83 Currently, six clinical trials \nare under study and seven studies have been completed.\nCurrent clinical trials\nIn recent years, analysis of cancer medication has taken out-\nstanding steps toward more practical, precise, and fewer \ninvasive cancer treatments in the research of clinical trials \n(Figure 1).\nCurrently"}

{"file": "new-approaches-and-procedures-for-cancer-treatment.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 6, "chunk": 1, "text": ", the most frequent entries focusing on cancer \ntherapies in the database of clinical trials (www.clinicalTri-\nals.gov) include the terminologies stem cell, targeted ther-\napy, immunotherapy, and gene therapy because they are \nvery promising and effective. Table 3 summarizes the poten-\ntial advantages and disadvantages of the new treatment \napproaches.\nTable 4 summarizes the approaches to advanced cancer \ntherapies and their respective delivery systems with examples.\nConclusion\nCurrent methods in oncology focus on the development of \nsafe and efficient cancer nanomedicines. Targeted medical \ncare helped rising the biodistribution of recent or already \ntested chemotherapeutical agents around the specific tissue \nto be treated; different methods, such as sequence medical \ncare, siRNAs delivery, therapy, and inhibitor molecules, sup-\nply new potentialities to cancer patients. Gene therapy acts \nby direct in situ insertion of exogenous genes into benign \ntumors. Noticeably, stem cells can be used as regenerative \nmedicine, therapeutic carriers, drug targeting, and generation \nof immune cells because of having unique biological actions \non other cells.22 On the opposite hand, thermal ablation and \nmagnetic hyperthermia are promising alternatives to the \ngrowth surgical process. Finally, radionics and pathomics \napproaches facilitate the management of huge knowledge \nsets from cancer patients to enhance prognosis and out-\ncomes. Much progress has been made, but many others are \nlikely to come soon, producing more and more ad hoc \nTable 2. Summary of gene therapy approaches.\nS. no. {"file": "Ocean_ecogeochemistry_A_review.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 1, "chunk": 0, "text": "327\nOceanography and Marine Biology: An Annual Review, 2013, 51, 327-374\n\u00a9 Roger N. Hughes, David Hughes, and I. Philip Smith, Editors\nTaylor & Francis\nOcEaN EcOgEOcHEmISTRy: a REvIEw\nKElTON w. mcmaHON1,2,3, lI lINg HamaDy1 & SImON R. THORROlD1\n1Biology Department, Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, \nMS50, Woods Hole, MA 02543, USA\n E- mail: kmcmahon@whoi.edu (corresponding author), lhamady@whoi.edu\n2Red Sea Research Center, King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, \nThuwal, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia\n E- mail: sthorrold@whoi.edu\n3Ocean Sciences Department, University of California-Santa Cruz, Santa Cruz, CA 95064, USA\nanimal movements and the acquisition and allocation of resource s provide mechanisms for indi-\nvidual behavioural traits to propagate through population, co mmunity and ecosystem levels of \nbiological organization. Recent developments in analytical geo chemistry have provided ecolo-\ngists with new opportunities to examine movements and trophi c dynamics and their subsequent \ninluence on the structure and functioning of animal communit ies. we refer to this approach as \necogeochemistry\u2014the application of geochemical techniques to fundamental questi ons in popula-\ntion and community ecology. we used  meta- analyses of published data to construct \u03b42H, \u03b413c, \u03b415N, \n\u03b418O and \u039414c isoscapes throughout the world\u2019s oceans. These maps reveal substantial spatial vari-\nability in stable isotope values on regional and  ocean- basin scales. we summarize distributions of \ndissolved metals commonly assayed in the calciied tissues of mar ine animals. Finally, we review \nstable isotope analysis (SIa) of amino acids and fatty acids. T hese analyses overcome many of \nthe problems that prevent bulk SIa from providing suficient ge ographic or trophic resolution in \nmarine applications. we expect that ecologists will increasin gly use ecogeochemistry approaches \nto estimate animal movements and trace nutrient pathways in ocean food webs. These studies will, \nin turn, help provide the scient"}
====================
{"file": "Ocean_ecogeochemistry_A_review.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 1, "chunk": 1, "text": "iic underpinning for  ecosyst em- based management strategies in \nmarine environments.\nIntroduction\nThe acquisition and allocation of resources are fundamental req uirements for all animals and sig-\nniicantly inluence behaviour, population dynamics and ecosystem functioning. animal movement \nplays a critical role in resource acquisition and the transfer of these resources among locations. \nTrophic and movement ecology are therefore inextricably linke d across a range of spatiotemporal \nscales within and among food webs. This connection extends to the techniques used to study con-\nnections among habitats and trophic groups. Stable isotope a nalysis (SIa) and other geochemi-\ncal methods have been used extensively in food web studies and, m ore recently, to trace animal \nmovements across habitats with distinctive isotopic signatures (Hobson 1999, Boecklen et al. 2011). \nThis convergence represents a new direction for the ield of eco geochemistry, a term irst used by \nmizutani et al. (1991) to describe the use of SIa to infer diets of bats and subsequently expanded to \ninclude a range of geochemical approaches applied to ecological studies of food web dynamics and \nmovement (mcmahon et al. 2013)."}
====================
{"file": "Ocean_ecogeochemistry_A_review.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 2, "chunk": 0, "text": "KElTON w. mcmaHON, lI lINg HamaDy & SImON R. THORROlD\n328\nEcologists have embraced the use of SIa in studies of marine food webs. a recent review found \nthat nearly 60% of trophic ecology studies using SIas published between 2007 and 2009 were con-\nducted in marine or estuarine environments (Boecklen et al. 2 011). However, while stable isotopes \nhave been used in animal migration studies in terrestrial environments for several decades (Hobson \n1999, Rubenstein & Hobson 2004), the approach has received fa r less attention in marine systems \n(Fry 1981, Schell et al. 1989, Best & Schell 1996). This lack of effort may be due, at least in part, to \na failure to recognize the degree of geographic variation in is otope and element abundances across \nmarine environments (Hobson 1999, Rubenstein & Hobson 2004) . compilations of maps showing \nspatial variation in isotope values have identiied marine isoscapes that are clearly suficient for use \nin movement studies over  ocean- basin scales (west et al. 2010, mcmahon et al. 2013).\nThe use of ecogeochemical approaches to examine trophic dynamics and movement patterns \nof animals offers signiicant advantages over traditional method s in marine environments. For \ninstance, the use of stable isotopes has overcome at least some of the problems associated with \nstomach content analysis to determine diets (michener & Schell 1994). Ecogeochemistry has also \nbeen employed to overcome problems associated with conventio nal tagging methods of the early \n life- history stages of marine animals (Thorrold et al. 2002 , Becker et al. 2007). Finally, in some \ninstances isotope analyses of ancient calciied tissues have provided a means of investigating eco-\nlogical processes over millennial timescales (limburg et al. 2011). Taken together, ecogeochemistry \nmay allow for signiicant progress in a number of important, bu t as yet unresolved, questions in \nocean ecology.\nIn this review, we outline the processes controlling isotope and elemental fractionation and"}
====================
{"file": "Ocean_ecogeochemistry_A_review.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 2, "chunk": 1, "text": " \nsummarize geographic gradients in isotope and elemental distributions in ocean and estuarine envi-\nronments. we assemble global ocean isoscapes for key elements in marine ecogeochemistry, includ-\ning seawater hydrogen (\u03b42HSw), dissolved inorganic carbon (DIc) ( \u03b413cDIc), seawater radiocarbon \n(\u039414cSw), plankton carbon ( \u03b413cPlK), plankton nitrogen ( \u03b415NPlK) and seawater oxygen ( \u03b418OSw). \nwe summarize distributions of those minor and trace elements that are consistently and accurately \nanalysed in the calciied tissues of marine ish and invertebrates and used as natural geochemical \ntags of natal origin (Thorrold et al. 1997). Finally, we highlight the potential for  compound- speciic \nstable isotope analyses, acknowledging that more research is needed in terms of understanding the \nprocesses controlling stable isotope fractionation of individual amino acids and fatty acids.\nData sources and isoscape methods\nIn this review, we have assembled isoscapes for a number of key elements in the marine environ-\nment. The data used to generate the isoscapes were collected from  met a- analyses of published \nisotope data. For \u03b42HSw and \u03b418OSw, all data were available on the global Oxygen-18 Database \n(Schmidt et al. 1999) on the National aeronautics and Space admin istration website (http://data.\ngiss.nasa.gov/ o18data/). Similarly, seawater radiocarbon (\u039414cSw) data were mined from the global \nData analysis Project (glODaP) (Key et al. 2004). Seawater DIc \u03b413cDIc data were collected \nfrom glODaP (Key et al. 2004), the Open access library Pangaea (http://www.pangaea.de), and \nextensive searches of google Scholar and web of Science. Date f or both \u039414cSw and \u03b413cDIc were \npredominantly more recent than the 1990s. The \u03b413cDIc data in the horizontal isoscape were from \nthe top 100 m of the world\u2019s oceans. Horizontal isoscapes of plan kton \u03b413cPlK and \u03b415NPlK values \n"}
====================
{"file": "Ocean_ecogeochemistry_A_review.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 2, "chunk": 2, "text": "were mined from extensive searches of google Scholar, web of S cience, and several online data \nrepositories, including Pangaea. we limited the plankton iso scape search to samples described as \nnet plankton (<1 mm) collected in the euphotic zone (<150 m depth) and not preserved in formalin. \nThe plankton isoscapes comprise a range of species but consist predominantly of copepods and \nsimilar zooplankton. To achieve the best spatial coverage, no attempts were made to sort data tem-\nporally. However, most data presented are more recent than the 1990s. {"file": "Ocean_ecogeochemistry_A_review.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 3, "chunk": 2, "text": "1); Stowasser et al. (2012); and wyatt (2011).\nIsoscapes were generated using Ocean Data view (ODv) version 4.5.0 (Brown 1998, Schlitzer \n2002, http://odv.awi.de/). Data are displayed as  colour- shaded maps based on contouring of the orig-\ninal data using the Data Interpolating variational analysis (DIva) gr idding software. DIva soft-\nware was designed to interpolate data spatially (Barth et al. 2010). DIva gridding takes into account \ncoastlines, subbasins and advection. calculations are highly optim ized and rely on a  inite- element \nresolution. In particular, the  inite- element method takes into account the distance between analysis \nand data (observation constraint), the regularity of the analysis (smoothness constraint) and physical \nlaws (behaviour constraint). Information about the DIva grid ding software used by ODv can be \nfound at http://modb.oce.ulg.ac.be/ mediawiki/ index.php/ DIva. Details of the algorithms employed \nby DIva gridding can be found at http://modb.oce.ulg.ac.be/ mediawiki/ index.php/ DIva_method.\nSystematics\nTo be successfully applied in the ield, an ecogeochemistry approach must do each of the following \n(Hobson et al. 2010): (1) establish a baseline isoscape that characterizes distinct geochemical signa-\ntures in different habitats or food web end members; (2) constrain tissue isotope turnover rates that \ndetermine the period of integration of geochemical signatures for a particular tissue; and (3) identify \nisotope or elemental fractionation factors between consumer an d diet, or between animals and the \nambient environment, that offset animal geochemical signatures f rom the baseline isotope val-\nues. The isotopic composition of elements in the marine environ ment is inluenced by a variety of \nphysical, chemical and biological processes that together produce unique geographic distributions, \ntermed isoscapes (west et al. 2010). Next, we provide a brief overview of the dominant sources of \nfractionation for elements commonly used in ecogeochemistry stu dies and discuss the resulting \ngeographic distributions in the marine and estuarine enviro n"}
====================
{"file": "Ocean_ecogeochemistry_A_review.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 3, "chunk": 3, "text": "ments. common reference standards \nfor the elements discussed can be found in Table\u00a01."}

{"file": "Ocean_ecogeochemistry_A_review.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 4, "chunk": 0, "text": "KElTON w. mcmaHON, lI lINg HamaDy & SImON R. THORROlD\n330\nHydrogen isotopes\nHydrogen isotope fractionation\nHydrogen has the largest mass difference between isotopes re lative to mass and hence the great-\nest variability of \u03b4 values of any element on Earth.  Physical- chemical processes governing hydro-\ngen isotope fractionation in the marine environment include eva poration, precipitation, mixing \nand exchange reactions (Friedman 1953). Evaporation from a number of sources, including clouds, \nwater bodies, soil and plant and animal respiration, forms an i mportant basis for fractionation of \nhydrogen isotopes in the hydrologic cycle. Fractionation of hydrogen isotopes during evaporation is \nlargely a kinetic process that depends on a number of factors and can, in turn, be quite large. vapour \npressures of the isotopologues of water decrease with decreas ing molecular weight; therefore, the \nheavy isotope (2H) will favour that part of the system in which it is more strongl y bound, that is, \nthe liquid phase (gat 1996). The same is true for condensation; ther efore, during evaporation and \ncondensation in an open system, the liquid phase of water becomes progressively enriched in 2H, \nwhile the vapour phase becomes progressively depleted. This p rocess is known as Rayleigh distil-\nlation (gat 1996). Rayleigh distillation has important implications for latitudinal gradients in ocean \n\u03b42H values of seawater ( \u03b42HSw) as described in the next section. Hydrogen isotope fractionat ion \nfactors for phase transitions of water are so large that even in  high- temperature systems like hydro-\nthermal vents, signiicant variation in \u03b42HSw can be seen (Horita & wesolowski 1994). Further \nfractionation of hydrogen isotopes can take place at hydrotherma l vents and  deep- water cold seeps \nduring oxidation of H2 and cH4 to H2O and cO2. The pressure (depth) at which these reactions take \nplace can also have an impact on hydrogen isotope fractionation (Horita 1999).\nHydrogen isotopes can also be fractionated"}
====================
{"file": "Ocean_ecogeochemistry_A_review.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 4, "chunk": 1, "text": " by biological processes, including bacterially medi-\nated production of hydrogen gas and methane, both of which tend to be depleted in 2H (Krichevsky \net al. 1961). Hydrogen isotope fractionation during photosynthesis typically results in organic mat-\nter that is relatively depleted in 2H; however, the individual steps involved in fractionation are still \nunclear (white 1989). It is important to note that at low temperatures water hydrogen will exchange \nquickly and reversibly with labile organic hydrogen bound in organic nitrogen, sulphur and oxygen \ncompounds (werstiuk & Ju 1989). water at neutral pH and low temp erature in the absence of a \ncatalyst, however, does not readily exchange with most  carbon- bound hydrogen (Sternberg 1988), \nparticularly hydrocarbons and lipids. Therefore, it is impor tant to choose appropriate tissues that \nTable\u00a01 common isotope ratios, their percentage abundances, reference standa rds, substance \ntypes, and \u03b4 values\nIsotope \nratio\nabundance \n(%) Standard Type value\n2H/1H 0.01/99.98 SmOw (Standard mean Ocean water) water \u03b4D (SmOw) = 0.00\u2030\n2H/1H 0.01/99.98 SlaP (Standard light antarctic Precipitation) water \u03b4D (SmOw) = \u2013428.00\u2030\n13c/12c 1.10/98.90 PDB (PeeDee Belemnite) calcite \u03b413c (PDB) = 0.00\u2030\n13c/12c 1.10/98.90 NBS-19 (National Bureau of Standards-19) calcite \u03b413c (PDB) =1.95\u2030\n14c/12c <0.01/98.90 NBS HOx1 (National Bureau of Standards \nOxalic acid I)\nOxalic acid\n15N/14N 0.36/99.64 atmospheric aIR air \u03b415N (aIR) = 0.00\u2030\n18O/16O 0.20/99.76 SmOw (Standard mean Ocean water) water \u03b418O (SmOw) = 0.00\u2030\n18O/"}
====================
{"file": "Ocean_ecogeochemistry_A_review.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 4, "chunk": 2, "text": "16O 0.20/99.76 SlaP (Standard light antarctic Precipitation) water \u03b418O (SmOw) = \u201355.50\u2030\n18O/16O 0.20/99.76 PDB (PeeDee Belemnite) calcite \u03b418O (SmOw) = 0.27\u2030\n18O/16O 0.20/99.76 NBS-19 (National Bureau of Standards-19) calcite \u03b418O (SmOw) = 28.64\u2030\n34S/32S 4.21/95.02 cDT (canyon Diablo Troilite) Iron sulphide \u03b418O (SmOw) = 0.00\u2030\nNote: For a complete set of standards, see coplen et al. (2002)."}
====================
{"file": "Ocean_ecogeochemistry_A_review.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 5, "chunk": 0, "text": "OcEaN EcOgEOcHEmISTRy: a REvIEw\n331\ncontain  non- exchangeable hydrogen or correct for exchange with suitable standards when attempt-\ning to examine animal migration with stable hydrogen isotopes (Kelly et al. 2009).\nHydrogen isotope geographic variability\nSurface \u03b42HSw values range from approximately \u201360\u2030 in the arctic Ocean to ap proximately 12\u2030 \nin parts of the mediterranean Sea (Figure\u00a01). Rayleigh distillation is a fundamental process control-\nling latitudinal gradients in \u03b42HSw. as water vapour travels polewards and cools, some of the vapour \ncondenses out as enriched precipitation, leaving the remainin g vapour further depleted relative to \nits source. The water vapour becomes more depleted as the fraction of vapour remaining becomes \nsmaller, until it is inally deposited as highly 2 H- depleted snow at the poles. This depletion can be \nmodelled as follows:\n 2H/1Hv = 2H/1Hvo f (\u03b1\u20131),\nwhere f is the fraction of vapour remaining, \u03b1 is the equilibrium fractionation factor for the \n water- vapour phase transition, and 2H/1Hv and 2H/1Hvo are the hydrogen isotope ratios of the cur-\nrent and initial water vapour fractions, respectively. This process results in a gradient of \u03b42HSw \nvalues that are more negative with increasing latitude. \u03b42HSw values that are more negative also \noccur in regions of river  run- off from large drainage basins. Riverine and groundwater sources typi-\ncally have \u03b42H values that relect the average isotope composition of precipitation that fell relatively \nrecently into watersheds or recharge sites for that area (Kenda ll & coplen 2001). These freshwater \nsources introduce unique \u03b42H signatures into coastal areas that are consistently lower th an \u03b42HSw \nvalues. The mouths of large rivers like the amazon can introduce anomalously low \u03b42H values that \npenetrate hundreds of kilometres into the atlantic Ocean. Simi larly, deuterium can be a valuable \ntracer of subsurface groundwater sources (Sonntag et al. 1983), resulting in unique nearshore \u03b42HSw \nsignatures that could be used to track animal"}
====================

In the Paciic Ocean, the \ncalifornia current exhibits \u03b42HSw values that are more negative than would be predicted based on \nlatitude due to advection of 2 H- depleted subpolar water towards the equator along the eastern Paciic \nOcean. conversely, the  north- eastern North atlantic exhibits enriched \u03b42HSw values for its latitude \ndue to polewards advection of 2 H- enriched  low- latitude water via the gulf Stream.\nCarbon isotopes\nCarbon-13 (13C)\n13C fractionation carbon isotopes are fractionated during several reactions as they move through \nthe environment and into food webs. The irst of these fractionation processes is caused by equili-\nbration of cO2 between the atmosphere and the surface ocean DIc pool (Boutton 1 991). The dis-\nsolution of cO2 in seawater occurs through the following reactions:\n CO CO H O H CO H HCO H CO2(atm) 2(aq) 2 2 2\u21cc \u21cc \u21cc \u21cc+ + + + \u2212 +\n3 3 2 2 2\u2212\nalthough the equilibration of cO 2 alone is relatively fast (approximately 1 year), exchange \nbetween atmospheric cO 2 and DIc that includes all the inorganic carbon species is a slow er pro-\ncess, on the order of about 10 years (Broecker & Peng 1974). at a t ypical surface seawater pH of \n8.2, seawater DIc has 91% bicarbonate ion, 8% carbonate ion, and 1% dissolved cO2. There is also \nsigniicant  temperature- dependent fractionation of carbon iso topes among the various dissolved \ncarbon species (Zeebe &  wolf- gladrow 2001). The \u03b413c value of cO 2(atm) is approximately \u20138\u2030 \n(Keeling et al. 2005). at 25\u00b0c, carbon isotope fractionation be tween cO2(atm) and cO2(aq) is 1.3"}

{"file": "Ocean_ecogeochemistry_A_review.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 6, "chunk": 1, "text": "\u2030, \nand fractionation between cO 2(aq) and bicarbonate ions is \u20139\u2030 (mook 1986, Zhang et al. 1995). \nFinally, fractionation between bicarbonate and carbonate ions was reported by mook (1986) to be \n0.4\u2030, although the value is not particularly well constrained (Zeebe &  wolf- gladrow 2001).\nPhotosynthetic marine organisms take up the lighter carbon iso tope ( 12c) at a faster rate, \nwith a \u03b413c fractionation value of approximately \u201319\u2030 between \u03b413cDIc and ixed organic carbon \n( lynch- Stieglitz et al. 1995). Internal biological paramete rs of primary producers, such as bio-\nsynthesis rate, enzymatic activity and cell lipid content, can s igniicantly inluence their \u03b413cPlK \nvalues (Fry & wainright 1991, Hinga et al. 1994). The most prom inent example of this differen-\ntial fractionation during photosynthesis can be seen in the \u03b413c values of c3 and c4 plants. Plants \nusing the c4 photosynthetic pathway typically have \u03b413c values that are more positive, ranging from \n\u20138\u2030 to \u201312\u2030, than c3 plants (-22\u2030 to \u201328\u2030) (see review by Farquhar et al. 1989). This difference \nis due to c4 plants using a different primary carboxylating enzyme, phosphenolpyruvate (PEP) car-\nboxylase, and a different species of inorganic carbon than c 3 plants that use  ribulose- bisphosphate \n carboxylase- oxygenase (Rubisco). During photosynthesis, phytoplankton take up DIc, and after \nmoderate kinetic fractionation, phytoplankton obtains a \u03b413c value between \u201316\u2030 and \u201324\u2030 \n(Peterson & Fry 1987).\n13C geographic variability Temperature is a key physical parameter that inluences \u03b413c variabil-\nity of cO2 globally. Introduction of 13 c- depleted atmospheric cO2 \nin regions of the ocean with prominent cO2 invasion, such as the North atlantic, results in relatively \nlow surface water \u03b413cDIc  values. conversely, outgassing of cO2 in equatorial upwelling zones gives \nsurface waters more positive \u03b413c values ( lynch- Stieglitz et al. 1995).
