{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 73, "chunk": 0, "text": "\u201cWe\u2019ve wasted almost the entire day,\u201d said the Englishman, sitting\ndown with the boy near one of the wells.\n\u201cMaybe we\u2019d better ask someone,\u201d the boy suggested.\nThe Englishman didn\u2019t want to tell others about his reasons for\nbeing at the oasis, and couldn\u2019t make up his mind. But, finally, he\nagreed that the boy, who spoke better Arabic than he, should do so.\nThe boy approached a woman who had come to the well to fill a\ngoatskin with water.\n\u201cGood afternoon, ma\u2019am. I\u2019m trying to find out where the alchemist\nlives here at the oasis.\u201d\nThe woman said she had never heard of such a person, and\nhurried away. But before she fled, she advised the boy that he had\nbetter not try to converse with women who were dressed in black,\nbecause they were married women. He should respect tradition.\nThe Englishman was disappointed. It seemed he had made the\nlong journey for nothing. The boy was also saddened; his friend was\nin pursuit of his Personal Legend. And, when someone was in such\npursuit, the entire universe made an effort to help him succeed\u2014\nthat\u2019s what the old king had said. He couldn\u2019t have been wrong.\n\u201cI had never heard of alchemists before,\u201d the boy said. \u201cMaybe no\none here has, either.\u201d\nThe Englishman\u2019s eyes lit up. \u201cThat\u2019s it! Maybe no one here knows\nwhat an alchemist is! Find out who it is who cures the people\u2019s\nillnesses!\u201d\nSeveral women dressed in black came to the well for water, but\nthe boy would speak to none of them, despite the Englishman\u2019s\ninsistence. Then a man approached.\n\u201cDo you know someone here who cures people\u2019s illnesses?\u201d the\nboy asked.\n\u201cAllah cures our illnesses,\u201d said the man, clearly frightened of the\nstrangers. \u201cYou\u2019re looking for witch doctors.\u201d He spoke some verses\nfrom the Koran, and moved on."}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 74, "chunk": 0, "text": "Another man appeared. He was older, and was carrying a small\nbucket. The boy repeated his question.\n\u201cWhy do you want to find that sort of person?\u201d the Arab asked.\n\u201cBecause my friend here has traveled for many months in order to\nmeet with him,\u201d the boy said.\n\u201cIf such a man is here at the oasis, he must be the very powerful\none,\u201d said the old man after thinking for a few moments. \u201cNot even\nthe tribal chieftains are able to see him when they want to. Only\nwhen he consents.\n\u201cWait for the end of the war. Then leave with the caravan. Don\u2019t try\nto enter into the life of the oasis,\u201d he said, and walked away.\nBut the Englishman was exultant. They were on the right track.\nFinally, a young woman approached who was not dressed in\nblack. She had a vessel on her shoulder, and her head was covered\nby a veil, but her face was uncovered. The boy approached her to\nask about the alchemist.\nAt that moment, it seemed to him that time stood still, and the\nSoul of the World surged within him. When he looked into her dark\neyes, and saw that her lips were poised between a laugh and\nsilence, he learned the most important part of the language that all\nthe world spoke\u2014the language that everyone on earth was capable\nof understanding in their heart. It was love. Something older than\nhumanity, more ancient than the desert. Something that exerted the\nsame force whenever two pairs of eyes met, as had theirs here at\nthe well. She smiled, and that was certainly an omen\u2014the omen he\nhad been awaiting, without even knowing he was, for all his life. The"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 75, "chunk": 0, "text": "omen he had sought to find with his sheep and in his books, in the\ncrystals and in the silence of the desert.\nIt was the pure Language of the World. It required no explanation,\njust as the universe needs none as it travels through endless time.\nWhat the boy felt at that moment was that he was in the presence of\nthe only woman in his life, and that, with no need for words, she\nrecognized the same thing. He was more certain of it than of\nanything in the world. He had been told by his parents and\ngrandparents that he must fall in love and really know a person\nbefore becoming committed. But maybe people who felt that way\nhad never learned the universal language. Because, when you know\nthat language, it\u2019s easy to understand that someone in the world\nawaits you, whether it\u2019s in the middle of the desert or in some great\ncity. And when two such people encounter each other, and their eyes\nmeet, the past and the future become unimportant. There is only that\nmoment, and the incredible certainty that everything under the sun\nhas been written by one hand only. It is the hand that evokes love,\nand creates a twin soul for every person in the world. Without such\nlove, one\u2019s dreams would have no meaning.\nMaktub, thought the boy.\nThe Englishman shook the boy: \u201cCome on, ask her!\u201d\nThe boy stepped closer to the girl, and when she smiled, he did\nthe same.\n\u201cWhat\u2019s your name?\u201d he asked.\n\u201cFatima,\u201d the girl said, averting her eyes.\n\u201cThat\u2019s what some women in my country are called.\u201d\n\u201cIt\u2019s the name of the Prophet\u2019s daughter,\u201d Fatima said. \u201cThe\ninvaders carried the name everywhere.\u201d The beautiful girl spoke of\nthe invaders with pride.\nThe Englishman prodded him, and the boy asked her about the\nman who cured people\u2019s illnesses.\n\u201cThat\u2019s the man who knows all the secrets of the world,\u201d she said.\n\u201cHe communicates with the genies of the desert.\u201d\nThe genies were the spirits of good and evil. And the girl pointed\nto the south, indicating that it was there the strange man lived. Then\nshe filled her vessel with water and left."}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 76, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Englishman vanished, too, gone to find the alchemist. And\nthe boy sat there by the well for a long time, remembering that one\nday in Tarifa the levanter had brought to him the perfume of that\nwoman, and realizing that he had loved her before he even knew\nshe existed. He knew that his love for her would enable him to\ndiscover every treasure in the world.\nThe next day, the boy returned to the well, hoping to see the girl.\nTo his surprise, the Englishman was there, looking out at the desert.\n\u201cI waited all afternoon and evening,\u201d he said. \u201cHe appeared with\nthe first stars of evening. I told him what I was seeking, and he asked\nme if I had ever transformed lead into gold. I told him that was what I\nhad come here to learn.\n\u201cHe told me I should try to do so. That\u2019s all he said: \u2018Go and try.\u2019\u201d\nThe boy didn\u2019t say anything. The poor Englishman had traveled all\nthis way, only to be told that he should repeat what he had already\ndone so many times.\n\u201cSo, then try,\u201d he said to the Englishman.\n\u201cThat\u2019s what I\u2019m going to do. I\u2019m going to start now.\u201d\nAs the Englishman left, Fatima arrived and filled her vessel with\nwater.\n\u201cI came to tell you just one thing,\u201d the boy said. \u201cI want you to be\nmy wife. I love you.\u201d\nThe girl dropped the container, and the water spilled.\n\u201cI\u2019m going to wait here for you every day. I have crossed the\ndesert in search of a treasure that is somewhere near the Pyramids,\nand for me, the war seemed a curse. But now it\u2019s a blessing,\nbecause it brought me to you.\u201d\n\u201cThe war is going to end someday,\u201d the girl said.\nThe boy looked around him at the date palms. He reminded\nhimself that he had been a shepherd, and that he could be a"}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 77, "chunk": 0, "text": "shepherd again. Fatima was more important than his treasure.\n\u201cThe tribesmen are always in search of treasure,\u201d the girl said, as\nif she had guessed what he was thinking. \u201cAnd the women of the\ndesert are proud of their tribesmen.\u201d\nShe refilled her vessel and left.\nThe boy went to the well every day to meet with Fatima. He told\nher about his life as a shepherd, about the king, and about the\ncrystal shop. They became friends, and except for the fifteen\nminutes he spent with her, each day seemed that it would never\npass. When he had been at the oasis for almost a month, the leader\nof the caravan called a meeting of all of the people traveling with\nhim.\n\u201cWe don\u2019t know when the war will end, so we can\u2019t continue our\njourney,\u201d he said. \u201cThe battles may last for a long time, perhaps even\nyears. There are powerful forces on both sides, and the war is\nimportant to both armies. It\u2019s not a battle of good against evil. It\u2019s a\nwar between forces that are fighting for the balance of power, and,\nwhen that type of battle begins, it lasts longer than others\u2014because\nAllah is on both sides.\u201d\nThe people went back to where they were living, and the boy went\nto meet with Fatima that afternoon. He told her about the morning\u2019s\nmeeting. \u201cThe day after we met,\u201d Fatima said, \u201cyou told me that you\nloved me. Then, you taught me something of the universal language\nand the Soul of the World. Because of that, I have become a part of\nyou.\u201d\nThe boy listened to the sound of her voice, and thought it to be\nmore beautiful than the sound of the wind in the date palms.\n\u201cI have been waiting for you here at this oasis for a long time. I\nhave forgotten about my past, about my traditions, and the way in\nwhich men of the desert expect women to behave. Ever since I was\na child, I have dreamed that the desert would bring me a wonderful\npresent. Now, my present has arrived, and it\u2019s you.\u201d\nThe boy wanted to take her hand. But Fatima\u2019s hands held to the\nhandles of her jug.\n\u201cYou have told me about your dreams, about the old king and your\ntreasure. And you\u2019ve told me about om"}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 77, "chunk": 1, "text": "ens. So now, I fear nothing,"}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 78, "chunk": 0, "text": "because it was those omens that brought you to me. And I am a part\nof your dream, a part of your Personal Legend, as you call it.\n\u201cThat\u2019s why I want you to continue toward your goal. If you have to\nwait until the war is over, then wait. But if you have to go before then,\ngo on in pursuit of your dream. The dunes are changed by the wind,\nbut the desert never changes. That\u2019s the way it will be with our love\nfor each other.\n\u201cMaktub,\u201d she said. \u201cIf I am really a part of your dream, you\u2019ll\ncome back one day.\u201d\nThe boy was sad as he left her that day. He thought of all the\nmarried shepherds he had known. They had a difficult time\nconvincing their wives that they had to go off into distant fields. Love\nrequired them to stay with the people they loved.\nHe told Fatima that, at their next meeting.\n\u201cThe desert takes our men from us, and they don\u2019t always return,\u201d\nshe said. \u201cWe know that, and we are used to it. Those who don\u2019t\nreturn become a part of the clouds, a part of the animals that hide in\nthe ravines and of the water that comes from the earth. They\nbecome a part of everything . . . they become the Soul of the World.\n\u201cSome do come back. And then the other women are happy\nbecause they believe that their men may one day return, as well. I\nused to look at those women and envy them their happiness. Now, I\ntoo will be one of the women who wait.\n\u201cI\u2019m a desert woman, and I\u2019m proud of that. I want my husband to\nwander as free as the wind that shapes the dunes. And, if I have to, I\nwill accept the fact that he has become a part of the clouds, and the\nanimals, and the water of the desert.\u201d\nThe boy went to look for the Englishman. He wanted to tell him\nabout Fatima. He was surprised when he saw that the Englishman\nhad built himself a furnace outside his tent. It was a strange furnace,\nfueled by firewood, with a transparent flask heating on top. As the\nEnglishman stared out at the desert, his eyes seemed brighter than\nthey had when he was reading his books.\n\u201cThis"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 78, "chunk": 1, "text": " is the first phase of the job,\u201d he said. \u201cI have to separate out\nthe sulfur. To do that successfully, I must have no fear of failure. It\nwas my fear of failure that first kept me from attempting the Master"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 79, "chunk": 0, "text": "Work. Now, I\u2019m beginning what I could have started ten years ago.\nBut I\u2019m happy at least that I didn\u2019t wait twenty years.\u201d\nHe continued to feed the fire, and the boy stayed on until the\ndesert turned pink in the setting sun. He felt the urge to go out into\nthe desert, to see if its silence held the answers to his questions.\nHe wandered for a while, keeping the date palms of the oasis\nwithin sight. He listened to the wind, and felt the stones beneath his\nfeet. Here and there, he found a shell, and realized that the desert, in\nremote times, had been a sea. He sat on a stone, and allowed\nhimself to become hypnotized by the horizon. He tried to deal with\nthe concept of love as distinct from possession, and couldn\u2019t\nseparate them. But Fatima was a woman of the desert, and, if\nanything could help him to understand, it was the desert.\nAs he sat there thinking, he sensed movement above him.\nLooking up, he saw a pair of hawks flying high in the sky.\nHe watched the hawks as they drifted on the wind. Although their\nflight appeared to have no pattern, it made a certain kind of sense to\nthe boy. It was just that he couldn\u2019t grasp what it meant. He followed\nthe movement of the birds, trying to read something into it. Maybe\nthese desert birds could explain to him the meaning of love without\nownership.\nHe felt sleepy. In his heart, he wanted to remain awake, but he\nalso wanted to sleep. \u201cI am learning the Language of the World, and\neverything in the world is beginning to make sense to me . . . even\nthe flight of the hawks,\u201d he said to himself. And, in that mood, he was\ngrateful to be in love. When you are in love, things make even more\nsense, he thought.\nSuddenly, one of the hawks made a flashing dive through the sky,\nattacking the other. As it did so, a sudden, fleeting image came to"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 80, "chunk": 0, "text": "the boy: an army, with its swords at the ready, riding into the oasis.\nThe vision vanished immediately, but it had shaken him. He had\nheard people speak of mirages, and had already seen some himself:\nthey were desires that, because of their intensity, materialized over\nthe sands of the desert. But he certainly didn\u2019t desire that an army\ninvade the oasis.\nHe wanted to forget about the vision, and return to his meditation.\nHe tried again to concentrate on the pink shades of the desert, and\nits stones. But there was something there in his heart that wouldn\u2019t\nallow him to do so.\n\u201cAlways heed the omens,\u201d the old king had said. The boy recalled\nwhat he had seen in the vision, and sensed that it was actually going\nto occur.\nHe rose, and made his way back toward the palm trees. Once\nagain, he perceived the many languages in the things about him: this\ntime, the desert was safe, and it was the oasis that had become\ndangerous.\nThe camel driver was seated at the base of a palm tree, observing\nthe sunset. He saw the boy appear from the other side of the dunes.\n\u201cAn army is coming,\u201d the boy said. \u201cI had a vision.\u201d\n\u201cThe desert fills men\u2019s hearts with visions,\u201d the camel driver\nanswered.\nBut the boy told him about the hawks: that he had been watching\ntheir flight and had suddenly felt himself to have plunged to the Soul\nof the World.\nThe camel driver understood what the boy was saying. He knew\nthat any given thing on the face of the earth could reveal the history\nof all things. One could open a book to any page, or look at a\nperson\u2019s hand; one could turn a card, or watch the flight of the birds\n. . . whatever the thing observed, one could find a connection with\nhis experience of the moment. Actually, it wasn\u2019t that those things, in\nthemselves, revealed anything at all; it was just that people, looking\nat what was occurring around them, could find a means of\npenetration to the Soul of the World.\nThe desert was full of men who earned their living based on the\nease with which they could penetrate to the Soul of the World. They\nwere known as seers, and they were held in fear by women and the"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 81, "chunk": 0, "text": "elderly. Tribesmen were also wary of consulting them, because it\nwould be impossible to be effective in battle if one knew that he was\nfated to die. The tribesmen preferred the taste of battle, and the thrill\nof not knowing what the outcome would be; the future was already\nwritten by Allah, and what he had written was always for the good of\nman. So the tribesmen lived only for the present, because the\npresent was full of surprises, and they had to be aware of many\nthings: Where was the enemy\u2019s sword? Where was his horse? What\nkind of blow should one deliver next in order to remain alive? The\ncamel driver was not a fighter, and he had consulted with seers.\nMany of them had been right about what they said, while some had\nbeen wrong. Then, one day, the oldest seer he had ever sought out\n(and the one most to be feared) had asked why the camel driver was\nso interested in the future.\n\u201cWell . . . so I can do things,\u201d he had responded. \u201cAnd so I can\nchange those things that I don\u2019t want to happen.\u201d\n\u201cBut then they wouldn\u2019t be a part of your future,\u201d the seer had\nsaid.\n\u201cWell, maybe I just want to know the future so I can prepare\nmyself for what\u2019s coming.\u201d\n\u201cIf good things are coming, they will be a pleasant surprise,\u201d said\nthe seer. \u201cIf bad things are, and you know in advance, you will suffer\ngreatly before they even occur.\u201d\n\u201cI want to know about the future because I\u2019m a man,\u201d the camel\ndriver had said to the seer. \u201cAnd men always live their lives based on\nthe future.\u201d\nThe seer was a specialist in the casting of twigs; he threw them on\nthe ground, and made interpretations based on how they fell. That\nday, he didn\u2019t make a cast. He wrapped the twigs in a piece of cloth\nand put them back in his bag.\n\u201cI make my living forecasting the future for people,\u201d he said. \u201cI\nknow the science of the twigs, and I know how to use them to\npenetrate to the place where all is written. There, I can read the past,\ndiscover what has already been forgotten, and understand the\nomens that are here in the present.\n\u201cWhen people consult me, it\u2019s not"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 81, "chunk": 1, "text": " that I\u2019m reading the future; I am\nguessing at the future. The future belongs to God, and it is only he"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 82, "chunk": 0, "text": "who reveals it, under extraordinary circumstances. How do I guess\nat the future? Based on the omens of the present. The secret is here\nin the present. If you pay attention to the present, you can improve\nupon it. And, if you improve on the present, what comes later will\nalso be better. Forget about the future, and live each day according\nto the teachings, confident that God loves his children. Each day, in\nitself, brings with it an eternity.\u201d\nThe camel driver had asked what the circumstances were under\nwhich God would allow him to see the future.\n\u201cOnly when he, himself, reveals it. And God only rarely reveals the\nfuture. When he does so, it is for only one reason: it\u2019s a future that\nwas written so as to be altered.\u201d\nGod had shown the boy a part of the future, the camel driver\nthought. Why was it that he wanted the boy to serve as his\ninstrument?\n\u201cGo and speak to the tribal chieftains,\u201d said the camel driver. \u201cTell\nthem about the armies that are approaching.\u201d\n\u201cThey\u2019ll laugh at me.\u201d\n\u201cThey are men of the desert, and the men of the desert are used\nto dealing with omens.\u201d\n\u201cWell, then, they probably already know.\u201d\n\u201cThey\u2019re not concerned with that right now. They believe that if\nthey have to know about something Allah wants them to know,\nsomeone will tell them about it. It has happened many times before.\nBut, this time, the person is you.\u201d\nThe boy thought of Fatima. And he decided he would go to see\nthe chiefs of the tribes.\nThe boy approached the guard at the front of the huge white tent at\nthe center of the oasis.\n\u201cI want to see the chieftains. I\u2019ve brought omens from the desert.\u201d\nWithout responding, the guard entered the tent, where he\nremained for some time. When he emerged, it was with a young\nArab, dressed in white and gold. The boy told the younger man what"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 83, "chunk": 0, "text": "he had seen, and the man asked him to wait there. He disappeared\ninto the tent.\nNight fell, and an assortment of fighting men and merchants\nentered and exited the tent. One by one, the campfires were\nextinguished, and the oasis fell as quiet as the desert. Only the lights\nin the great tent remained. During all this time, the boy thought about\nFatima, and he was still unable to understand his last conversation\nwith her.\nFinally, after hours of waiting, the guard bade the boy enter. The\nboy was astonished by what he saw inside. Never could he have\nimagined that, there in the middle of the desert, there existed a tent\nlike this one. The ground was covered with the most beautiful\ncarpets he had ever walked upon, and from the top of the structure\nhung lamps of handwrought gold, each with a lighted candle. The\ntribal chieftains were seated at the back of the tent in a semicircle,\nresting upon richly embroidered silk cushions. Servants came and\nwent with silver trays laden with spices and tea. Other servants\nmaintained the fires in the hookahs. The atmosphere was suffused\nwith the sweet scent of smoke.\nThere were eight chieftains, but the boy could see immediately\nwhich of them was the most important: an Arab dressed in white and\ngold, seated at the center of the semicircle. At his side was the\nyoung Arab the boy had spoken with earlier.\n\u201cWho is this stranger who speaks of omens?\u201d asked one of the\nchieftains, eyeing the boy.\n\u201cIt is I,\u201d the boy answered. And he told what he had seen."}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 84, "chunk": 0, "text": "\u201cWhy would the desert reveal such things to a stranger, when it\nknows that we have been here for generations?\u201d said another of the\nchieftains.\n\u201cBecause my eyes are not yet accustomed to the desert,\u201d the boy\nsaid. \u201cI can see things that eyes habituated to the desert might not\nsee.\u201d\nAnd also because I know about the Soul of the World, he thought\nto himself.\n\u201cThe oasis is neutral ground. No one attacks an oasis,\u201d said a\nthird chieftain.\n\u201cI can only tell you what I saw. If you don\u2019t want to believe me, you\ndon\u2019t have to do anything about it.\u201d\nThe men fell into an animated discussion. They spoke in an\nArabic dialect that the boy didn\u2019t understand, but, when he made to\nleave, the guard told him to stay. The boy became fearful; the omens\ntold him that something was wrong. He regretted having spoken to\nthe camel driver about what he had seen in the desert.\nSuddenly, the elder at the center smiled almost imperceptibly, and\nthe boy felt better. The man hadn\u2019t participated in the discussion,\nand, in fact, hadn\u2019t said a word up to that point. But the boy was\nalready used to the Language of the World, and he could feel the\nvibrations of peace throughout the tent. Now his intuition was that he\nhad been right in coming.\nThe discussion ended. The chieftains were silent for a few\nmoments as they listened to what the old man was saying. Then he\nturned to the boy: this time his expression was cold and distant.\n\u201cTwo thousand years ago, in a distant land, a man who believed in\ndreams was thrown into a dungeon and then sold as a slave,\u201d the old\nman said, now in the dialect the boy understood. \u201cOur merchants\nbought that man, and brought him to Egypt. All of us know that\nwhoever believes in dreams also knows how to interpret them.\u201d\nThe elder continued, \u201cWhen the pharaoh dreamed of cows that\nwere thin and cows that were fat, this man I\u2019m speaking of rescued\nEgypt from famine. His name was Joseph. He, too, was a stranger in\na strange land, like you, and he was probably about your age.\u201d\nHe paused, and his eyes were still unfriendly."}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 85, "chunk": 0, "text": "\u201cWe always observe the Tradition. The Tradition saved Egypt from\nfamine in those days, and made the Egyptians the wealthiest of\npeoples. The Tradition teaches men how to cross the desert, and\nhow their children should marry. The Tradition says that an oasis is\nneutral territory, because both sides have oases, and so both are\nvulnerable.\u201d\nNo one said a word as the old man continued.\n\u201cBut the Tradition also says that we should believe the messages\nof the desert. Everything we know was taught to us by the desert.\u201d\nThe old man gave a signal, and everyone stood. The meeting was\nover. The hookahs were extinguished, and the guards stood at\nattention. The boy made ready to leave, but the old man spoke\nagain:\n\u201cTomorrow, we are going to break the agreement that says that no\none at the oasis may carry arms. Throughout the entire day we will\nbe on the lookout for our enemies. When the sun sets, the men will\nonce again surrender their arms to me. For every ten dead men\namong our enemies, you will receive a piece of gold.\n\u201cBut arms cannot be drawn unless they also go into battle. Arms\nare as capricious as the desert, and, if they are not used, the next\ntime they might not function. If at least one of them hasn\u2019t been used\nby the end of the day tomorrow, one will be used on you.\u201d\nWhen the boy left the tent, the oasis was illuminated only by the\nlight of the full moon. He was twenty minutes from his tent, and\nbegan to make his way there.\nHe was alarmed by what had happened. He had succeeded in\nreaching through to the Soul of the World, and now the price for\nhaving done so might be his life. It was a frightening bet. But he had\nbeen making risky bets ever since the day he had sold his sheep to\npursue his Personal Legend. And, as the camel driver had said, to\ndie tomorrow was no worse than dying on any other day. Every day\nwas there to be lived or to mark one\u2019s departure from this world.\nEverything depended on one word: \u201cMaktub.\u201d\nWalking along in the silence, he had no regrets. If he died\ntomorrow, it would be because God was not willing to change the\nfuture. He would at least have died after having crossed the"}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 85, "chunk": 1, "text": " strait,\nafter having worked in a crystal shop, and after having known the"}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 86, "chunk": 0, "text": "silence of the desert and Fatima\u2019s eyes. He had lived every one of\nhis days intensely since he had left home so long ago. If he died\ntomorrow, he would already have seen more than other shepherds,\nand he was proud of that.\nSuddenly he heard a thundering sound, and he was thrown to the\nground by a wind such as he had never known. The area was\nswirling in dust so intense that it hid the moon from view. Before him\nwas an enormous white horse, rearing over him with a frightening\nscream.\nWhen the blinding dust had settled a bit, the boy trembled at what\nhe saw. Astride the animal was a horseman dressed completely in\nblack, with a falcon perched on his left shoulder. He wore a turban\nand his entire face, except for his eyes, was covered with a black\nkerchief. He appeared to be a messenger from the desert, but his\npresence was much more powerful than that of a mere messenger.\nThe strange horseman drew an enormous, curved sword from a\nscabbard mounted on his saddle. The steel of its blade glittered in\nthe light of the moon.\n\u201cWho dares to read the meaning of the flight of the hawks?\u201d he\ndemanded, so loudly that his words seemed to echo through the fifty\nthousand palm trees of Al-Fayoum.\n\u201cIt is I who dared to do so,\u201d said the boy. He was reminded of the\nimage of Santiago Matamoros, mounted on his white horse, with the"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 87, "chunk": 0, "text": "infidels beneath his hooves. This man looked exactly the same,\nexcept that now the roles were reversed.\n\u201cIt is I who dared to do so,\u201d he repeated, and he lowered his head\nto receive a blow from the sword. \u201cMany lives will be saved, because\nI was able to see through to the Soul of the World.\u201d\nThe sword didn\u2019t fall. Instead, the stranger lowered it slowly, until\nthe point touched the boy\u2019s forehead. It drew a droplet of blood.\nThe horseman was completely immobile, as was the boy. It didn\u2019t\neven occur to the boy to flee. In his heart, he felt a strange sense of\njoy: he was about to die in pursuit of his Personal Legend. And for\nFatima. The omens had been true, after all. Here he was, face-to-\nface with his enemy, but there was no need to be concerned about\ndying\u2014the Soul of the World awaited him, and he would soon be a\npart of it. And, tomorrow, his enemy would also be a part of that\nSoul.\nThe stranger continued to hold the sword at the boy\u2019s forehead.\n\u201cWhy did you read the flight of the birds?\u201d\n\u201cI read only what the birds wanted to tell me. They wanted to save\nthe oasis. Tomorrow all of you will die, because there are more men\nat the oasis than you have.\u201d\nThe sword remained where it was. \u201cWho are you to change what\nAllah has willed?\u201d\n\u201cAllah created the armies, and he also created the hawks. Allah\ntaught me the language of the birds. Everything has been written by\nthe same hand,\u201d the boy said, remembering the camel driver\u2019s\nwords.\nThe stranger withdrew the sword from the boy\u2019s forehead, and the\nboy felt immensely relieved. But he still couldn\u2019t flee.\n\u201cBe careful with your prognostications,\u201d said the stranger. \u201cWhen\nsomething is written, there is no way to change it.\u201d\n\u201cAll I saw was an army,\u201d said the boy. \u201cI didn\u2019t see the outcome of\nthe battle.\u201d\nThe stranger seemed satisfied with the answer. But he kept the\nsword in his hand. \u201cWhat is a stranger doing in a strange land?\u201d\n\u201cI am following my Personal Legend. It\u2019s not something you would\nunderstand.\u201d"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 88, "chunk": 0, "text": "The stranger placed his sword in its scabbard, and the boy\nrelaxed.\n\u201cI had to test your courage,\u201d the stranger said. \u201cCourage is the\nquality most essential to understanding the Language of the World.\u201d\nThe boy was surprised. The stranger was speaking of things that\nvery few people knew about.\n\u201cYou must not let up, even after having come so far,\u201d he\ncontinued. \u201cYou must love the desert, but never trust it completely.\nBecause the desert tests all men: it challenges every step, and kills\nthose who become distracted.\u201d\nWhat he said reminded the boy of the old king.\n\u201cIf the warriors come here, and your head is still on your shoulders\nat sunset, come and find me,\u201d said the stranger.\nThe same hand that had brandished the sword now held a whip.\nThe horse reared again, raising a cloud of dust.\n\u201cWhere do you live?\u201d shouted the boy, as the horseman rode\naway.\nThe hand with the whip pointed to the south.\nThe boy had met the alchemist.\nNext morning, there were two thousand armed men scattered\nthroughout the palm trees at Al-Fayoum. Before the sun had reached\nits high point, five hundred tribesmen appeared on the horizon. The\nmounted troops entered the oasis from the north; it appeared to be a\npeaceful expedition, but they all carried arms hidden in their robes.\nWhen they reached the white tent at the center of Al-Fayoum, they\nwithdrew their scimitars and rifles. And they attacked an empty tent.\nThe men of the oasis surrounded the horsemen from the desert\nand within half an hour all but one of the intruders were dead. The\nchildren had been kept at the other side of a grove of palm trees,\nand saw nothing of what had happened. The women had remained\nin their tents, praying for the safekeeping of their husbands, and saw\nnothing of the battle, either. Were it not for the bodies there on the\nground, it would have appeared to be a normal day at the oasis."}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 89, "chunk": 0, "text": "The only tribesman spared was the commander of the battalion.\nThat afternoon, he was brought before the tribal chieftains, who\nasked him why he had violated the Tradition. The commander said\nthat his men had been starving and thirsty, exhausted from many\ndays of battle, and had decided to take the oasis so as to be able to\nreturn to the war.\nThe tribal chieftain said that he felt sorry for the tribesmen, but\nthat the Tradition was sacred. He condemned the commander to\ndeath without honor. Rather than being killed by a blade or a bullet,\nhe was hanged from a dead palm tree, where his body twisted in the\ndesert wind.\nThe tribal chieftain called for the boy, and presented him with fifty\npieces of gold. He repeated his story about Joseph of Egypt, and\nasked the boy to become the counselor of the oasis.\nWhen the sun had set, and the first stars made their appearance, the\nboy started to walk to the south. He eventually sighted a single tent,\nand a group of Arabs passing by told the boy that it was a place\ninhabited by genies. But the boy sat down and waited.\nNot until the moon was high did the alchemist ride into view. He\ncarried two dead hawks over his shoulder.\n\u201cI am here,\u201d the boy said.\n\u201cYou shouldn\u2019t be here,\u201d the alchemist answered. \u201cOr is it your\nPersonal Legend that brings you here?\u201d\n\u201cWith the wars between the tribes, it\u2019s impossible to cross the\ndesert. So I have come here.\u201d\nThe alchemist dismounted from his horse, and signaled that the\nboy should enter the tent with him. It was a tent like many at the\noasis. The boy looked around for the ovens and other apparatus\nused in alchemy, but saw none. There were only some books in a\npile, a small cooking stove, and the carpets, covered with mysterious\ndesigns.\n\u201cSit down. We\u2019ll have something to drink and eat these hawks,\u201d\nsaid the alchemist."}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 90, "chunk": 0, "text": "The boy suspected that they were the same hawks he had seen\non the day before, but he said nothing. The alchemist lighted the fire,\nand soon a delicious aroma filled the tent. It was better than the\nscent of the hookahs.\n\u201cWhy did you want to see me?\u201d the boy asked.\n\u201cBecause of the omens,\u201d the alchemist answered. \u201cThe wind told\nme you would be coming, and that you would need help.\u201d\n\u201cIt\u2019s not I the wind spoke about. It\u2019s the other foreigner, the\nEnglishman. He\u2019s the one that\u2019s looking for you.\u201d\n\u201cHe has other things to do first. But he\u2019s on the right track. He has\nbegun to try to understand the desert.\u201d\n\u201cAnd what about me?\u201d\n\u201cWhen a person really desires something, all the universe\nconspires to help that person to realize his dream,\u201d said the\nalchemist, echoing the words of the old king. The boy understood.\nAnother person was there to help him toward his Personal Legend.\n\u201cSo you are going to instruct me?\u201d\n\u201cNo. You already know all you need to know. I am only going to\npoint you in the direction of your treasure.\u201d\n\u201cBut there\u2019s a tribal war,\u201d the boy reiterated.\n\u201cI know what\u2019s happening in the desert.\u201d\n\u201cI have already found my treasure. I have a camel, I have my\nmoney from the crystal shop, and I have fifty gold pieces. In my own\ncountry, I would be a rich man.\u201d\n\u201cBut none of that is from the Pyramids,\u201d said the alchemist.\n\u201cI also have Fatima. She is a treasure greater than anything else I\nhave won.\u201d\n\u201cShe wasn\u2019t found at the Pyramids, either.\u201d\nThey ate in silence. The alchemist opened a bottle and poured a\nred liquid into the boy\u2019s cup. It was the most delicious wine he had\never tasted.\n\u201cIsn\u2019t wine prohibited here?\u201d the boy asked\n\u201cIt\u2019s not what enters men\u2019s mouths that\u2019s evil,\u201d said the alchemist.\n\u201cIt\u2019s what comes out of their mouths that is.\u201d\nThe alchemist was a bit daunting, but, as the boy drank the wine,\nhe relaxed. After they finished eating they sat outside the tent, under\na moon so brilliant that it made the stars pale."}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 91, "chunk": 0, "text": "\u201cDrink and enjoy yourself,\u201d said the alchemist, noticing that the\nboy was feeling happier. \u201cRest well tonight, as if you were a warrior\npreparing for combat. Remember that wherever your heart is, there\nyou will find your treasure. You\u2019ve got to find the treasure, so that\neverything you have learned along the way can make sense.\n\u201cTomorrow, sell your camel and buy a horse. Camels are\ntraitorous: they walk thousands of paces and never seem to tire.\nThen suddenly, they kneel and die. But horses tire bit by bit. You\nalways know how much you can ask of them, and when it is that they\nare about to die.\u201d\nThe following night, the boy appeared at the alchemist\u2019s tent with a\nhorse. The alchemist was ready, and he mounted his own steed and\nplaced the falcon on his left shoulder. He said to the boy, \u201cShow me\nwhere there is life out in the desert. Only those who can see such\nsigns of life are able to find treasure.\u201d\nThey began to ride out over the sands, with the moon lighting their\nway. I don\u2019t know if I\u2019ll be able to find life in the desert, the boy\nthought. I don\u2019t know the desert that well yet.\nHe wanted to say so to the alchemist, but he was afraid of the\nman. They reached the rocky place where the boy had seen the\nhawks in the sky, but now there was only silence and the wind.\n\u201cI don\u2019t know how to find life in the desert,\u201d the boy said. \u201cI know\nthat there is life here, but I don\u2019t know where to look.\u201d\n\u201cLife attracts life,\u201d the alchemist answered.\nAnd then the boy understood. He loosened the reins on his horse,\nwho galloped forward over the rocks and sand. The alchemist\nfollowed as the boy\u2019s horse ran for almost half an hour. They could\nno longer see the palms of the oasis\u2014only the gigantic moon above\nthem, and its silver reflections from the stones of the desert.\nSuddenly, for no apparent reason, the boy\u2019s horse began to slow.\n\u201cThere\u2019s life here,\u201d the boy said to the alchemist. \u201cI don\u2019t know the\nlanguage of the desert, but my horse knows the language of life.\u201d\nThey dismounted, and the alchemist said nothing. Advancing\nslow"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 91, "chunk": 1, "text": "ly, they searched among the stones. The alchemist stopped"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 92, "chunk": 0, "text": "abruptly, and bent to the ground. There was a hole there among the\nstones. The alchemist put his hand into the hole, and then his entire\narm, up to his shoulder. Something was moving there, and the\nalchemist\u2019s eyes\u2014the boy could see only his eyes\u2014squinted with\nhis effort. His arm seemed to be battling with whatever was in the\nhole. Then, with a motion that startled the boy, he withdrew his arm\nand leaped to his feet. In his hand, he grasped a snake by the tail.\nThe boy leapt as well, but away from the alchemist. The snake\nfought frantically, making hissing sounds that shattered the silence of\nthe desert. It was a cobra, whose venom could kill a person in\nminutes.\n\u201cWatch out for his venom,\u201d the boy said. But even though the\nalchemist had put his hand in the hole, and had surely already been\nbitten, his expression was calm. \u201cThe alchemist is two hundred years\nold,\u201d the Englishman had told him. He must know how to deal with\nthe snakes of the desert.\nThe boy watched as his companion went to his horse and\nwithdrew a scimitar. With its blade, he drew a circle in the sand, and\nthen he placed the snake within it. The serpent relaxed immediately.\n\u201cNot to worry,\u201d said the alchemist. \u201cHe won\u2019t leave the circle. You\nfound life in the desert, the omen that I needed.\u201d\n\u201cWhy was that so important?\u201d\n\u201cBecause the Pyramids are surrounded by the desert.\u201d The boy\ndidn\u2019t want to talk about the Pyramids. His heart was heavy, and he\nhad been melancholy since the previous night. To continue his\nsearch for the treasure meant that he had to abandon Fatima.\n\u201cI\u2019m going to guide you across the desert,\u201d the alchemist said.\n\u201cI want to stay at the oasis,\u201d the boy answered. \u201cI\u2019ve found Fatima,\nand, as far as I\u2019m concerned, she\u2019s worth more than treasure.\u201d"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 93, "chunk": 0, "text": "\u201cFatima is a woman of the desert,\u201d said the alchemist. \u201cShe knows\nthat men have to go away in order to return. And she already has her\ntreasure: it\u2019s you. Now she expects that you will find what it is you\u2019re\nlooking for.\u201d\n\u201cWell, what if I decide to stay?\u201d\n\u201cLet me tell you what will happen. You\u2019ll be the counselor of the\noasis. You have enough gold to buy many sheep and many camels.\nYou\u2019ll marry Fatima, and you\u2019ll both be happy for a year. You\u2019ll learn\nto love the desert, and you\u2019ll get to know every one of the fifty\nthousand palms. You\u2019ll watch them as they grow, demonstrating how\nthe world is always changing. And you\u2019ll get better and better at\nunderstanding omens, because the desert is the best teacher there\nis.\n\u201cSometime during the second year, you\u2019ll remember about the\ntreasure. The omens will begin insistently to speak of it, and you\u2019ll try\nto ignore them. You\u2019ll use your knowledge for the welfare of the oasis\nand its inhabitants. The tribal chieftains will appreciate what you do.\nAnd your camels will bring you wealth and power.\n\u201cDuring the third year, the omens will continue to speak of your\ntreasure and your Personal Legend. You\u2019ll walk around, night after\nnight, at the oasis, and Fatima will be unhappy because she\u2019ll feel it\nwas she who interrupted your quest. But you will love her, and she\u2019ll\nreturn your love. You\u2019ll remember that she never asked you to stay,\nbecause a woman of the desert knows that she must await her man.\nSo you won\u2019t blame her. But many times you\u2019ll walk the sands of the\ndesert, thinking that maybe you could have left . . . that you could\nhave trusted more in your love for Fatima. Because what kept you at\nthe oasis was your own fear that you might never come back. At that\npoint, the omens will tell you that your treasure is buried forever.\n\u201cThen, sometime during the fourth year, the omens will abandon\nyou, because you\u2019ve stopped listening to them. The tribal chieftains\nwill see that, and you\u2019ll be dismissed from your position as counselor.\nBut, by then, you\u2019ll be a rich merchant, with many"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 93, "chunk": 1, "text": " camels and a\ngreat deal of merchandise. You\u2019ll spend the rest of your days\nknowing that you didn\u2019t pursue your Personal Legend, and that now\nit\u2019s too late."}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 94, "chunk": 0, "text": "\u201cYou must understand that love never keeps a man from pursuing\nhis Personal Legend. If he abandons that pursuit, it\u2019s because it\nwasn\u2019t true love . . . the love that speaks the Language of the World.\u201d\nThe alchemist erased the circle in the sand, and the snake\nslithered away among the rocks. The boy remembered the crystal\nmerchant who had always wanted to go to Mecca, and the\nEnglishman in search of the alchemist. He thought of the woman\nwho had trusted in the desert. And he looked out over the desert that\nhad brought him to the woman he loved.\nThey mounted their horses, and this time it was the boy who\nfollowed the alchemist back to the oasis. The wind brought the\nsounds of the oasis to them, and the boy tried to hear Fatima\u2019s\nvoice.\nBut that night, as he had watched the cobra within the circle, the\nstrange horseman with the falcon on his shoulder had spoken of love\nand treasure, of the women of the desert and of his Personal\nLegend.\n\u201cI\u2019m going with you,\u201d the boy said. And he immediately felt peace\nin his heart.\n\u201cWe\u2019ll leave tomorrow before sunrise,\u201d was the alchemist\u2019s only\nresponse.\nThe boy spent a sleepless night. Two hours before dawn, he awoke\none of the boys who slept in his tent, and asked him to show him\nwhere Fatima lived. They went to her tent, and the boy gave his\nfriend enough gold to buy a sheep.\nThen he asked his friend to go into the tent where Fatima was\nsleeping, and to awaken her and tell her that he was waiting outside.\nThe young Arab did as he was asked, and was given enough gold to\nbuy yet another sheep.\n\u201cNow leave us alone,\u201d said the boy to the young Arab. The Arab\nreturned to his tent to sleep, proud to have helped the counselor of\nthe oasis, and happy at having enough money to buy himself some\nsheep."}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 95, "chunk": 0, "text": "Fatima appeared at the entrance to the tent. The two walked out\namong the palms. The boy knew that it was a violation of the\nTradition, but that didn\u2019t matter to him now.\n\u201cI\u2019m going away,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd I want you to know that I\u2019m coming\nback. I love you because . . .\u201d\n\u201cDon\u2019t say anything,\u201d Fatima interrupted. \u201cOne is loved because\none is loved. No reason is needed for loving.\u201d\nBut the boy continued, \u201cI had a dream, and I met with a king. I\nsold crystal and crossed the desert. And, because the tribes\ndeclared war, I went to the well, seeking the alchemist. So, I love you\nbecause the entire universe conspired to help me find you.\u201d\nThe two embraced. It was the first time either had touched the\nother.\n\u201cI\u2019ll be back,\u201d the boy said.\n\u201cBefore this, I always looked to the desert with longing,\u201d said\nFatima. \u201cNow it will be with hope. My father went away one day, but\nhe returned to my mother, and he has always come back since\nthen.\u201d\nThey said nothing else. They walked a bit farther among the\npalms, and then the boy left her at the entrance to her tent.\n\u201cI\u2019ll return, just as your father came back to your mother,\u201d he said.\nHe saw that Fatima\u2019s eyes were filled with tears.\n\u201cYou\u2019re crying?\u201d\n\u201cI\u2019m a woman of the desert,\u201d she said, averting her face. \u201cBut\nabove all, I\u2019m a woman.\u201d\nFatima went back to her tent, and, when daylight came, she went\nout to do the chores she had done for years. But everything had\nchanged. The boy was no longer at the oasis, and the oasis would\nnever again have the same meaning it had had only yesterday. It\nwould no longer be a place with fifty thousand palm trees and three\nhundred wells, where the pilgrims arrived, relieved at the end of their\nlong journeys. From that day on, the oasis would be an empty place\nfor her.\nFrom that day on, it was the desert that would be important. She\nwould look to it every day, and would try to guess which star the boy\nwas following in search of his treasure. She would have to send her\nkisses on the wind, hoping that the"}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 96, "chunk": 0, "text": "and would tell him that she was alive. From\nthat day on, the desert would represent only one thing to her: the\nhope for his return.\n\u201cDon\u2019t think about what you\u2019ve left behind,\u201d the alchemist said to the\nboy as they began to ride across the sands of the desert. \u201cEverything\nis written in the Soul of the World, and there it will stay forever.\u201d\n\u201cMen dream more about coming home than about leaving,\u201d the\nboy said. He was already reaccustomed to the desert\u2019s silence.\n\u201cIf what one finds is made of pure matter, it will never spoil. And\none can always come back. If what you had found was only a\nmoment of light, like the explosion of a star, you would find nothing\non your return.\u201d\nThe man was speaking the language of alchemy. But the boy\nknew that he was referring to Fatima.\nIt was difficult not to think about what he had left behind. The\ndesert, with its endless monotony, put him to dreaming. The boy\ncould still see the palm trees, the wells, and the face of the woman\nhe loved. He could see the Englishman at his experiments, and the\ncamel driver who was a teacher without realizing it. Maybe the\nalchemist has never been in love, the boy thought.\nThe alchemist rode in front, with the falcon on his shoulder. The\nbird knew the language of the desert well, and whenever they\nstopped, he flew off in search of game. On the first day he returned\nwith a rabbit, and on the second with two birds."}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 97, "chunk": 0, "text": "At night, they spread their sleeping gear and kept their fires\nhidden. The desert nights were cold, and were becoming darker and\ndarker as the phases of the moon passed. They went on for a week,\nspeaking only of the precautions they needed to follow in order to\navoid the battles between the tribes. The war continued, and at times\nthe wind carried the sweet, sickly smell of blood. Battles had been\nfought nearby, and the wind reminded the boy that there was the\nlanguage of omens, always ready to show him what his eyes had\nfailed to observe.\nOn the seventh day, the alchemist decided to make camp earlier\nthan usual. The falcon flew off to find game, and the alchemist\noffered his water container to the boy.\n\u201cYou are almost at the end of your journey,\u201d said the alchemist. \u201cI\ncongratulate you for having pursued your Personal Legend.\u201d\n\u201cAnd you\u2019ve told me nothing along the way,\u201d said the boy. \u201cI\nthought you were going to teach me some of the things you know. A\nwhile ago, I rode through the desert with a man who had books on\nalchemy. But I wasn\u2019t able to learn anything from them.\u201d\n\u201cThere is only one way to learn,\u201d the alchemist answered. \u201cIt\u2019s\nthrough action. Everything you need to know you have learned\nthrough your journey. You need to learn only one thing more.\u201d\nThe boy wanted to know what that was, but the alchemist was\nsearching the horizon, looking for the falcon.\n\u201cWhy are you called the alchemist?\u201d\n\u201cBecause that\u2019s what I am.\u201d\n\u201cAnd what went wrong when other alchemists tried to make gold\nand were unable to do so?\u201d\n\u201cThey were looking only for gold,\u201d his companion answered. \u201cThey\nwere seeking the treasure of their Personal Legend, without wanting\nactually to live out the Personal Legend.\u201d\n\u201cWhat is it that I still need to know?\u201d the boy asked.\nBut the alchemist continued to look to the horizon. And finally the\nfalcon returned with their meal. They dug a hole and lit their fire in it,\nso that the light of the flames would not be seen.\n\u201cI\u2019m an alchemist simply because I\u2019m an alchemist,\u201d he said, as he\nprepared the meal. \u201cI learned the science from my grandfather, who\nlearned from his father, and so on,"}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 97, "chunk": 1, "text": " back to the creation of the world."}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 98, "chunk": 0, "text": "In those times, the Master Work could be written simply on an\nemerald. But men began to reject simple things, and to write tracts,\ninterpretations, and philosophical studies. They also began to feel\nthat they knew a better way than others had. Yet the Emerald Tablet\nis still alive today.\u201d\n\u201cWhat was written on the Emerald Tablet?\u201d the boy wanted to\nknow.\nThe alchemist began to draw in the sand, and completed his\ndrawing in less than five minutes. As he drew, the boy thought of the\nold king, and the plaza where they had met that day; it seemed as if\nit had taken place years and years ago.\n\u201cThis is what was written on the Emerald Tablet,\u201d said the\nalchemist, when he had finished.\nThe boy tried to read what was written in the sand.\n\u201cIt\u2019s a code,\u201d said the boy, a bit disappointed. \u201cIt looks like what I\nsaw in the Englishman\u2019s books.\u201d\n\u201cNo,\u201d the alchemist answered. \u201cIt\u2019s like the flight of those two\nhawks; it can\u2019t be understood by reason alone. The Emerald Tablet\nis a direct passage to the Soul of the World.\n\u201cThe wise men understood that this natural world is only an image\nand a copy of paradise. The existence of this world is simply a\nguarantee that there exists a world that is perfect. God created the\nworld so that, through its visible objects, men could understand his\nspiritual teachings and the marvels of his wisdom. That\u2019s what I\nmean by action.\u201d\n\u201cShould I understand the Emerald Tablet?\u201d the boy asked.\n\u201cPerhaps, if you were in a laboratory of alchemy, this would be the\nright time to study the best way to understand the Emerald Tablet.\nBut you are in the desert. So immerse yourself in it. The desert will\ngive you an understanding of the world; in fact, anything on the face\nof the earth will do that. You don\u2019t even have to understand the\ndesert: all you have to do is contemplate a simple grain of sand, and\nyou will see in it all the marvels of creation.\u201d\n\u201cHow do I immerse myself in the desert?\u201d"}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 99, "chunk": 0, "text": "\u201cListen to your heart. It knows all things, because it came from the\nSoul of the World, and it will one day return there.\u201d\nThey crossed the desert for another two days in silence. The\nalchemist had become much more cautious, because they were\napproaching the area where the most violent battles were being\nwaged. As they moved along, the boy tried to listen to his heart.\nIt was not easy to do; in earlier times, his heart had always been\nready to tell its story, but lately that wasn\u2019t true. There had been\ntimes when his heart spent hours telling of its sadness, and at other\ntimes it became so emotional over the desert sunrise that the boy\nhad to hide his tears. His heart beat fastest when it spoke to the boy\nof treasure, and more slowly when the boy stared entranced at the\nendless horizons of the desert. But his heart was never quiet, even\nwhen the boy and the alchemist had fallen into silence.\n\u201cWhy do we have to listen to our hearts?\u201d the boy asked, when\nthey had made camp that day.\n\u201cBecause, wherever your heart is, that is where you\u2019ll find your\ntreasure.\u201d\n\u201cBut my heart is agitated,\u201d the boy said. \u201cIt has its dreams, it gets\nemotional, and it\u2019s become passionate over a woman of the desert. It\nasks things of me, and it keeps me from sleeping many nights, when\nI\u2019m thinking about her.\u201d\n\u201cWell, that\u2019s good. Your heart is alive. Keep listening to what it has\nto say.\u201d\nDuring the next three days, the two travelers passed by a number\nof armed tribesmen, and saw others on the horizon. The boy\u2019s heart\nbegan to speak of fear. It told him stories it had heard from the Soul"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 100, "chunk": 0, "text": "of the World, stories of men who sought to find their treasure and\nnever succeeded. Sometimes it frightened the boy with the idea that\nhe might not find his treasure, or that he might die there in the\ndesert. At other times, it told the boy that it was satisfied: it had found\nlove and riches.\n\u201cMy heart is a traitor,\u201d the boy said to the alchemist, when they\nhad paused to rest the horses. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t want me to go on.\u201d\n\u201cThat makes sense,\u201d the alchemist answered. \u201cNaturally it\u2019s afraid\nthat, in pursuing your dream, you might lose everything you\u2019ve won.\u201d\n\u201cWell, then, why should I listen to my heart?\u201d\n\u201cBecause you will never again be able to keep it quiet. Even if you\npretend not to have heard what it tells you, it will always be there\ninside you, repeating to you what you\u2019re thinking about life and about\nthe world.\u201d\n\u201cYou mean I should listen, even if it\u2019s treasonous?\u201d\n\u201cTreason is a blow that comes unexpectedly. If you know your\nheart well, it will never be able to do that to you. Because you\u2019ll know\nits dreams and wishes, and will know how to deal with them.\n\u201cYou will never be able to escape from your heart. So it\u2019s better to\nlisten to what it has to say. That way, you\u2019ll never have to fear an\nunanticipated blow.\u201d\nThe boy continued to listen to his heart as they crossed the\ndesert. He came to understand its dodges and tricks, and to accept it\nas it was. He lost his fear, and forgot about his need to go back to\nthe oasis, because, one afternoon, his heart told him that it was\nhappy. \u201cEven though I complain sometimes,\u201d it said, \u201cit\u2019s because I\u2019m\nthe heart of a person, and people\u2019s hearts are that way. People are\nafraid to pursue their most important dreams, because they feel that\nthey don\u2019t deserve them, or that they\u2019ll be unable to achieve them.\nWe, their hearts, become fearful just thinking of loved ones who go\naway forever, or of moments that could have been good but weren\u2019t,\nor of treasures that might have been found but were forever hidden\nin the sands. Because, when these things happen, we suffer terribly.\u201d\n\u201cMy heart is afraid that it will have to"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 100, "chunk": 1, "text": " suffer,\u201d the boy told the\nalchemist one night as they looked up at the moonless sky.\n\u201cTell your heart that the fear of suffering is worse than the suffering\nitself. And that no heart has ever suffered when it goes in search of"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 101, "chunk": 0, "text": "its dreams, because every second of the search is a second\u2019s\nencounter with God and with eternity.\u201d\n\u201cEvery second of the search is an encounter with God,\u201d the boy\ntold his heart. \u201cWhen I have been truly searching for my treasure,\nevery day has been luminous, because I\u2019ve known that every hour\nwas a part of the dream that I would find it. When I have been truly\nsearching for my treasure, I\u2019ve discovered things along the way that I\nnever would have seen had I not had the courage to try things that\nseemed impossible for a shepherd to achieve.\u201d\nSo his heart was quiet for an entire afternoon. That night, the boy\nslept deeply, and, when he awoke, his heart began to tell him things\nthat came from the Soul of the World. It said that all people who are\nhappy have God within them. And that happiness could be found in a\ngrain of sand from the desert, as the alchemist had said. Because a\ngrain of sand is a moment of creation, and the universe has taken\nmillions of years to create it. \u201cEveryone on earth has a treasure that\nawaits him,\u201d his heart said. \u201cWe, people\u2019s hearts, seldom say much\nabout those treasures, because people no longer want to go in\nsearch of them. We speak of them only to children. Later, we simply\nlet life proceed, in its own direction, toward its own fate. But,\nunfortunately, very few follow the path laid out for them\u2014the path to\ntheir Personal Legends, and to happiness. Most people see the\nworld as a threatening place, and, because they do, the world turns\nout, indeed, to be a threatening place.\n\u201cSo, we, their hearts, speak more and more softly. We never stop\nspeaking out, but we begin to hope that our words won\u2019t be heard:\nwe don\u2019t want people to suffer because they don\u2019t follow their\nhearts.\u201d\n\u201cWhy don\u2019t people\u2019s hearts tell them to continue to follow their\ndreams?\u201d the boy asked the alchemist.\n\u201cBecause that\u2019s what makes a heart suffer most, and hearts don\u2019t\nlike to suffer.\u201d\nFrom then on, the boy understood his heart. He asked it, please,\nnever to stop speaking to him. He asked that, when he wandered far\nfrom his dreams, his heart press"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 101, "chunk": 1, "text": " him and sound the alarm. The boy\nswore that, every time he heard the alarm, he would heed its\nmessage."}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 102, "chunk": 0, "text": "That night, he told all of this to the alchemist. And the alchemist\nunderstood that the boy\u2019s heart had returned to the Soul of the\nWorld.\n\u201cSo what should I do now?\u201d the boy asked.\n\u201cContinue in the direction of the Pyramids,\u201d said the alchemist.\n\u201cAnd continue to pay heed to the omens. Your heart is still capable of\nshowing you where the treasure is.\u201d\n\u201cIs that the one thing I still needed to know?\u201d\n\u201cNo,\u201d the alchemist answered. \u201cWhat you still need to know is this:\nbefore a dream is realized, the Soul of the World tests everything\nthat was learned along the way. It does this not because it is evil, but\nso that we can, in addition to realizing our dreams, master the\nlessons we\u2019ve learned as we\u2019ve moved toward that dream. That\u2019s\nthe point at which most people give up. It\u2019s the point at which, as we\nsay in the language of the desert, one \u2018dies of thirst just when the\npalm trees have appeared on the horizon.\u2019\n\u201cEvery search begins with beginner\u2019s luck. And every search ends\nwith the victor\u2019s being severely tested.\u201d\nThe boy remembered an old proverb from his country. It said that\nthe darkest hour of the night came just before the dawn.\nOn the following day, the first clear sign of danger appeared. Three\narmed tribesmen approached, and asked what the boy and the\nalchemist were doing there.\n\u201cI\u2019m hunting with my falcon,\u201d the alchemist answered.\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to have to search you to see whether you\u2019re armed,\u201d\none of the tribesmen said.\nThe alchemist dismounted slowly, and the boy did the same.\n\u201cWhy are you carrying money?\u201d asked the tribesman, when he\nhad searched the boy\u2019s bag.\n\u201cI need it to get to the Pyramids,\u201d he said.\nThe tribesman who was searching the alchemist\u2019s belongings\nfound a small crystal flask filled with a liquid, and a yellow glass egg\nthat was slightly larger than a chicken\u2019s egg.\n\u201cWhat are these things?\u201d he asked."}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 103, "chunk": 0, "text": "\u201cThat\u2019s the Philosopher\u2019s Stone and the Elixir of Life. It\u2019s the\nMaster Work of the alchemists. Whoever swallows that elixir will\nnever be sick again, and a fragment from that stone turns any metal\ninto gold.\u201d\nThe Arabs laughed at him, and the alchemist laughed along. They\nthought his answer was amusing, and they allowed the boy and the\nalchemist to proceed with all of their belongings.\n\u201cAre you crazy?\u201d the boy asked the alchemist, when they had\nmoved on. \u201cWhat did you do that for?\u201d\n\u201cTo show you one of life\u2019s simple lessons,\u201d the alchemist\nanswered. \u201cWhen you possess great treasures within you, and try to\ntell others of them, seldom are you believed.\u201d\nThey continued across the desert. With every day that passed, the\nboy\u2019s heart became more and more silent. It no longer wanted to\nknow about things of the past or future; it was content simply to\ncontemplate the desert, and to drink with the boy from the Soul of\nthe World. The boy and his heart had become friends, and neither\nwas capable now of betraying the other.\nWhen his heart spoke to him, it was to provide a stimulus to the\nboy, and to give him strength, because the days of silence there in\nthe desert were wearisome. His heart told the boy what his strongest\nqualities were: his courage in having given up his sheep and in trying\nto live out his Personal Legend, and his enthusiasm during the time\nhe had worked at the crystal shop.\nAnd his heart told him something else that the boy had never\nnoticed: it told the boy of dangers that had threatened him, but that\nhe had never perceived. His heart said that one time it had hidden\nthe rifle the boy had taken from his father, because of the possibility\nthat the boy might wound himself. And it reminded the boy of the day\nwhen he had been ill and vomiting out in the fields, after which he"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 104, "chunk": 0, "text": "had fallen into a deep sleep. There had been two thieves farther\nahead who were planning to steal the boy\u2019s sheep and murder him.\nBut, since the boy hadn\u2019t passed by, they had decided to move on,\nthinking that he had changed his route.\n\u201cDoes a man\u2019s heart always help him?\u201d the boy asked the\nalchemist.\n\u201cMostly just the hearts of those who are trying to realize their\nPersonal Legends. But they do help children, drunkards, and the\nelderly, too.\u201d\n\u201cDoes that mean that I\u2019ll never run into danger?\u201d\n\u201cIt means only that the heart does what it can,\u201d the alchemist said.\nOne afternoon, they passed by the encampment of one of the\ntribes. At each corner of the camp were Arabs garbed in beautiful\nwhite robes, with arms at the ready. The men were smoking their\nhookahs and trading stories from the battlefield. No one paid any\nattention to the two travelers.\n\u201cThere\u2019s no danger,\u201d the boy said, when they had moved on past\nthe encampment.\nThe alchemist sounded angry: \u201cTrust in your heart, but never\nforget that you\u2019re in the desert. When men are at war with one\nanother, the Soul of the World can hear the screams of battle. No\none fails to suffer the consequences of everything under the sun.\u201d\nAll things are one, the boy thought. And then, as if the desert\nwanted to demonstrate that the alchemist was right, two horsemen\nappeared from behind the travelers.\n\u201cYou can\u2019t go any farther,\u201d one of them said. \u201cYou\u2019re in the area\nwhere the tribes are at war.\u201d\n\u201cI\u2019m not going very far,\u201d the alchemist answered, looking straight\ninto the eyes of the horsemen. They were silent for a moment, and\nthen agreed that the boy and the alchemist could move along.\nThe boy watched the exchange with fascination. \u201cYou dominated\nthose horsemen with the way you looked at them,\u201d he said.\n\u201cYour eyes show the strength of your soul,\u201d answered the\nalchemist.\nThat\u2019s true, the boy thought. He had noticed that, in the midst of\nthe multitude of armed men back at the encampment, there had\nbeen one who stared fixedly at the two. He had been so far away"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 105, "chunk": 0, "text": "that his face wasn\u2019t even visible. But the boy was certain that he had\nbeen looking at them.\nFinally, when they had crossed the mountain range that extended\nalong the entire horizon, the alchemist said that they were only two\ndays from the Pyramids.\n\u201cIf we\u2019re going to go our separate ways soon,\u201d the boy said, \u201cthen\nteach me about alchemy.\u201d\n\u201cYou already know about alchemy. It is about penetrating to the\nSoul of the World, and discovering the treasure that has been\nreserved for you.\u201d\n\u201cNo, that\u2019s not what I mean. I\u2019m talking about transforming lead\ninto gold.\u201d\nThe alchemist fell as silent as the desert, and answered the boy\nonly after they had stopped to eat.\n\u201cEverything in the universe evolved,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd, for wise men,\ngold is the metal that evolved the furthest. Don\u2019t ask me why; I don\u2019t\nknow why. I just know that the Tradition is always right.\n\u201cMen have never understood the words of the wise. So gold,\ninstead of being seen as a symbol of evolution, became the basis for\nconflict.\u201d\n\u201cThere are many languages spoken by things,\u201d the boy said.\n\u201cThere was a time when, for me, a camel\u2019s whinnying was nothing\nmore than whinnying. Then it became a signal of danger. And, finally,\nit became just a whinny again.\u201d\nBut then he stopped. The alchemist probably already knew all\nthat.\n\u201cI have known true alchemists,\u201d the alchemist continued. \u201cThey\nlocked themselves in their laboratories, and tried to evolve, as gold\nhad. And they found the Philosopher\u2019s Stone, because they\nunderstood that when something evolves, everything around that\nthing evolves as well.\n\u201cOthers stumbled upon the stone by accident. They already had\nthe gift, and their souls were readier for such things than the souls of\nothers. But they don\u2019t count. They\u2019re quite rare.\n\u201cAnd then there were the others, who were interested only in gold.\nThey never found the secret. They forgot that lead, copper, and iron\nhave their own Personal Legends to fulfill. And anyone who"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 106, "chunk": 0, "text": "interferes with the Personal Legend of another thing never will\ndiscover his own.\u201d\nThe alchemist\u2019s words echoed out like a curse. He reached over\nand picked up a shell from the ground.\n\u201cThis desert was once a sea,\u201d he said.\n\u201cI noticed that,\u201d the boy answered.\nThe alchemist told the boy to place the shell over his ear. He had\ndone that many times when he was a child, and had heard the sound\nof the sea.\n\u201cThe sea has lived on in this shell, because that\u2019s its Personal\nLegend. And it will never cease doing so until the desert is once\nagain covered by water.\u201d\nThey mounted their horses, and rode out in the direction of the\nPyramids of Egypt.\nThe sun was setting when the boy\u2019s heart sounded a danger signal.\nThey were surrounded by gigantic dunes, and the boy looked at the\nalchemist to see whether he had sensed anything. But he appeared\nto be unaware of any danger. Five minutes later, the boy saw two\nhorsemen waiting ahead of them. Before he could say anything to\nthe alchemist, the two horsemen had become ten, and then a\nhundred. And then they were everywhere in the dunes.\nThey were tribesmen dressed in blue, with black rings surrounding\ntheir turbans. Their faces were hidden behind blue veils, with only\ntheir eyes showing.\nEven from a distance, their eyes conveyed the strength of their\nsouls. And their eyes spoke of death.\n"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 107, "chunk": 0, "text": "The two were taken to a nearby military camp. A soldier shoved the\nboy and the alchemist into a tent where the chief was holding a\nmeeting with his staff.\n\u201cThese are the spies,\u201d said one of the men.\n\u201cWe\u2019re just travelers,\u201d the alchemist answered.\n\u201cYou were seen at the enemy camp three days ago. And you were\ntalking with one of the troops there.\u201d\n\u201cI\u2019m just a man who wanders the desert and knows the stars,\u201d said\nthe alchemist. \u201cI have no information about troops or about the\nmovement of the tribes. I was simply acting as a guide for my friend\nhere.\u201d\n\u201cWho is your friend?\u201d the chief asked.\n\u201cAn alchemist,\u201d said the alchemist. \u201cHe understands the forces of\nnature. And he wants to show you his extraordinary powers.\u201d\nThe boy listened quietly. And fearfully.\n\u201cWhat is a foreigner doing here?\u201d asked another of the men.\n\u201cHe has brought money to give to your tribe,\u201d said the alchemist,\nbefore the boy could say a word. And seizing the boy\u2019s bag, the\nalchemist gave the gold coins to the chief.\nThe Arab accepted them without a word. There was enough there\nto buy a lot of weapons.\n\u201cWhat is an alchemist?\u201d he asked, finally.\n\u201cIt\u2019s a man who understands nature and the world. If he wanted to,\nhe could destroy this camp just with the force of the wind.\u201d\nThe men laughed. They were used to the ravages of war, and\nknew that the wind could not deliver them a fatal blow. Yet each felt\nhis heart beat a bit faster. They were men of the desert, and they\nwere fearful of sorcerers.\n\u201cI want to see him do it,\u201d said the chief.\n\u201cHe needs three days,\u201d answered the alchemist. \u201cHe is going to\ntransform himself into the wind, just to demonstrate his powers. If he\ncan\u2019t do so, we humbly offer you our lives, for the honor of your\ntribe.\u201d\n\u201cYou can\u2019t offer me something that is already mine,\u201d the chief said,\narrogantly. But he granted the travelers three days.\nThe boy was shaking with fear, but the alchemist helped him out\nof the tent."}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 108, "chunk": 0, "text": "\u201cDon\u2019t let them see that you\u2019re afraid,\u201d the alchemist said. \u201cThey\nare brave men, and they despise cowards.\u201d\nBut the boy couldn\u2019t even speak. He was able to do so only after\nthey had walked through the center of the camp. There was no need\nto imprison them: the Arabs simply confiscated their horses. So,\nonce again, the world had demonstrated its many languages: the\ndesert only moments ago had been endless and free, and now it was\nan impenetrable wall.\n\u201cYou gave them everything I had!\u201d the boy said. \u201cEverything I\u2019ve\nsaved in my entire life!\u201d\n\u201cWell, what good would it be to you if you had to die?\u201d the\nalchemist answered. \u201cYour money saved us for three days. It\u2019s not\noften that money saves a person\u2019s life.\u201d\nBut the boy was too frightened to listen to words of wisdom. He\nhad no idea how he was going to transform himself into the wind. He\nwasn\u2019t an alchemist!\nThe alchemist asked one of the soldiers for some tea, and poured\nsome on the boy\u2019s wrists. A wave of relief washed over him, and the\nalchemist muttered some words that the boy didn\u2019t understand.\n\u201cDon\u2019t give in to your fears,\u201d said the alchemist, in a strangely\ngentle voice. \u201cIf you do, you won\u2019t be able to talk to your heart.\u201d\n\u201cBut I have no idea how to turn myself into the wind.\u201d\n\u201cIf a person is living out his Personal Legend, he knows everything\nhe needs to know. There is only one thing that makes a dream\nimpossible to achieve: the fear of failure.\u201d\n\u201cI\u2019m not afraid of failing. It\u2019s just that I don\u2019t know how to turn\nmyself into the wind.\u201d\n\u201cWell, you\u2019ll have to learn; your life depends on it.\u201d\n\u201cBut what if I can\u2019t?\u201d\n\u201cThen you\u2019ll die in the midst of trying to realize your Personal\nLegend. That\u2019s a lot better than dying like millions of other people,\nwho never even knew what their Personal Legends were.\n\u201cBut don\u2019t worry,\u201d the alchemist continued. \u201cUsually the threat of\ndeath makes people a lot more aware of their lives.\u201d\n"}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 109, "chunk": 0, "text": "The first day passed. There was a major battle nearby, and a\nnumber of wounded were brought back to the camp. The dead\nsoldiers were replaced by others, and life went on. Death doesn\u2019t\nchange anything, the boy thought.\n\u201cYou could have died later on,\u201d a soldier said to the body of one of\nhis companions. \u201cYou could have died after peace had been\ndeclared. But, in any case, you were going to die.\u201d\nAt the end of the day, the boy went looking for the alchemist, who\nhad taken his falcon out into the desert.\n\u201cI still have no idea how to turn myself into the wind,\u201d the boy\nrepeated.\n\u201cRemember what I told you: the world is only the visible aspect of\nGod. And that what alchemy does is to bring spiritual perfection into\ncontact with the material plane.\u201d\n\u201cWhat are you doing?\u201d\n\u201cFeeding my falcon.\u201d\n\u201cIf I\u2019m not able to turn myself into the wind, we\u2019re going to die,\u201d the\nboy said. \u201cWhy feed your falcon?\u201d\n\u201cYou\u2019re the one who may die,\u201d the alchemist said. \u201cI already know\nhow to turn myself into the wind.\u201d\nOn the second day, the boy climbed to the top of a cliff near the\ncamp. The sentinels allowed him to go; they had already heard\nabout the sorcerer who could turn himself into the wind, and they\ndidn\u2019t want to go near him. In any case, the desert was impassable.\nHe spent the entire afternoon of the second day looking out over\nthe desert, and listening to his heart. The boy knew the desert\nsensed his fear.\nThey both spoke the same language.\nOn the third day, the chief met with his officers. He called the\nalchemist to the meeting and said, \u201cLet\u2019s go see the boy who turns\nhimself into the wind.\u201d\n\u201cLet\u2019s,\u201d the alchemist answered."}
