{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 110, "chunk": 0, "text": "The boy took them to the cliff where he had been on the previous\nday. He told them all to be seated.\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to take awhile,\u201d the boy said.\n\u201cWe\u2019re in no hurry,\u201d the chief answered. \u201cWe are men of the\ndesert.\u201d\nThe boy looked out at the horizon. There were mountains in the\ndistance. And there were dunes, rocks, and plants that insisted on\nliving where survival seemed impossible. There was the desert that\nhe had wandered for so many months; despite all that time, he knew\nonly a small part of it. Within that small part, he had found an\nEnglishman, caravans, tribal wars, and an oasis with fifty thousand\npalm trees and three hundred wells.\n\u201cWhat do you want here today?\u201d the desert asked him. \u201cDidn\u2019t you\nspend enough time looking at me yesterday?\u201d\n\u201cSomewhere you are holding the person I love,\u201d the boy said. \u201cSo,\nwhen I look out over your sands, I am also looking at her. I want to\nreturn to her, and I need your help so that I can turn myself into the\nwind.\u201d\n\u201cWhat is love?\u201d the desert asked.\n\u201cLove is the falcon\u2019s flight over your sands. Because for him, you\nare a green field, from which he always returns with game. He knows\nyour rocks, your dunes, and your mountains, and you are generous\nto him.\u201d\n\u201cThe falcon\u2019s beak carries bits of me, myself,\u201d the desert said. \u201cFor\nyears, I care for his game, feeding it with the little water that I have,\nand then I show him where the game is. And, one day, as I enjoy the\nfact that his game thrives on my surface, the falcon dives out of the\nsky, and takes away what I\u2019ve created.\u201d"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 111, "chunk": 0, "text": "\u201cBut that\u2019s why you created the game in the first place,\u201d the boy\nanswered. \u201cTo nourish the falcon. And the falcon then nourishes\nman. And, eventually, man will nourish your sands, where the game\nwill once again flourish. That\u2019s how the world goes.\u201d\n\u201cSo is that what love is?\u201d\n\u201cYes, that\u2019s what love is. It\u2019s what makes the game become the\nfalcon, the falcon become man, and man, in his turn, the desert. It\u2019s\nwhat turns lead into gold, and makes the gold return to the earth.\u201d\n\u201cI don\u2019t understand what you\u2019re talking about,\u201d the desert said.\n\u201cBut you can at least understand that somewhere in your sands\nthere is a woman waiting for me. And that\u2019s why I have to turn myself\ninto the wind.\u201d\nThe desert didn\u2019t answer him for a few moments.\nThen it told him, \u201cI\u2019ll give you my sands to help the wind to blow,\nbut, alone, I can\u2019t do anything. You have to ask for help from the\nwind.\u201d\nA breeze began to blow. The tribesmen watched the boy from a\ndistance, talking among themselves in a language that the boy\ncouldn\u2019t understand.\nThe alchemist smiled.\nThe wind approached the boy and touched his face. It knew of the\nboy\u2019s talk with the desert, because the winds know everything. They\nblow across the world without a birthplace, and with no place to die.\n\u201cHelp me,\u201d the boy said. \u201cOne day you carried the voice of my\nloved one to me.\u201d\n\u201cWho taught you to speak the language of the desert and the\nwind?\u201d\n\u201cMy heart,\u201d the boy answered.\nThe wind has many names. In that part of the world, it was called\nthe sirocco, because it brought moisture from the oceans to the east.\nIn the distant land the boy came from, they called it the levanter,\nbecause they believed that it brought with it the sands of the desert,\nand the screams of the Moorish wars. Perhaps, in the places beyond\nthe pastures where his sheep lived, men thought that the wind came\nfrom Andalusia. But, actually, the wind came from no place at all, nor\ndid it go to any place; that\u2019s why it was stronger than the desert."}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 112, "chunk": 0, "text": "Someone might one day plant trees in the desert, and even raise\nsheep there, but never would they harness the wind.\n\u201cYou can\u2019t be the wind,\u201d the wind said. \u201cWe\u2019re two very different\nthings.\u201d\n\u201cThat\u2019s not true,\u201d the boy said. \u201cI learned the alchemist\u2019s secrets in\nmy travels. I have inside me the winds, the deserts, the oceans, the\nstars, and everything created in the universe. We were all made by\nthe same hand, and we have the same soul. I want to be like you,\nable to reach every corner of the world, cross the seas, blow away\nthe sands that cover my treasure, and carry the voice of the woman I\nlove.\u201d\n\u201cI heard what you were talking about the other day with the\nalchemist,\u201d the wind said. \u201cHe said that everything has its own\nPersonal Legend. But people can\u2019t turn themselves into the wind.\u201d\n\u201cJust teach me to be the wind for a few moments,\u201d the boy said.\n\u201cSo you and I can talk about the limitless possibilities of people and\nthe winds.\u201d\nThe wind\u2019s curiosity was aroused, something that had never\nhappened before. It wanted to talk about those things, but it didn\u2019t\nknow how to turn a man into the wind. And look how many things the\nwind already knew how to do! It created deserts, sank ships, felled\nentire forests, and blew through cities filled with music and strange\nnoises. It felt that it had no limits, yet here was a boy saying that\nthere were other things the wind should be able to do.\n\u201cThis is what we call love,\u201d the boy said, seeing that the wind was\nclose to granting what he requested. \u201cWhen you are loved, you can\ndo anything in creation. When you are loved, there\u2019s no need at all to\nunderstand what\u2019s happening, because everything happens within\nyou, and even men can turn themselves into the wind. As long as the\nwind helps, of course.\u201d\nThe wind was a proud being, and it was becoming irritated with\nwhat the boy was saying. It commenced to blow harder, raising the\ndesert sands. But finally it had to recognize that, even making its\nway around the world, it didn\u2019t know how to turn a man into the wind.\nAnd it knew nothing about love.\n\u201cIn my travels around the world, I"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 112, "chunk": 1, "text": "\u2019ve often seen people speaking\nof love and looking toward the heavens,\u201d the wind said, furious at"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 113, "chunk": 0, "text": "having to acknowledge its own limitations. \u201cMaybe it\u2019s better to ask\nheaven.\u201d\n\u201cWell then, help me do that,\u201d the boy said. \u201cFill this place with a\nsandstorm so strong that it blots out the sun. Then I can look to\nheaven without blinding myself.\u201d\nSo the wind blew with all its strength, and the sky was filled with\nsand. The sun was turned into a golden disk.\nAt the camp, it was difficult to see anything. The men of the desert\nwere already familiar with that wind. They called it the simum, and it\nwas worse than a storm at sea. Their horses cried out, and all their\nweapons were filled with sand.\nOn the heights, one of the commanders turned to the chief and\nsaid, \u201cMaybe we had better end this!\u201d\nThey could barely see the boy. Their faces were covered with the\nblue cloths, and their eyes showed fear.\n\u201cLet\u2019s stop this,\u201d another commander said.\n\u201cI want to see the greatness of Allah,\u201d the chief said, with respect.\n\u201cI want to see how a man turns himself into the wind.\u201d\nBut he made a mental note of the names of the two men who had\nexpressed their fear. As soon as the wind stopped, he was going to\nremove them from their commands, because true men of the desert\nare not afraid.\n\u201cThe wind told me that you know about love,\u201d the boy said to the\nsun. \u201cIf you know about love, you must also know about the Soul of\nthe World, because it\u2019s made of love.\u201d\n\u201cFrom where I am,\u201d the sun said, \u201cI can see the Soul of the World.\nIt communicates with my soul, and together we cause the plants to\ngrow and the sheep to seek out shade. From where I am\u2014and I\u2019m a\nlong way from the earth\u2014I learned how to love. I know that if I came\neven a little bit closer to the earth, everything there would die, and\nthe Soul of the World would no longer exist. So we contemplate each\nother, and we want each other, and I give it life and warmth, and it\ngives me my reason for living.\u201d\n\u201cSo you know about love,\u201d the boy said.\n\u201cAnd I know the Soul of the World, because we have talked at\ngreat length to each other during this endless trip through the\nuniverse. It tells me that"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 113, "chunk": 1, "text": " its greatest problem is that, up until now,"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 114, "chunk": 0, "text": "only the minerals and vegetables understand that all things are one.\nThat there\u2019s no need for iron to be the same as copper, or copper the\nsame as gold. Each performs its own exact function as a unique\nbeing, and everything would be a symphony of peace if the hand that\nwrote all this had stopped on the fifth day of creation.\n\u201cBut there was a sixth day,\u201d the sun went on.\n\u201cYou are wise, because you observe everything from a distance,\u201d\nthe boy said. \u201cBut you don\u2019t know about love. If there hadn\u2019t been a\nsixth day, man would not exist; copper would always be just copper,\nand lead just lead. It\u2019s true that everything has its Personal Legend,\nbut one day that Personal Legend will be realized. So each thing has\nto transform itself into something better, and to acquire a new\nPersonal Legend, until, someday, the Soul of the World becomes\none thing only.\u201d\nThe sun thought about that, and decided to shine more brightly.\nThe wind, which was enjoying the conversation, started to blow with\ngreater force, so that the sun would not blind the boy.\n\u201cThis is why alchemy exists,\u201d the boy said. \u201cSo that everyone will\nsearch for his treasure, find it, and then want to be better than he\nwas in his former life. Lead will play its role until the world has no\nfurther need for lead; and then lead will have to turn itself into gold.\n\u201cThat\u2019s what alchemists do. They show that, when we strive to\nbecome better than we are, everything around us becomes better,\ntoo.\u201d\n\u201cWell, why did you say that I don\u2019t know about love?\u201d the sun\nasked the boy.\n\u201cBecause it\u2019s not love to be static like the desert, nor is it love to\nroam the world like the wind. And it\u2019s not love to see everything from\na distance, like you do. Love is the force that transforms and\nimproves the Soul of the World. When I first reached through to it, I\nthought the Soul of the World was perfect. But later, I could see that\nit was like other aspects of creation, and had its own passions and\nwars. It is we who nourish the Soul of the World, and the world we\nlive in will be either better or worse, depending on whether we\nbecome better or worse."}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 114, "chunk": 1, "text": " And that\u2019s where the power of love comes\nin. Because when we love, we always strive to become better than\nwe are.\u201d"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 115, "chunk": 0, "text": "\u201cSo what do you want of me?\u201d the sun asked.\n\u201cI want you to help me turn myself into the wind,\u201d the boy\nanswered.\n\u201cNature knows me as the wisest being in creation,\u201d the sun said.\n\u201cBut I don\u2019t know how to turn you into the wind.\u201d\n\u201cThen, whom should I ask?\u201d\nThe sun thought for a minute. The wind was listening closely, and\nwanted to tell every corner of the world that the sun\u2019s wisdom had its\nlimitations. That it was unable to deal with this boy who spoke the\nLanguage of the World.\n\u201cSpeak to the hand that wrote all,\u201d said the sun.\nThe wind screamed with delight, and blew harder than ever. The\ntents were being blown from their ties to the earth, and the animals\nwere being freed from their tethers. On the cliff, the men clutched at\neach other as they sought to keep from being blown away.\nThe boy turned to the hand that wrote all. As he did so, he sensed\nthat the universe had fallen silent, and he decided not to speak.\nA current of love rushed from his heart, and the boy began to\npray. It was a prayer that he had never said before, because it was a\nprayer without words or pleas. His prayer didn\u2019t give thanks for his\nsheep having found new pastures; it didn\u2019t ask that the boy be able\nto sell more crystal; and it didn\u2019t beseech that the woman he had met\ncontinue to await his return. In the silence, the boy understood that\nthe desert, the wind, and the sun were also trying to understand the\nsigns written by the hand, and were seeking to follow their paths,\nand to understand what had been written on a single emerald. He\nsaw that omens were scattered throughout the earth and in space,\nand that there was no reason or significance attached to their\nappearance; he could see that not the deserts, nor the winds, nor the\nsun, nor people knew why they had been created. But that the hand\nhad a reason for all of this, and that only the hand could perform\nmiracles, or transform the sea into a desert . . . or a man into the\nwind. Because only the hand understood that it was a larger design\nthat had moved the universe to the point at which six days of\ncreation had evolved into a"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 115, "chunk": 1, "text": " Master Work.\nThe boy reached through to the Soul of the World, and saw that it\nwas a part of the Soul of God. And he saw that the Soul of God was"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 116, "chunk": 0, "text": "his own soul. And that he, a boy, could perform miracles.\nThe simum blew that day as it had never blown before. For\ngenerations thereafter, the Arabs recounted the legend of a boy who\nhad turned himself into the wind, almost destroying a military camp,\nin defiance of the most powerful chief in the desert.\nWhen the simum ceased to blow, everyone looked to the place\nwhere the boy had been. But he was no longer there; he was\nstanding next to a sand-covered sentinel, on the far side of the\ncamp.\nThe men were terrified at his sorcery. But there were two people\nwho were smiling: the alchemist, because he had found his perfect\ndisciple, and the chief, because that disciple had understood the\nglory of God.\nThe following day, the general bade the boy and the alchemist\nfarewell, and provided them with an escort party to accompany them\nas far as they chose.\nThey rode for the entire day. Toward the end of the afternoon, they\ncame upon a Coptic monastery. The alchemist dismounted, and told\nthe escorts they could return to the camp.\n\u201cFrom here on, you will be alone,\u201d the alchemist said. \u201cYou are\nonly three hours from the Pyramids.\u201d\n\u201cThank you,\u201d said the boy. \u201cYou taught me the Language of the\nWorld.\u201d\n\u201cI only invoked what you already knew.\u201d"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 117, "chunk": 0, "text": "The alchemist knocked on the gate of the monastery. A monk\ndressed in black came to the gates. They spoke for a few minutes in\nthe Coptic tongue, and the alchemist bade the boy enter.\n\u201cI asked him to let me use the kitchen for a while,\u201d the alchemist\nsmiled.\nThey went to the kitchen at the back of the monastery. The\nalchemist lighted the fire, and the monk brought him some lead,\nwhich the alchemist placed in an iron pan. When the lead had\nbecome liquid, the alchemist took from his pouch the strange yellow\negg. He scraped from it a sliver as thin as a hair, wrapped it in wax,\nand added it to the pan in which the lead had melted.\nThe mixture took on a reddish color, almost the color of blood. The\nalchemist removed the pan from the fire, and set it aside to cool. As\nhe did so, he talked with the monk about the tribal wars.\n\u201cI think they\u2019re going to last for a long time,\u201d he said to the monk.\nThe monk was irritated. The caravans had been stopped at Giza\nfor some time, waiting for the wars to end. \u201cBut God\u2019s will be done,\u201d\nthe monk said.\n\u201cExactly,\u201d answered the alchemist.\nWhen the pan had cooled, the monk and the boy looked at it,\ndazzled. The lead had dried into the shape of the pan, but it was no\nlonger lead. It was gold.\n\u201cWill I learn to do that someday?\u201d the boy asked.\n\u201cThis was my Personal Legend, not yours,\u201d the alchemist\nanswered. \u201cBut I wanted to show you that it was possible.\u201d\nThey returned to the gates of the monastery. There, the alchemist\nseparated the disk into four parts."}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 118, "chunk": 0, "text": "\u201cThis is for you,\u201d he said, holding one of the parts out to the monk.\n\u201cIt\u2019s for your generosity to the pilgrims.\u201d\n\u201cBut this payment goes well beyond my generosity,\u201d the monk\nresponded.\n\u201cDon\u2019t say that again. Life might be listening, and give you less the\nnext time.\u201d\nThe alchemist turned to the boy. \u201cThis is for you. To make up for\nwhat you gave to the general.\u201d\nThe boy was about to say that it was much more than he had\ngiven the general. But he kept quiet, because he had heard what the\nalchemist said to the monk.\n\u201cAnd this is for me,\u201d said the alchemist, keeping one of the parts.\n\u201cBecause I have to return to the desert, where there are tribal wars.\u201d\nHe took the fourth part and handed it to the monk.\n\u201cThis is for the boy. If he ever needs it.\u201d\n\u201cBut I\u2019m going in search of my treasure,\u201d the boy said. \u201cI\u2019m very\nclose to it now.\u201d\n\u201cAnd I\u2019m certain you\u2019ll find it,\u201d the alchemist said.\n\u201cThen why this?\u201d\n\u201cBecause you have already lost your savings twice. Once to the\nthief, and once to the general. I\u2019m an old, superstitious Arab, and I\nbelieve in our proverbs. There\u2019s one that says, \u2018Everything that\nhappens once can never happen again. But everything that happens\ntwice will surely happen a third time.\u2019\u201d They mounted their horses.\n\u201cI want to tell you a story about dreams,\u201d said the alchemist.\nThe boy brought his horse closer.\n\u201cIn ancient Rome, at the time of Emperor Tiberius, there lived a\ngood man who had two sons. One was in the military, and had been\nsent to the most distant regions of the empire. The other son was a\npoet, and delighted all of Rome with his beautiful verses.\n\u201cOne night, the father had a dream. An angel appeared to him,\nand told him that the words of one of his sons would be learned and\nrepeated throughout the world for all generations to come. The father\nwoke from his dream grateful and crying, because life was generous,"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 119, "chunk": 0, "text": "and had revealed to him something any father would be proud to\nknow.\n\u201cShortly thereafter, the father died as he tried to save a child who\nwas about to be crushed by the wheels of a chariot. Since he had\nlived his entire life in a manner that was correct and fair, he went\ndirectly to heaven, where he met the angel that had appeared in his\ndream.\n\u201c\u2018You were always a good man,\u2019 the angel said to him. \u2018You lived\nyour life in a loving way, and died with dignity. I can now grant you\nany wish you desire.\u2019\n\u201c\u2018Life was good to me,\u2019 the man said. \u2018When you appeared in my\ndream, I felt that all my efforts had been rewarded, because my\nson\u2019s poems will be read by men for generations to come. I don\u2019t\nwant anything for myself. But any father would be proud of the fame\nachieved by one whom he had cared for as a child, and educated as\nhe grew up. Sometime in the distant future, I would like to see my\nson\u2019s words.\u2019\n\u201cThe angel touched the man\u2019s shoulder, and they were both\nprojected far into the future. They were in an immense setting,\nsurrounded by thousands of people speaking a strange language.\n\u201cThe man wept with happiness.\n\u201c\u2018I knew that my son\u2019s poems were immortal,\u2019 he said to the angel\nthrough his tears. \u2018Can you please tell me which of my son\u2019s poems\nthese people are repeating?\u2019\n\u201cThe angel came closer to the man, and, with tenderness, led him\nto a bench nearby, where they sat down.\n\u201c\u2018The verses of your son who was the poet were very popular in\nRome,\u2019 the angel said. \u2018Everyone loved them and enjoyed them. But\nwhen the reign of Tiberius ended, his poems were forgotten. The\nwords you\u2019re hearing now are those of your son in the military.\u2019\n\u201cThe man looked at the angel in surprise.\n\u201c\u2018Your son went to serve at a distant place, and became a\ncenturion. He was just and good. One afternoon, one of his servants\nfell ill, and it appeared that he would die. Your son had heard of a\nrabbi who was able to cure illnesses, and he rode out for days and\ndays in search of this man. Along the way, he learned"}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 119, "chunk": 1, "text": " that the man\nhe was seeking was the Son of God. He met others who had been"}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 120, "chunk": 0, "text": "cured by him, and they instructed your son in the man\u2019s teachings.\nAnd so, despite the fact that he was a Roman centurion, he\nconverted to their faith. Shortly thereafter, he reached the place\nwhere the man he was looking for was visiting.\u2019\n\u201c\u2018He told the man that one of his servants was gravely ill, and the\nrabbi made ready to go to his house with him. But the centurion was\na man of faith, and, looking into the eyes of the rabbi, he knew that\nhe was surely in the presence of the Son of God.\u2019\n\u201c\u2018And this is what your son said,\u2019 the angel told the man. \u2018These\nare the words he said to the rabbi at that point, and they have never\nbeen forgotten: \u201cMy Lord, I am not worthy that you should come\nunder my roof. But only speak a word and my servant will be\nhealed.\u201d \u2019\u201d\nThe alchemist said, \u201cNo matter what he does, every person on\nearth plays a central role in the history of the world. And normally he\ndoesn\u2019t know it.\u201d\nThe boy smiled. He had never imagined that questions about life\nwould be of such importance to a shepherd.\n\u201cGood-bye,\u201d the alchemist said.\n\u201cGood-bye,\u201d said the boy.\nThe boy rode along through the desert for several hours, listening\navidly to what his heart had to say. It was his heart that would tell\nhim where his treasure was hidden.\n\u201cWhere your treasure is, there also will be your heart,\u201d the\nalchemist had told him.\nBut his heart was speaking of other things. With pride, it told the\nstory of a shepherd who had left his flock to follow a dream he had\non two different occasions. It told of Personal Legend, and of the\nmany men who had wandered in search of distant lands or beautiful\nwomen, confronting the people of their times with their preconceived\nnotions. It spoke of journeys, discoveries, books, and change.\nAs he was about to climb yet another dune, his heart whispered,\n\u201cBe aware of the place where you are brought to tears. That\u2019s where\nI am, and that\u2019s where your treasure is.\u201d"}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 121, "chunk": 0, "text": "The boy climbed the dune slowly. A full moon rose again in the\nstarry sky: it had been a month since he had set forth from the oasis.\nThe moonlight cast shadows through the dunes, creating the\nappearance of a rolling sea; it reminded the boy of the day when that\nhorse had reared in the desert, and he had come to know the\nalchemist. And the moon fell on the desert\u2019s silence, and on a man\u2019s\njourney in search of treasure.\nWhen he reached the top of the dune, his heart leapt. There,\nilluminated by the light of the moon and the brightness of the desert,\nstood the solemn and majestic Pyramids of Egypt.\nThe boy fell to his knees and wept. He thanked God for making\nhim believe in his Personal Legend, and for leading him to meet a\nking, a merchant, an Englishman, and an alchemist. And above all\nfor his having met a woman of the desert who had told him that love\nwould never keep a man from his Personal Legend.\nIf he wanted to, he could now return to the oasis, go back to\nFatima, and live his life as a simple shepherd. After all, the alchemist\ncontinued to live in the desert, even though he understood the\nLanguage of the World, and knew how to transform lead into gold.\nHe didn\u2019t need to demonstrate his science and art to anyone. The\nboy told himself that, on the way toward realizing his own Personal\nLegend, he had learned all he needed to know, and had experienced\neverything he might have dreamed of.\nBut here he was, at the point of finding his treasure, and he\nreminded himself that no project is completed until its objective has\nbeen achieved. The boy looked at the sands around him, and saw\nthat, where his tears had fallen, a scarab beetle was scuttling\nthrough the sand. During his time in the desert, he had learned that,\nin Egypt, the scarab beetles are a symbol of God.\nAnother omen! The boy began to dig into the dune. As he did so,\nhe thought of what the crystal merchant had once said: that anyone"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 122, "chunk": 0, "text": "could build a pyramid in his backyard. The boy could see now that\nhe couldn\u2019t do so if he placed stone upon stone for the rest of his life.\nThroughout the night, the boy dug at the place he had chosen, but\nfound nothing. He felt weighted down by the centuries of time since\nthe Pyramids had been built. But he didn\u2019t stop. He struggled to\ncontinue digging as he fought the wind, which often blew the sand\nback into the excavation. His hands were abraded and exhausted,\nbut he listened to his heart. It had told him to dig where his tears fell.\nAs he was attempting to pull out the rocks he encountered, he\nheard footsteps. Several figures approached him. Their backs were\nto the moonlight, and the boy could see neither their eyes nor their\nfaces.\n\u201cWhat are you doing here?\u201d one of the figures demanded.\nBecause he was terrified, the boy didn\u2019t answer. He had found\nwhere his treasure was, and was frightened at what might happen.\n\u201cWe\u2019re refugees from the tribal wars, and we need money,\u201d the\nother figure said. \u201cWhat are you hiding there?\u201d\n\u201cI\u2019m not hiding anything,\u201d the boy answered.\nBut one of them seized the boy and yanked him back out of the\nhole. Another, who was searching the boy\u2019s bags, found the piece of\ngold.\n\u201cThere\u2019s gold here,\u201d he said.\nThe moon shone on the face of the Arab who had seized him, and\nin the man\u2019s eyes the boy saw death.\n\u201cHe\u2019s probably got more gold hidden in the ground.\u201d\nThey made the boy continue digging, but he found nothing. As the\nsun rose, the men began to beat the boy. He was bruised and\nbleeding, his clothing was torn to shreds, and he felt that death was\nnear.\n\u201cWhat good is money to you if you\u2019re going to die? It\u2019s not often\nthat money can save someone\u2019s life,\u201d the alchemist had said. Finally,\nthe boy screamed at the men, \u201cI\u2019m digging for treasure!\u201d And,\nalthough his mouth was bleeding and swollen, he told his attackers\nthat he had twice dreamed of a treasure hidden near the Pyramids of\nEgypt.\nThe man who appeared to be the leader of the group spoke to\none of the others: \u201cLeave him. He doesn\u2019t have anything else. He"}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 123, "chunk": 0, "text": "must have stolen this gold.\u201d\nThe boy fell to the sand, nearly unconscious. The leader shook\nhim and said, \u201cWe\u2019re leaving.\u201d\nBut before they left, he came back to the boy and said, \u201cYou\u2019re not\ngoing to die. You\u2019ll live, and you\u2019ll learn that a man shouldn\u2019t be so\nstupid. Two years ago, right here on this spot, I had a recurrent\ndream, too. I dreamed that I should travel to the fields of Spain and\nlook for a ruined church where shepherds and their sheep slept. In\nmy dream, there was a sycamore growing out of the ruins of the\nsacristy, and I was told that, if I dug at the roots of the sycamore, I\nwould find a hidden treasure. But I\u2019m not so stupid as to cross an\nentire desert just because of a recurrent dream.\u201d\nAnd they disappeared.\nThe boy stood up shakily, and looked once more at the Pyramids.\nThey seemed to laugh at him, and he laughed back, his heart\nbursting with joy.\nBecause now he knew where his treasure was."}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 124, "chunk": 0, "text": "Epilogue\nThe boy reached the small, abandoned church just as night was\nfalling. The sycamore was still there in the sacristy, and the stars\ncould still be seen through the half-destroyed roof. He remembered\nthe time he had been there with his sheep; it had been a peaceful\nnight . . . except for the dream.\nNow he was here not with his flock, but with a shovel.\nHe sat looking at the sky for a long time. Then he took from his\nknapsack a bottle of wine, and drank some. He remembered the\nnight in the desert when he had sat with the alchemist, as they\nlooked at the stars and drank wine together. He thought of the many\nroads he had traveled, and of the strange way God had chosen to\nshow him his treasure. If he hadn\u2019t believed in the significance of\nrecurrent dreams, he would not have met the Gypsy woman, the\nking, the thief, or . . . \u201cWell, it\u2019s a long list. But the path was written in\nthe omens, and there was no way I could go wrong,\u201d he said to\nhimself.\nHe fell asleep, and when he awoke the sun was already high. He\nbegan to dig at the base of the sycamore.\n\u201cYou old sorcerer,\u201d the boy shouted up to the sky. \u201cYou knew the\nwhole story. You even left a bit of gold at the monastery so I could\nget back to this church. The monk laughed when he saw me come\nback in tatters. Couldn\u2019t you have saved me from that?\u201d\n\u201cNo,\u201d he heard a voice on the wind say. \u201cIf I had told you, you\nwouldn\u2019t have seen the Pyramids. They\u2019re beautiful, aren\u2019t they?\u201d\nThe boy smiled, and continued digging. Half an hour later, his\nshovel hit something solid. An hour later, he had before him a chest\nof Spanish gold coins. There were also precious stones, gold masks\nadorned with red and white feathers, and stone statues embedded\nwith jewels. The spoils of a conquest that the country had long ago"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 125, "chunk": 0, "text": "forgotten, and that some conquistador had failed to tell his children\nabout.\nThe boy took out Urim and Thummim from his bag. He had used\nthe two stones only once, one morning when he was at a\nmarketplace. His life and his path had always provided him with\nenough omens.\nHe placed Urim and Thummim in the chest. They were also a part\nof his new treasure, because they were a reminder of the old king,\nwhom he would never see again.\nIt\u2019s true; life really is generous to those who pursue their Personal\nLegend, the boy thought. Then he remembered that he had to get to\nTarifa so he could give one-tenth of his treasure to the Gypsy\nwoman, as he had promised. Those Gypsies are really smart, he\nthought. Maybe it was because they moved around so much.\nThe wind began to blow again. It was the levanter, the wind that\ncame from Africa. It didn\u2019t bring with it the smell of the desert, nor the\nthreat of Moorish invasion. Instead, it brought the scent of a perfume\nhe knew well, and the touch of a kiss\u2014a kiss that came from far\naway, slowly, slowly, until it rested on his lips.\nThe boy smiled. It was the first time she had done that.\n\u201cI\u2019m coming, Fatima,\u201d he said.\n"}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 126, "chunk": 0, "text": "An inspirational companion to The Alchemist that invites us to live\nout our dreams, to embrace the uncertainty of life, and to rise to\nmeet our own unique destiny. In his inimitable style, Paulo Coelho\npresents a collection of philosophical stories that will delight and\nguide seekers everywhere and help bring out the Warrior of Light\nwithin each of us."}

{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 127, "chunk": 0, "text": "Warrior of the Light\nPROLOGUE\n\u201cJust off the beach to the west of the village lies an island, and on it\nis a vast temple with many bells,\u201d said the woman.\nThe boy noticed that she was dressed strangely and had a veil\ncovering her head. He had never seen her before.\n\u201cHave you ever visited that temple?\u201d she asked. \u201cGo there and tell\nme what you think of it?\u201d\nSeduced by the woman\u2019s beauty, the boy went to the place she\nhad indicated. He sat down on the beach and stared out at the\nhorizon, but he saw only what he always saw: blue sky and ocean.\nDisappointed, he walked to a nearby fishing village and asked if\nanyone there knew about an island and a temple.\n\u201cOh, that was many years ago, when my great-grandparents were\nalive,\u201d said an old fisherman. \u201cThere was an earthquake, and the\nisland was swallowed up by the sea. But although we can no longer\nsee the island, we can still hear the temple bells when the ocean\nsets them swinging down below.\u201d\nThe boy went back to the beach and tried to hear the bells. He\nspent the whole afternoon there, but all he heard was the noise of\nthe waves and the cries of the seagulls.\nWhen night fell, his parents came looking for him. The following\nmorning, he went back to the beach; he could not believe that such a\nbeautiful woman would have lied to him. If she ever returned, he\ncould tell her that, although he had not seen the island, he had heard\nthe temple bells set ringing by the motion of the waves.\nMany months passed; the woman did not return and the boy\nforgot all about her; now he was convinced that he needed to\ndiscover the riches and treasures in the submerged temple. If he"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 128, "chunk": 0, "text": "could hear the bells, he would be able to locate it and salvage the\ntreasure hidden below.\nHe lost interest in school and even in his friends. He became the\nbutt of all the other children\u2019s jokes. They used to say: \u201cHe\u2019s not like\nus. He prefers to sit looking at the sea because he\u2019s afraid of being\nbeaten in our games.\u201d\nAnd they all laughed to see the boy sitting on the shore.\nAlthough he still could not hear the old temple bells ringing, the\nboy learned about other things. He began to realize that he had\ngrown so used to the sound of the waves that he was no longer\ndistracted by them. Soon after that, he became used to the cries of\nthe seagulls, the buzzing of the bees and the wind blowing amongst\nthe palm trees.\nSix months after his first conversation with the woman, the boy\ncould sit there oblivious to all other noises, but he still could not hear\nthe bells from the drowned temple.\nFishermen came and talked to him, insisting that they had heard\nthe bells.\nBut the boy never did.\nSome time later, however, the fishermen changed their tune: \u201cYou\nspend far too much time thinking about the bells beneath the sea.\nForget about them and go back to playing with your friends. Perhaps\nit\u2019s only fishermen who can hear them.\u201d\nAfter almost a year, the boy thought: \u201cPerhaps they\u2019re right. I\nwould do better to grow up and become a fisherman and come down\nto this beach every morning, because I\u2019ve come to love it here.\u201d And\nhe thought too: \u201cPerhaps it\u2019s just another legend and the bells were\nall shattered during the earthquake and have never rung out since.\u201d\nThat afternoon, he decided to go back home.\nHe walked down to the ocean to say goodbye. He looked once\nmore at the natural world around him and because he was no longer\nconcerned about the bells, he could again smile at the beauty of the\nseagulls\u2019 cries, the roar of the sea, and the wind blowing in the palm\ntrees. Far off, he heard the sound of his friends playing and he felt\nglad to think that he would soon resume his childhood games.\nThe boy was happy and\u2014as only a child can\u2014he felt grateful for\nbeing alive. He was sure that he had not wasted his time, for he had"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 129, "chunk": 0, "text": "learned to contemplate Nature and to respect it.\nThen, because he was listening to the sea, the seagulls, the wind\nin the palm trees, and the voices of his friends playing, he also heard\nthe first bell.\nAnd then another.\nAnd another, until, to his great joy, all the bells in the drowned\ntemple were ringing.\nYears later, when he was a grown man, he returned to the village\nand to the beach of his childhood. He no longer dreamed of finding\ntreasure at the bottom of the sea; perhaps that had all been a\nproduct of his imagination, and he had never really heard the\nsubmerged bells ring out on one lost childhood afternoon. Even so,\nhe decided to walk for a while along the beach, to listen to the noise\nof the wind and to the cries of the seagulls.\nImagine his surprise when, there on the beach, he saw the\nwoman who had first spoken to him about the island and its temple.\n\u201cWhat are you doing here?\u201d he asked.\n\u201cI was waiting for you,\u201d she replied.\nHe noticed that, despite the passing years, the woman looked\nexactly the same; the veil hiding her hair had not faded with time.\nShe handed him a blue notebook full of blank pages.\n\u201cWrite: A Warrior of the Light values a child\u2019s eyes because they\nare able to look at the world without bitterness. When he wants to\nfind out if the person beside him is worthy of his trust, he tries to see\nhim as a child would.\u201d\n\u201cWhat is a Warrior of the Light?\u201d\n\u201cYou already know that,\u201d she replied with a smile. \u201cHe is someone\ncapable of understanding the miracle of life, of fighting to the last for\nsomething he believes in\u2014and of hearing the bells that the waves\nset ringing on the seabed.\u201d\nHe had never thought of himself as a Warrior of the Light. The\nwoman seemed to read his thoughts. \u201cEveryone is capable of these\nthings. And, though no one thinks of himself as a Warrior of the\nLight, we all are.\u201d\nHe looked at the blank pages in the notebook. The woman smiled\nagain.\n\u201cWrite about the Warrior,\u201d she said."}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 130, "chunk": 0, "text": "About the Author\nPhoto by Xavier Gonz\u00e1lez\nPAULO COELHO was born in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. His own life\nhas in many ways been as varied and unusual as the protagonists of\nhis internationally acclaimed novels. Like them, Paulo Coelho has\nfollowed a dream in a quest for fulfillment. His own dream, to be a\nwriter, met with frustration throughout much of his early adult life, a\ntime in which he worked at various professions, some of them\nmaterially rewarding but spiritually unfulfilling. \u201cI always knew,\u201d he\nsays, \u201cthat my Personal Legend, to use a term from alchemy, was to\nwrite.\u201d He was thirty-eight when he published his first book.\nIn 1970, after deciding that law school was not for him, he traveled\nthrough much of South America, North Africa, Mexico, and Europe.\nReturning to Brazil after two years, he began a successful career as\na popular songwriter. In 1974, he was imprisoned for a short time by\nthe military dictatorship then ruling in Brazil. In 1980, he experienced\none of the defining moments of his life: he walked the five hundred\u2013\nplus mile Road of Santiago de Compostela in northwestern Spain.\nOn this ancient highway, used for centuries by pilgrims from France\nto get to the cathedral said to house the remains of St. James, he"}
====================
{"file": "The-Alchemist.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 131, "chunk": 0, "text": "achieved a self-awareness and a spiritual awakening that he later\ndescribed in The Pilgrimage.\nPaulo Coelho once said that following your dream is like learning\na foreign language; you will make mistakes but you will get there in\nthe end. In 1988, he published The Alchemist, a novel that explores\nthis theme, and it launched him as an international bestselling\nauthor. Specifically, Paulo Coelho is recognized for his powerful\nstorytelling technique and the profound spiritual insights he blends\nseamlessly into his parables. His books have sold over 150 million\ncopies worldwide. A winner of numerous literary prizes, he has been\na member of the Brazilian Academy of Letters since 2002. Paulo\nCoelho is also a prominent speaker for humanitarian causes. In\n2007, he was named a United Nations Messenger of Peace.\nDiscover great authors, exclusive offers, and more at hc.com."}

{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 1, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  1 \n \nThe Plan of the Giza Pyramids \nby John A.R. Legon \nRevision Date:   22-11-2019 \nMy initial findings on the Giza Site Plan of Three Pyramids were first briefly summarized in a \npamphlet  published by the Archaeology Society of Staten Island in 1979.1  Subsequently, I \ndescribed the most significant features of the integrated site plan in several articles in the journals \nDiscussions in Egyptology2 and G\u00f6ttinger Miszellen.3  Further research has shown that many \nmore factors must be taken into account, without alterating the basic framework of the dimensions \nin royal cubits which I described in 1979. The following text is  based on my article in Discussions \nin Egyptology Vol. 10, but now includes much new material and new illustrations.  In addition, \nacount has been taken of the extensive survey work carried out since 2012 by the late Glen Dash, \nand the positions of the corners of the three pyramids have been placed in the coordinate system \ninitiated by Mark Lehner and David Goodman for the Giza Plateau Mapping Project. \nNow that a detailed topographical study of the Giza Plateau is in progress, 4 it is interesting to \nconsider the results of the excavations and survey carried out by Flinders Petrie in 1880-2, when \nthe exact dimensions and relative positions of the pyramids of Khufu, Khaefre and Menkaure, \nwere established by triangulation..5 With reference to Petrie's survey-data, the present paper \nreviews the evidence first put forward by the writer in 1979, 6 showing that the sizes and relative \npositions of the three pyramids were determined by a single unifying ground plan.  \n                                                \n \n1 J.A.R. Legon, 'The Plan of the Giza Pyramids', Archaeological Reports of the Archaeology Society of Staten Island , \nVol.10 No.1. New York, 1979. \n2  J.A.R. Legon, 'A Ground Plan at Giza', DE 10 (1988), 33-40; 'The Giza Ground Plan and Sphinx', DE 14 (1989), 53-\n60. \n3 . J.A.R. Legon, 'The Design"}
====================
{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 1, "chunk": 1, "text": " of the Pyramid of Khaefre', GM 110 (1989), 27-34; 'The Geometry of the Bent \nPyramid', GM 116 (1990) 65-72, 71; 'The Giza Site Plan Revisited', GM 124 (1991), 69-78. \n4 1. M. Lehner, 'The Development of the Giza Necropolis: The Khufu Project', MDAIK 41, 1985, 109-143.  \n5 2. W.M.F. Petrie, The Pyramids and Temples of Gizeh (London, 1883). First edition only for full details, 34-36.  \n6  J.A.R. Legon, 'The Plan of the Giza Pyramids', Archaeological Reports of the Archaeology Society of Staten Island , \nVol.10 No.1. New York, 1979.  \n "}
====================
{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 2, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  2 \n \nThe existence of a dimensional scheme underlying the placing of the three pyramids is suggested \nin the first instance by the very regular arrangement of these pyramids on the Giza plateau. As a \nresult, the sides of the bases and the distances that separate them define consecutive axial distances \nfrom north to south and from east to west. The three pyramids were accurately aligned with respect \nto the four cardinal points, and were displaced from one another in a configuration which satisfies \nthe requirements of a coherent dimensional design. Certain technical difficulties relating to the site \nchosen for each pyramid in turn also suggest that there must have been some significant constraint, \nin addition to factors such as ease of construction or the selection of the most favourable \narchitectural setting, which determined where each of the three pyramids was positioned. \n \nUsing some of the finest surveying equipment available in his day, Petrie asserted that he had fixed \nthe positions of the main stations in his triangulation to within 3 mm.7 The accuracy of his work is \nproven by the fact that his result for the mean side-length of the Great Pyramid differs from the \nvalue obtained in the meticulous survey carried out by J.H. Cole in 1925,8 by only 1.5 cm,  even \nthough nearly all of the outer casing of the pyramid is missing. Whereas Petrie had located single \npoints of the casing in pits near the centre of each side, excavations in preparation for the work by \nCole showed that substantial traces of the original casing-edge still remained on the pavement in \nsome places where the casing itself has been destroyed. \n                                                \n \n7  Petrie, op.cit., 24. \n8 .J-H..Cole, The determination of the exact size and orientation of the Great Pyramid of Giza, (Survey of Egypt, \npaper no.39), (Cairo, 1925). "}
====================
{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 3, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  3 \nThe dimensions of the three pyramid-bases as determined by Petrie are given in Table I, together \nwith the average variations in the lengths of the sides and the orientations of the three pyramids \nwith respect to true north. The distances separating the centres of the pyramids were computed \nby Petrie along axes constructed parallel to the mean azimuth of the Second and Great Pyramids \nof -4' 52\",9 and are given in Table II.  \nh  Table I      Petrie: Inches   Royal Cubits         Azimuth \n Great Pyramid        9068.8 \u00b1 0.6        439.81          -3' 43\u201d \n  Second Pyramid        8474.9 \u00b1 1.5        411.00          -5' 26\u201d \n Third Pyramid        4153.6 \u00b1 3.0         201.44          14' 03\u201d \nTo obtain the axial components of spacing between the bases of the three pyramids, the distances \nbetween the pyramid-centres can be combined with the sides of the bases, to give the dimensions \nas listed in Table III. There will be small differences at the corners due to slight variations in the \nazimuths of the sides with respect to the axes of the plan; but since the Second and Great Pyramids \nhave the same orientation to within two minutes of arc - a remarkably small divergence - these \ndifferences average only about 5 cm. The Third Pyramid, however, differs in azimuth from the \nSecond and Great Pyramids by about 1/3 degree in a clockwise direction, so that elements of about \n25 cm are generated at the corners relative to the mean components of spacing. The exact positions \ncan be calculated using Petrie's original survey coordinates (see below). \nTable II: Axial Distances between the Centres of the Three  \n          Pyramids as stated by Petrie in Inches \n N to S   E to W \nCentre of 1st to Centre of 2nd Pyramid  13931.6    13165.8 \nCentre of 2nd to Centre of 3rd Pyramid  15170.4     9450.2       \nCentre of 1st to Centre of 3rd Pyramid  29102.0   22616.0 \nWhen the various dimensions are expressed in terms of the"}

{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 4, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  4 \nN side 1st to S side 3rd Pyramid 35713.2 1731.97       1732 \nS side 1st to N side 2nd Pyramid 5159.7 250.23         250 \nS side 2nd to N side 3rd Pyramid 8856.1 429.49 429.5 \nDistances from East to West ... \nW side 1st to W side 2nd Pyramid 12868.8 624.09         624 \nW side 2nd to W side 3rd Pyramid 7289.5 353.52         353.5 \nE side 1st to W side 3rd Pyramid 29227.2 1417.42       1417.5 \nW side 1st to E side 2nd Pyramid 4393.9 213.09         213 \nW side 2nd to E side 3rd Pyramid 3135.9 152.08         152 \nThe Lehner/Goodman and Glen Dash Surveys \n In 1984, Mark Lehner and David Goodman began the Giza Plateau Mapping Project, which was \nintended to produce a topographical contour map of the plateau on a scale large enough to allow \nthe positions of monuments and other archaeological features to be accurately recorded.  In the \nfollowing year, Lehner and Goodman published a map of the Giza plateau which some theorists \nassumed was the result of this new survey work. In fact, however, the various monuments and \nfeatures were traced from  the 1:5000 photogrammetric map which had been prepared by the \nEgyptian Ministry of Housing and Reconstruction, with the assistance of aerial photographs. \nAlthough the EMHR map carries the framework of a grid which could have been used to locate \nstructures on the plateau with sufficient accuracy for archaeological purposes,  Goodman and \nLehner decided to construct a new grid with an origin located at the notional centre of the Great \nPyramid.  This point does not exist on the ground and can only be deduced by reconstructing the \npyramid\u2019s sides and corners. It was assigned the coordinates of 100,000 north and 50,000 east, in \nconsequence of which the coordinates of structures west of the origin require the prefix"}
====================
{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 4, "chunk": 1, "text": " of 499, \nwhile those to south of the origin are prefixed by 99 \u2013 a complication which could easily have been \navoided by placing the origin outside the area of the plateau. Surprisingly, Lehner\u2019s grid is subject \nto an error of scaling of about 1 part in 50, so that the grid coordinates of the Third Pyramid, for \nexample,  are displaced  by about 18 metres. \nConfirmation of the accuracy of Petrie's findings has come from the surveys carried out in 2012 \nand 2015 by the Glen Dash Foundation in conjunction with Ancient Egypt Research Associates, \ncontinuing the work of Lehner and Goodman for the GPMP some thirty years earlier.12 By locating \nPetrie\u2019s original station marks at the corners of the Great Pyramid, and referring to Petrie\u2019s stated \ncoordinates for these stations,  it has emerged that the standard of length implied by the base-line \nof Petrie\u2019s triangulation was effectively lacking by about 1 part in 5,000 \u2013 a discrepancy which \nPetrie himself noted when he compared his findings with the baseline of the previous survey by \nDavid Gill.13  Taking this into account in a significant endorsement of Petrie's work, Glen Dash \n                                                \n \n12   Glen Dash, 'New Angles on the Great Pyramid' , Aeragram 13-2, Fall 2012, 10-19 \n13  See Petrie, Pyramids and Temples p. 205-7.  The shortfall may perhaps be ascribed to Petrie\u2019s base-line measuring \nequipment, which was of his own devising . "}

Glen Dash, 'Where, Precisely, are the Three Pyramids of Giza?'. \nhttp://www.academia.edu/6056783/Where_Precisely_are_the_Three_Pyramids_of_Giza  \n15 It will be noted that the azimuth and length of cubit differ very slightly from the values obtained in the writer\u2019s \noriginal analysis. {"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 6, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  6 \nconstructed. The dimensions would thus have been measured out from the north-eastern area of the \nplateau, southwards and westwards towards the Second and Third Pyramids. The task of setting \nout the plan would have been no more difficult in principle than laying out the base of a single \npyramid, and it will be noted that the components of spacing between the three pyramids are in \neach case shorter than the side-length of the Great Pyramid. \nBefore the extensive quarrying of the rock for building stone took  place, the natural \nsurface of the Giza plateau had a general slope of around 5 degrees, and the projection onto \nthe horizontal plane of a measurement taken over the surface would have been reduced by \nabout 0.4%. Thus the dimensions of the site plan could have been laid out with reasonable  \naccuracy without correcting for the slope of the plateau. Once the approximate position for \neach pyramid had been determined, however, the sites were leveled around the perimeter, \nand may also have been connected by temporary horizontal-topped embankments so that \nthe east-west and north-south components of spacing between the three pyramid bases \ncould be laid down with the greatest accuracy. While ropes may have been used in the \ninitial marking out of the site plan, the observed accuracy in the finished dimensions was \nprobably achieved  through the use of pairs of butting measuring rods laid alternately end \nover end \u2013 a method capable of achieving a high degree of precision.16 \n \nThe Great Pyramid \nIt is generally accepted that the sides of the Great Pyramid measure 440 cubits, although \nonly the longest or south side has exactly this length according to the survey by Cole.17  In \nterms of the Giza royal cubit of 0.52375 metres or 20.620 inches, the actual mean side of \n230.364 metres corresponds to 439.8 cubits, with an average variation in the sides of only 6 \ncm or 0.1 cubit. Petrie suggested that an adjustment had been effected such that the \nperimeter of the base would express the 'pi-proportion' in relation to the height of 280 \ncubits, with greater accuracy than the value for \u03c0 of 22/7.18 In this case, the theoretical side-\nlength will be  (140 \u00d7 \u03c0) or 439.822... cub"}
====================
{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 6, "chunk": 1, "text": "its.  \nAlthough the mean side-length of the Great Pyramid in the survey by the Glen Dash \nFoundation is just 1 mm less than Cole\u2019s mean result, small differences in the alignment of \nthe individual sides give rise to variations in the side-lengths which cannot now be resolved.. \nCole\u2019s findings must take precedence over those of Glen Dash, however, because the traces \nof the casing-edge were better preserved. The use of regression analysis by the GDF team to \ndetemine confidence limits for the lengths of the sides is flawed because the data does not \nsatisfy the statistical requirements. \n \nThe Placing of the Second Pyramid \nTurning now to the position of the Second Pyramid relative to the Great Pyramid, the \nanalysis of Petrie's survey data shows that the mean north-south spacing between the two \npyramids is 250.2 cubits. It seems likely, therefore, that the builders intended to place the \nnorth side of the Second Pyramid on a line just 250 cubits southwards from the south side of \n                                                \n \n16  S. Clarke and R. Engelbach suggest an accuracy to one part in 250,000.  Ancient Egyptian Masonry (Oxford 1930), \n66. \n17 Length of south side, 230.454 metres; Cole, op.cit., 6 \n18 Petrie, op.cit., 220 "}
====================
{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 7, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  7 \nthe Great Pyramid. Taking further distances along the north-south axis, the impression of a \ndeliberate design is strongly supported. The distance southwards from the north side of the \nGreat Pyramid to the south side of the Second Pyramid is 1101 cubits, or only 0.1% greater \nthan the round-figure of 1100 cubits. This is just 2\u00bd times the side of the Great Pyramid of \n440 cubits, and the south sides of the two pyramids are separated by an axial distance from \nnorth to south of about 3/2 \u00d7 440 or 660 cubits.  \nFrom these plausible formative dimensions of 440 and 250 cubits, we can now obtain a \nprovisional design-value for the side-length of the Second Pyramid as follows: \n \nNominal  Side-length of Second Pyramid = 440 \u00d7 3/2 - 250 = 410 cubits \n \nI have termed this the nominal side-length of the Second Pyramid, because Petrie's survey-\ndata gives an actual mean side of of 8474.9 inches or exactly 411 cubits. The average \nvariation in the sides from their mean length is only 1.5 inches or 4 cm. Thus although the \nabove derivation accounts for a dimension of about 410 cubits in preference to one of just \n400 cubits, an adjustment of one cubit appears to have been made to the actual side-length. \nReasons for this adjustment will be given shortly. \nNow taking dimensions along the east-west axis, Petrie's data places the west side of the \nSecond Pyramid 624 cubits westwards from the west side of the Great Pyramid. Again with \nan adjustment of one cubit, therefore, this dimension may be equated with a nominal value of \n2\u00bd \u00d7 250 or 625 cubits, making it analogous to the distance of 2\u00bd \u00d7 440 or 1100 cubits along \nthe north-south axis. Hence the side-length of the Second Pyramid and the position relative to \nthe Great Pyramid may be ascribed to a simple design based upon modules of 440 and 250 "}
====================
{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 8, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  8 \ncubits. The side-length of the Second Pyramid is defined as (1\u00bd \u00d7 440 - 250) or 410 cubits, \nwhile the east-west spacing from the Great Pyramid is found to be (625 - 410) or 215 cubits: \nWith reference to this modular scheme, however, the builders evidently subtracted one cubit \nfrom the dimension of 625 cubits, and added one cubit to the dimension of 1100 cubits, \nmaking the side-length of the Second Pyramid equal to 411 cubits, while the east-west \nspacing from the Great Pyramid became (624 - 411) or 213 cubits (see Table III). These \nadjustments suggest that further factors influenced the final choice of dimensions; and indeed \nthese factors are found to have anticipated the inclusion of the Third Pyramid in the \ncompleted ground plan.  \n \nThe Enclosing Rectangle of the Site Plan \nAs shown by the survey-data in Table III, the Third Pyramid extends the scheme of the Second \nand Great Pyramids by 631 cubits towards the south and 353.5 cubits towards the west. The \noverall dimensions of the Giza site plan are thereby defined along the two axes. Computing these \nenclosing dimensions from the component parts, we find:  \nOverall East-West Dimension    = 440 + 624 + 353.5 = 1417.5 cubits  \nOverall North-South Dimension = 440 + 661 + 631 = 1732 cubits "}

{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 9, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  9 \nRather surprisingly,  these dimensions  represent the square roots of the first two prime numbers, \ntwo and three, multiplied by a factor of 1000. The theoretical values are: \n \n                   1000\u221a2 = 1414.21... ,      1000\u221a3 = 1732.05... \nWhile the north-south dimension thus expresses the value of 1000\u221a3 exactly, the east-west \ndimension displays a discrepancy of about 3.3 cubits with respect to the exact value of 1000\u221a2. \nThis apparent error amouts to only about 0.2%, however, and is explained by other factors in the \nformulation of the dimensions, as we will see. \nThe occurrence of these square root values in the dimensions of the Giza plan points to a \ngeometrical development beginning with a square of 1000 cubits, as shown in the diagram below. \nThe east-west dimension of 1000\u221a2 cubits is first obtained as the diagonal length in this square, \nwhich is marked off along the north side to give the overall dimension from east to west. A \nrectangle measuring 1000 by 1000\u221a2 cubits is then constructed, with a diagonal length of 1000\u221a3 \ncubits which is marked off along the east side to give  the overall dimension of the plan from north \nto south. \nThe validity of this geometry is confirmed by the ease with which it can be extended so as to \ndefine the major division of the plan which takes place at the south side of the Second \nPyramid.  It is in fact only necessary to draw in the diagonal of the enclosing rectangle on a \nplan of \u221a2 : \u221a3 to obtain a point of intersection with the opposing diagonal of the initial square \non a plan of 1 : 1.  This defines a length of diagonal equal to the dimension of 1101 cubits \nwhich encloses the Second and Great Pyramids from north to south, as shown below .                             \n \nIt will be seen that the diagonal rising from southern end of the base-line of 1000\u221a3 cubits on a \nplan of  \u221a2 : \u221a3, intersects the diagonal rising from northern end on a plan of 1:1, such as to "}

{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 10, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  10 \ndivide the base-line in the ratio of \u221a2 : \u221a3. Consequently, the length marked off along  the 1 : 1 \ndiagonal will be: \n                       \u221a2 \n1000 \u221a3  \u00d7   --------    \u00d7  \u221a2  =  1101.020\u2026cubits \n                   \u221a2 + \u221a3 \nHence nearly the exact whole number of 1101 cubits which we earlier ascribed to a simple \nmodular scheme adjusted by one cubit,  is now seen to have had its origin in the most \nfundamental geometry of the enclosing rectangle of the site plan. \n \nIt is also possible to construct the enclosing rectangle starting from a double square or 1:2 \nrectangle of 1000  \u00d7 2000 cubits.  While the east-west dimension of 1000\u221a2 cubits is given \n once again by the diagonal in each component square of 1000 cubits,  the north-south \ndimension is constructed with reference to the diagonal of the double square of 1000\u221a5 \ncubits. When this dimension is applied as  the hypotenuse in a right triangle having the \ndimension of 1000\u221a2 cubits as base,  the height of the triangle will be 1000\u221a3 cubits. The \nhypotenuse, furthermore, intersects the opposing diagonal of one component square so as to \ndivide the length of the double square in the exact ratio of \u221a2 : \u221a3, or into parts of 899 and \n1101 cubits. Thus the major north-south division of the site plan is defined as before. \n "}

{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 11, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  11 \nNeedless to say, these geometrical constructions are conceptual and would have been \nworked out by the architect on a convenient scale on a drawing board or scribing floor.  \nOnly the pyramid bases and the components of spacing between them had to be marked  \nout on the ground of the Giza plateau. \nCompletion of the Site Plan \nThe evaluation of Petrie's survey-data shows that the north-south overall dimension of the \nGiza site plan together with the division at the south side of the Second Pyramid, satisfy the \ngeometrical requirements with complete accuracy. The question therefore arises as to why \nthe east-west overall dimension diverges from the value of 1000\u221a2 or 1414.2 cubits by \nabout three cubits. That this is not an error is initially indicated by the fact that the axial \ncomponent of 353.5 cubits westwards from the Second Pyramid to the west side of the \nThird Pyramid has the value of 250\u221a2 cubits:  \n250\u221a2 = 353.55... cubits \nThus this dimension is accurately one-quarter of the ideal overall dimension on the same \naxis. It is the length of the diagonal in the modular layout squares of 250 cubits, which define \nthe north-south spacing between the Second and Great Pyramids and the dimension of about \n2\u00bd \u00d7 250 or 625 cubits on the east-west axis. Adding this element of 353.5 cubits  to the \ndistances as already defined in our initial modular scheme along the east-west axis gives an \noverall east-west dimension of (440 + 625 + 353.5) equals 1418.5 cubits, which is more than \n4 cubits greater than the value of 1000\u221a2 cubits. Thus the subtraction of one cubit from the \ncomponent of 2\u00bd \u00d7 250 or 625 cubits may be seen as a judicious adjustment which improved \nthe accuracy of the square-root value in the overall dimension, without unduly undermining \nthe integrity of the modular scheme. This adjustment, furthermore, was balanced by the \naddition of one cubit to the modular dimension of 2\u00bd \u00d7 440 or 1100 cubits, to satisfy the    \nfundamental division of the overall dimension at the south side of the Second Pyramid. \nThe mathematical import"}

{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 11, "chunk": 1, "text": " of the site plan is greatly enhanced by the expression of the square \nroots of 2, 3, 5 and 7, in each case multiplied by the module of 250 cubits.  The side-length \nof the Second Pyramid  being 411 cubits, the axial distance westwards from the centre of the \nSecond Pyramid to west side of the Third Pyramid is:  \n411/2 + 353.5  =  559 cubits  \n           and     250 \u221a5  =  559.01...  \nThe east-spacing between the Second Pyramid and Great Pyramid being (624 - 411) or 213 cubits,  \nthe axial distance westwards from the centre of the Great Pyramid to the east side of the Second \nPyramd is found to be: \n   440/2 + 213  =  433 cubits \n         and       250\u221a3  =  433.01.. {"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 12, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  12 \nThis is the length of diagonal in the rectangle measuring 250 \u00d7 250\u221a2 cubits, which is contained in \nthe Giza site plan between the north-south dimension of 250 cubits and the east-west dimension of \n353.5 cubits. It is now evident that a 1 : \u221a3 : 2 right triangle with hypotenuse of 500 cubits and \nadjacent sides of 250 and 433 cubits can be constructed on the spacing between the Second and \nGreat Pyramids, as shown below.  \n \nFinally,  the axial distance southwards from the Great Pyramid to the south side of the Second \nPyramid is:  \n                                                   (250 + 411) = 661 cubits  \nand    250\u221a7 = 661.437...  \nIn closely connected dimensions along the two axes of the plan, therefore, the square roots \nof two, three, five, and seven are all accurately represented in terms of a module of 250 \ncubits.  Three  of these square-roots values are represented elsewhere in the plan with a \nfactor of 1000 cubits..Given that the site plan contains only seven independent dimensions \n\u2013 the three pyramid bases and the four components of spacing -  the fact that seven square \nroot values are expressed in the dimensions is remarkable. \nIt will be seen that the addition of one cubit to the nominal side of the Second Pyramid of \n410 cubits facilitated the accurate expression of 250\u221a3 and 250\u221a5 on the east-west axis, \nand also resulted in a good approximation to 250\u221a7 on the north-south axis. This last "}

{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 13, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  13 \ndimension is a natural product of the geometry already described., and can be constructed \nas the diagonal in a rectangle measuring 250\u221a2 by 250\u221a5 cubits, or as the diagonal in a \nrectangle measuring 250\u221a3 by 500 cubits. In conclusion, the square roots of the first four \nprime numbers are all defined in the Giza plan in terms of the module of 250 cubits., which \ndefines the north-south spacing between the Second and Great Pyramids. \nThe Scheme of the Third Pyramid \nThe Third Pyramid seems to have served primarily as a corner marker in the Giza site plan, and \nthereby extends the scheme of the Second and Great Pyramids by 353.5 cubits towards the west \nand 631cubits towards the south to define the enclosing rectangle of the plan.. It has dimensions of \nits own, however, which represent a significant development of the design. It so happens that the \nnumbers 353.5 and 631 are in the almost exact ratio of 1: (1 + \u03c0/4), and can therefore be used to \ngenerate the pi-proportion of the Great Pyramid within the bounding 353.5 by 631 cubit rectangle  \n                 "}

{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 14, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  14 \n   \nSubtracting the short side from the long  side leaves a remainder of (631 \u2013 353.5) or 277.5 cubits, \nwhich is in the ratio of  \u03c0 : 4 to the short side of 353.5 cubits and so yields  the \u03c0/4 pyramid slope:.  \nAs shown in the diagram above, the side-length of the Third Pyramid is defined within the \nrectangle of 277.5 by 353.5 cubits.by the intersection of a line drawn on a plan of 1:1 from the \nSW corner, with a line drawn on a plan of 1:2 from the NE corner. This results in a space on \nthe east side which is twice as wide as the space on the north side, giving dimensions of 152 \nand 152/2 cubits respectively. The side-length of the Third Pyramid is thus found to be (353.5 \n\u2013 152) = (277.5 \u2013 76) =  201.5 cubits, in agreement with Petrie's mean survey result of 4153.6 \ninches or 201.44 cubits..  The element of 152 cubits determines the east-west spacing between \nthe Second and Third Pyramids, and is exactly one-seventh of the consecutive axial distance of \n1064 cubits from the west side of the Second Pyramid to the east side of the Great Pyramid.. \nThese relationships form the basis for a scheme of the circle squared, in which a square with \na side of 500 cubits is circumscribed by a circle with radius of 250\u221a2 or 353.5 cubits, and a \ncircumference of 2220 cubits (for pi = 3.140).  To square the circle, a second square with a \nside of 555 cubits is centred on the first square but aligned along the diagonal, generating the \nelements as described above. \n \n \n \n "}

{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 15, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  15 \n \nWe must also note that the base of the Third Pyramid is equal to the side of a cube, the volume of \nwhich is  that of a sphere with a diameter equal to the module of 250 cubits.  The exact side-length \nrequired for this cubing of the sphere being 201.499 cubits, the result is not lacking in accuracy. \n \nThe Orientation of the Third Pyramid \nThe occurrence of half numbers of cubits in the planning of the Third Pyramid is associated with \nthe slight difference in the orientation of this pyramid with respect to the axes of  the site plan, \nsufficient to shift the corners by 0.5 cubit in a clockwise direction relative to the midpoints of the \nsides. By this means, whole tens of cubits were introduced into dimensions which would otherwise \nhave been greater or less by 0.5 cubit, and a secondary set of requirements for the dimensions \nrelating to the Third Pyramid was facilitated. \n \nThe north-south spacing between the Second and Third Pyramids was thus increased to 430 cubits \nwhen measured to the north-east corner of the Third Pyramid, but reduced to 429 cubits when \nmeasured to the north-west corner. The lesser dimension combines with the side-length of the \nSecond Pyramid to give a distance of (429 + 411) or 840 cubits, which is just three times the \nheight of the Great Pyramid.  It will also be seen that the north-west corner of the Third Pyramid is \n(429 + 1101) or 1530 cubits southwards from the northern boundary of the plan, while the south-\nwest corner is (354 + 411) equals 765 or 1530/2 cubits westwards  from the east side of the Second  \nPyramid. There is thus a hint of the further relationships which are hidden within structure of the \nplan.19  \n \nConclusion \nWhilst the wealth of evidence here presented leaves no doubt whatsoever that the three great Giza \nPyramids are the components of a single unified site plan of surprising sophistication, it must be \nadmitted that the existence of the plan is entirely unexpected by Egyptologists, and indeed makes \nliitle sense in the context of ancient Egyptian funerary architecture.  The Egyptian kings were not \ngiven to forming positional relationships between their tombs and those of their predecessors and \n"}
====================
{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 15, "chunk": 1, "text": "successors,  and the mathematical nature of the design at Giza can hardly be explained by any \nknown requirements of the funerary cult. \n \nWhereas the Egyptologist will see this as a reason to dismiss the site plan as a strange aberration \nthat can have no relevance for their subject,  the true scientist will recognise the impossibility of \nthe mathematical relationships having arisen by chance, especially given the accuracy, simplicity \nand coherence of the design,  and the consistency with which a particular theme \u2013 the expression \nof square roots \u2013 was pursued by the architect.  It is possible to envisage the occasional \napproximate occurrence of such numbers popping up in random sets of dimensions by chance, but \nthe systematic and accurate expression of the square roots of the first four prime numbers with a \nfactor of 250 cubits, duplicated in three instances with a factor of 1000 cubits, cannot possibly be \ndismissed as coincidence. \n \n                                                \n \n   19 . These results point to a further geometrical development of the plan as described in The Giza Site  \n         Plan Revisited' in G\u00f6ttinger Miszellen124 (1991). \n "}

{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 16, "chunk": 0, "text": "The Plan of the Giza Pyramids  16 \nIf, as the present writer believes, the existence of the site plan cannot be reconciled with the \nfunerary theory, then it is not the solid factual evidence of the dimensional relationhips that is at \nfault, for this is the bed-rock reality of the Giza site. The evidence for the usage of these pyramids \nas tombs by certain kings of the Fourth Dynasty, on the other hand, is secondary and superficial, \nand could be explained by the appropriation of pre-existing monuments. The Giza layout provides \ncompelling evidence in support of the claim which is made in the Osirian Scripts,20 to the effect \nthat the three pyramids were constructed as a centre for the initiation of priest-neophytes into the \noccult wisdom of ancient Egypt, some thousands of years before the founding of the historical \nFirst Dynasty. \n \nNeedless to say, the notion that the Giza pyramids and temples could predate the Fourth Dynasty is \nunlikely to find many supporters in orthodox circles, but is nonetheless worthy of consideration in \nthe view of the present writer.. The fact that the name of Khufu is found written on the internal \nmasonry of the Great Pyramid in no way invalidates this possibility, since it is obvious that a king \nwho wished to claim ownership of the monument would have been obliged to adopt the name of \nthe original builder as his own, in order to avoid the need to erase the name from the fabric of the \npyramid  \u2013 an  impossible task. \n \nThe historical Khufu of the Fourth Dynasty would not, however, have wanted to be remembered as \nthe appropriator of the Great Pyramid, but rather as the builder, and to this end it is conceivable \nthat he required the population of Egypt to contribute stones towards its construction. Garbled \nreferences to this state of affairs may be found in the history of Herodotus, who tells us that Khufu \nplunged into all manner of wickedness.  He closed the temples, forbade the Egyptians from \nmaking offerings to the gods, and instead compelled them to labour one and all in his service.21  \nHe  raised money by prostituting his own daughter, who being bent on leaving a monument which \nwould perpetuate her own memory, required each man to make her a present of a stone towards the \nworks which she contemplated.. The records"}
====================
{"file": "The_Plan_of_the_Giza_Pyramids.pdf", "source": "pdf", "page": 16, "chunk": 1, "text": " concerning the delivery of stones to the site which \nhave recently been found at the port of Wadi el Jarf on the coast of the Red Sea have been assumed \nto support the conventional view of Khufu\u2019s activities, but could equally show how officials were \nrequired to deliver stones to the Giza site and keep a detailed account of their contribution to the \nking\u2019s faux pyramid-building exercise.. \n \nLeading Egyptologists have long recognised the difficulty of maintaining that a monument as vast \nas the Great Pyramid could have been built in the reign of one king.. The work load in terms of \nblocks of stone moved into position each day was simply too great. The idea that the Giza \nPyramids predate the Fourth Dynasty may seem preposterous to many, but is justified by the \nrecords preserved by the Egyptians themselves in documents such as the Turin King List and the \nhistory of Manetho. Here we find mention of an era of remote antiquity known as Zep Tepi \u2013 the \nFirst Time - when Egypt was ruled by priest-initiates who founded the divine dynasties and were \nlater revered as gods or demigods. Scattered across Egypt are monuments that date back to this era \nbut are mostly deeply buried beneath the silt of the Nile, although some were restored and reused \nby the kings of the \u2018authentic\u2019 period..Amongst these monuments, its position carefully integrated \nwith the Giza plan, the Great Sphinx still stands as the enduring guardian of the genuine mystery \nregarding which I have endeavoured throw a glimmering light. \n                                                \n \n20 See H.C. Randall-Stevens, Atlantis to the Latter Days.  Jersey, 1966.   http://www.cdfas.plus.com/kta.htm \n21 The History of Herodotus, Book II Chap.124-6. "}
